description:
Chad is the best! Hi Chad! 

This place has amazing wine, delicious cheese and meat plates (with plenty of bread - there's never enough bread!), and ambiance that can't be beat. The staff is fabulous, and always ready to suggest wines so I don't need to pretend I know what I want.  

The art is always interesting (we became "patrons of the arts" for the first time at an opening 3 years ago), and you can tell that people come here to have a relaxing, enjoyable time, escaping from the hectic City to the solace of Hotel Biron. 

Fab wine bar for a date, meeting up with friends, or stopping by after dinner nearby.
author: Mimi M.

description: Adorable and cozy, with friendly and laid back staff. Nice, generous pours too. It was a great place to be able to catch up with a friend in relative peace.
author: B. Y.

description:
A charming dimly-lit wine bar hidden in an alleyway on the streets of SF, ideal for a secret conversation with a friend. Skip the Hog's head and plot your plans for Dumbledore's army here. Some lovely paintings on the wall make for a pretty sighting.

Drinks are great and the bartender knowledgeable, try the hefe and malbec.
author: Siddhartha G.

description:
Cute little wine bar which wasn't too crowded on a weeknight.  Good wine list and cheese was delicious.  Service was slow, but wasn't a big deal.

I did not enjoy the experience however due to the strong odor of cleaning product. The whole bar unfortunately smelled like a freshly mopped bathroom.  In general I do not want to get bathroom vibes form a place, but particularly in a wine bar where your sense of smell is so important.
author: Kristina H.

description: Intimate spot that is easy to miss in a small, side street. Dimly lit, narrow, mostly tables and two couches. You order at the bar and can sit anywhere. I came here on a weeknight and loved that the place wasn't crowded. Good wine selection and the cheese and meat selections are soooooooo yum. Great date spot or place to chill with a small group of friends!
author: Annie S.

description:
Even though service at the bar was overtly unfriendly and frazzled, I can still appreciate the specialness of Hotel Biron. It's dark & cavern-like. It's casual but sexy. It feels very European, in that effortlessly cool kind of way. A true hidden gem. 

You order everything at the bar (hence, the frazzled bartender). The wine list is divided by region, repping US, France, Italy, Germany, South America, Spain, New Zealand, etc. Over 20 wines offered by the glass, but bottles are definitely a better deal. I did the math: bottle price is 3x the glass price, and you definitely get at least 5 glasses in a bottle! After all, this is the kind of place you want to stay and lounge for a while, so bottles make sense. 

Food is simple: build your own cheese & charcuterie plates. What more do you need? Nothing really. 

The right spot for a laid back nightcap, pre-dinner drinks, or simple catch-up date with friends. Note, it's cozy, so better for small groups (2-4) than large ones.
author: Nique F.

description:
Definitely a hidden gem!! 

Stumbled across this little wine bar while waiting for a table at Zuni Cafe, conveniently located a few doors down. 

This is such a cute little wine bar - good selection, knowledgeable staff, and cozy interior.
I had only 1 drink there, and definitely would've stayed for another.

I will come back very soon for more drinks and conversation in the future :)
author: Taylor M.

description: Service was terrible. The decor was very dated and falling apart. Wine list was good but really expensive and in-imaginative. Better wine bars out there in SF for sure
author: David F.

description: Hotel Biron offers the most crisp & stimulating sparkling wine/champagne selections I've encountered in SF. They also have tasty wines and beers, which my friends love.  And How could I not mention their cheese and charcuterie?! They're always delicious, decadent & filling enough for your French soul! Surely, your life must be rather melancholy without Hotel Biron in your life!
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description:
Hôtel Biron is not a hotel at all. It's a swank wine bar tucked away on a side street around the corner from Market Street. Unless somebody told you about, you probably didn't know of its existence. Well. Now you know! Only tell your cool friends okay.

After a tough week... wait, who am I kidding? After any day, a glass of wine to kickstart your tastebuds, or fire up your nose with splendid aromas of berry, oak and spice is always a welcome reward. Dimly lit, Hôtel Biron forces you to use your inside voice as you leave the hustle of life at the threshold. It is not a place for your entire office, or gang of friends.  So join a pal and leave the 'group' behind. The tables are for two and four, nothing more. 

There's no table service (sigh) so you'll need to get up and place your next order. Credit cards and cash are accepted forms of payment. The menu offers a varied range of American, French and Argentinean wines. They may have Italian as well. Though I can't recall. I was with my Argentinean friend so we focused on the other three. Champagne of course is also served. 

If I could make one request, I would like more single glass options. My friend wanted to try a glass of the St. Émilion, which unfortunately was only by the bottle ($55). Aside from that, it is a very nice wine bar.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Tucked away and spacious. Open late, unlike most places in the city.

In fact, I don't want more people to know about it. ;P
author: Victoria C.

description:
Never coming back!!!

Came tonight, Saturday, my friend and I started a tab and gave the card, went our merry way drinking.

He does last call, OK. Cool thanks.

Its about 1.  We kinda finish up our convo and then figure we should go.  The bartender asks us for our tab name, we tell him.  

Its then that i dunno where the communication went wrong.  We thought, its last call, he runs our card, we sign out.  My friend goes up to do that, gets a bad vibe from the girls sitting at the bar.

They work there. So were they giving us the stink eye just cuz we were the last to sign our tab???

When we leave, I heard the girl at the bar say "DON'T come back soon".  I turned around as soon as the door shut and was like WTF!?  They muttered it like hoping we wouldn't hear but we did.  And we are two women innocently having wine at a table...

I'm a bar tender in this town for 8 years and ive hanged out at my place of business many many nights. I would NEVER EVER bad mouth a customer leaving like that.  Just because they were slow closing out or anything... you keep it to yourself.

We are probably never coming here again.  Industry people beware no love here!
author: Kitty O.

description:
I really liked this place! Beautiful ambiance with the dim lighting and cork ceiling. Came here for a friend's birthday and we had a really great time sitting in back with about a party of 10. 

Not really a wine person, but I DEFINITELY found my new favorite thanks to this place. My friend and I both ordered the Dessert Wine from Portugal, "Mas Candi". Tasted like Apple Cider. If you're looking for sweet, I would definitely recommend this one. Cheers to Hôtel Biron! ;-)
author: Bria S.

description:
What a cute hidden gem of a wine bar Hotel Biron is. 

With a nondescript entrance on an alley just parallel to Market Street, it's easy to miss it. Inside is a cosy little wine bar with quite a few comfy spots to lounge around. If you're lucky, you can get one of the few couches here. Great for date night. We came here after my birthday dinner and shared a couple bottles of lovely wine and some cheese. Really loved the relaxed vibe of the place. 

As a bonus, they have a small selection of bottled beers BUT they have my most favorite Belgian brew - Straffe Hendrik tripel. They ran out the night I was there (they did have the quad but I like the tripel more) but the sure fact that they offer it, plus the cosy atmosphere, are good enough reasons to return.
author: Jon L.

description:
This is my favorite bar in the city. The wines are, without fail, excellent (and often organic/sustainably harvested, if you care about that kind of thing). And the cheese/charcuterie selections are also well chosen and affordable with generous portions.
(NB: they rotate about half the menu every couple of months, I think). 

The bartenders (often the owner) are always very generous, offering tastes prior to large pours of wine by the glass, and they like to give information about the wine without being condescending.

There isn't really table service (the complaints about negligent service are confusing), and I'm not sure why you'd need it for wine and cheese/charcuterie (they do bring the food out to you and they bus the tables). 

The atmosphere is cozy and laid back, and it maintains that vibe even when there's a crowd. The art on the walls is sometimes questionable, but it's for sale, so I assume they are supporting locals, and that's good enough for me.
author: Aimee F.

description: The ambiance is the real sell here -- dimly lit, cozy space. Last time I went, I'm pretty sure most of the patrons were on dates. It's a great space to split a bottle of mid-price wine ($50+).
author: Bre D.

description: Cute, hidden date spot. Perfect for an intimate night.
author: Yad L.

description: This was a nice place to meet up. It's a wine bar. The space is kinda tight and small. I got a ginger beer and it was served in a nice glass. We sat outside because it was too loud and tight inside.
author: Denise C.

description:
Love this place! It's just like a quaint, casual European wine bar. 

I dropped a star, because the service can be European, as well. The servers - while very friendly and polite - are not attentive to the tables. One has to walk up to the bar to get wine and order munchies. But don't let that deter you!

The cheese, pate, and riette were all VERY delicious and well worth the $7.

I tasted three wines: one champagne and two reds (all French). Absolutely rock star wines. It seems pricey at $13 per glass, but they really do pour a full glass of quality wine. Patrons are meant to show up with a friend or two and order a bottle, which is why there are so many bottles listed. Besides, that's how it works in many places in Italy.

I added back the star I dropped at the beginning, because this place is open until 2am. It seems that so few wine bars do this! I found my new spot.
author: Jeremy T.

description:
TIP:  Don't just take the first free table out front.  There is an inconspicuous seating area in the back with a comfy couch.

Hotel Biron is a wonderful venue.  I love the backstreet location on a small European side lane that splits through a block near Market St.  Never a tourist, this is purely a locals spot.

The wine selection is worldly.  Whether you prefer German, Italian, French or domestic, you'll find an option here.  Glasses start at $12 and average $14.  No full bar here - just wine.

You get all your drinks at the bar; there is no table service.  However, this is a-okay.  The server the night we went was Chad.  He was knowledgeable and friendly.  As we were walking up he was regaling the whole bar with a hilarious story.  A great bartender.

The only negative - and causing the loss of a star - was the incredibly strong sanitizer/bleach smell upon entry.  We went early in the evening so I suspect that the staff had just washed down the floors.  After about 15 minutes inside, our noses acclimated and we could no longer smell it.  But if you went outside for a bit and came back in, it was distinctly still present.

The noise level here is low - perfect for great conversations.  No reservations - just show up.
author: Joel J.

description:
Do not go here unless you dig European-style taverns with friendly, knowledgable bar staff, excellent girl/guy ratios and supremely interesting and fun wine lists.

That said, the beer selection could be better, but I'll be back for the wine.
author: Tyler M.

description:
Awesome wine bar! I'm on this perpetual pursuit of the perfect wine bar and have been frequenting a decent amount around SF. 

Hotel Biron didn't look like much from the outside. In fact, when I saw the small alley-like street, the dark opening marked by a faded "B" right next to the rear kitchen entrance of a restaurant I thought I'd made a mistake. 

Once you venture inside though, you're met with a lot of dark brick and wood, dim lighting and sectioned off rooms. All in all, a perfect wine-drinking evening environment.

There are a couple thick couches thrown around, and the menu is simple but expansive. This place could easily double as a coffee shop during the day that I would love to come read at. 

 Wish I lived closer!
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
In my head, and in the imagination of countless movie directors, the way you enter Hotel Biron is no different than walking into a Victorian London brothel...and Jack the Ripper is standing by and waiting to behead your whore ass.  

But I sashayed my whore ass here like I was about to kill Jack the Ripper for like, giving me syphillis or something (I'm bad at this). The bread here was plentiful, enough to soak up all of Jack the Ripper's bloody remains. The bar lady tender was a bitch, but this is Frisco, and I shouldn't have called it that. Or wear a shirt that said "the City" with San Jose's skyline depicted.  However, I'm not in a wine bar not just for the attitude, I'm here for THAT and wine.  And this place has a pretty good list of "New California" wines that would give Robert Parker gout.
author: Jalop N.

description:
Hotel Biron tries to be Inconspicuous by hiding itself in an alley behind Zuni Cafe, but I was smart enough to check out the Yelp reviews before hand because the only clue to this place is a glowing orange "B"  sign. 

What does the "B" stand for?

B stands for Bacchus. They are serious about their wine choices (heavy on European varietals) and looking at that looong list will make your brain work extra hard. Order their cheese/charcuterie plate to keep your synapses firing away.

B stands for Break. It will  break the bank. They have 30+ wines by the glass, but do not offer wine flights. Ask for a taste from the barman before making a choice.

B stands for Berate. As in, I'm berating myself for not seeking this place out sooner!

B stands for Babe.  Seriously, bring your babe when you go here on date night: exposed brick, cozy interior and low lighting. Hey, everyone looks good in candle light, right?

B stands for Banging. That's what you'll be doing after a bottle of wine and a hot kissing session on their comfortable couch in a secluded area towards the back of the bar. 

You're welcome.
author: Janice C.

description:
I like that this place is a bit hidden and feels like it was probably a speakeasy back in the day. It is small though, and I can tell it would be awful if crowded. 

I really appreciate their cheese selection (I might be a cheese-aholic) and they serve an appropriate quantity of bread with it. 

I don't love that their wine selections start at $12/glass or $39/bottle, and I'll hesitate to return because of it. I was looking for even one $7-9 option, but I had to drink beer for that. 

Beyond the pricey wine, it's hard to get between it and the rest of the city without some walking at least 3 city blocks from Van Ness Muni (not the place to break in your new stilettos) or taking a cab-- all in all, an expensive night that's really just OK.
author: Krista L.

description:
Hands down, my favorite wine bar in the city.  Everything about it is what a wine bar should be.  The selection of wine is extraordinary with knowledgeable bartenders assisting you.  Additionally, they have a relatively fine selection of beer for the non-wine drinkers.

What sets this place apart is the ambience.  It just has an uplifting and grown up feel to it.  One of my go to's in the city and it never disappoints.
author: Steve A.

description:
This wine venue is located in an isolated, discrete alley, in which I would have never known about or encounter upon.  

With its narrow pathway and limited space for lounging, this hole-in-the-wall place, exudes an underground, chill vibe.

It's surely not calling for any attention and I feel like only passer-bys and the neighborhood would know about this spot.

If you're looking for some seclusion over wine and a nice getaway from the main crowd, this place fits perfectly with your agenda.
author: Tiffany D.

description: The perfect date spot. Nice ambiance, interesting, not crowded or empty, great wine (they have beer too). I never order a specific glass, I just describe what I like in a wine and they let you try a few before buying.
author: Sydney M.

description:
guy behind bar seemed nice but we didn't really interact with him except to place our order because there was no one servicing the tables.

Wines are ok
Not a fan of the cheeses they were serving
Service was non-existent and it wasn't that busy that night
It's also very loud - not a place to have an easy conversation

will not be returning
author: Lev E.

description:
Adorable, quaint and perfect second date spot. 
Get all that talkin' outta the way on date 1, it can be a little noisy hard to hear, and awwwwkward when the bartender isn't paying much attention. 

BUT the ambiance is well worth date #2. Cozy, dim, hidden in an alley.
author: Christina M.

description: I really like this place. It was small and cozy. The atmosphere is really lovely. There are a good amount of choice for wine to choose from. The bartender was super sweet and attentive. Perfect spot for a date or hanging out with friends
author: Zisele N.

description:
It's taken me way too long to review this place, mostly because who reviews their favorite neighborhood bar? Well, this girl feels it's worth a shout out. 

The ambience is cozy and unpretentious, the wine selections are unique and priced at an incredibly reasonable 30-50ish per bottle, and the helpings of meats and cheeses (and good god, crusty french bread) can only be described as AMPLE. The bartenders are down to lecture you about the wine and food (or about your love life) and equally down to leave you alone.

It's hands down my favorite low key place to meet a friend for drinks and (light) dinner in the area.

Please don't ever change, Biron. You are a welcome respite from a crazy world.
author: Stacy T.

description: This is my favorite bar in the city. I don't even want to write a review because I'm selfish and don't want the place crowded... Kidding. For us knowing little to nothing about wine, the bartender (Chad) is very gracious and we enjoyed his recommendations. The atmosphere of a cozy, not too trendy, not too upscale place is perfect. I'm making this my go to, end-of-weekend place. 5/5
author: Alyssa V.

description: I just moved back to SF after 10 years and I am so stoked that this place is still here and hasn't changed much at all.  Was and still is one of my favorite chilled out places to go for a good glass or bottle.  Great prices too! Some very yummy, affordable wines.  I usually go for the Malbec.
author: Adrian C.

description: If you want to meet really goal oriented, forward thinking, proactive people on the cutting edge of technology and innovation who have their finger on the pulse of the changing market and are the decision makers and leaders of today don't come here. Then I'll have to hear you talk about that shit and it will ruin an otherwise wonderful place.
author: Jon F.

description: Awesome little bar in a random spot in Hayes/upper market, a block from Zuni. Great spot for meeting a few friends or a date. Good selection of wine by the glass and beers
author: Aki N.

description: Loved the wine and the food! The bartender was not as great! Not attentive at all, no silverware - his friends were there so he ignored the customers and made us feel unwelcome so did his friends. Felt like we were a bother. Sucks because we are good customers! Would have give. 5 stars and a good tip! Work is work buddy!
author: Jessi K.

description: Hidden, wonderful, and lovely.
author: Mel G.

description:
One of my FAVORITE wining spots in San Francisco.  This place is truly unique and undisclosed from the rest of the outside world.  I imagine the streets of Paris lined with little hidden spots everywhere.  Well this ain't Paris honey but this inconspicuous diamond amongst the rough takes me back.

The entrance is barely lit, with a small "B" located above the doorway.  You would NEVER know anything was there unless, well... you knew.  The walls are exposed brick lined with artwork from emerging artists that change out frequently.  The wine is what we're all here for and it's good.  You can acquire a cheese and accoutrement plate while pairing your wines.  The dimly-lit space is filled with comfy couches and inviting tables for 2-4 people.  Make sure to find your spot and score it right away as this place can get full quickly and you wont want to leave once planted.
author: Kevin J.

description: Nice but a bit pretentious and overpriced. There are a few very similar bars in the city & this is problems isn't the best. Still, as I say, it's nice.
author: Fi M.

description:
This is one of my favorite bars in the City.  They have a great selection of beers and an even better offering of wine.  There's really good finger food as well for when the drink selections are doing their work.  

The best part though are the bartenders.  They're all really knowledgeable about all of their offerings, and have yet to make an unwelcome recommendation. 

All in all,  it's a great place for a quiet drink with friends.
author: Billy H.

description:
I liked Hotel Biron.  It was loud and crowded even at an early time, but it can be cozy and intimate (can be, but isn't necessarily, depending on where one sits).  I liked the bartender, who made some good suggestions about various types of wines I might like based on my preferences.  

Biron also has some limited food options -- mostly charcuterie and cheeses.  We tried a couple of cheeses and some olives.  That was nice.

Biron isn't what I'd call cheap.  A glass a wine, after tax and tip was $18.  For a date, a couple glasses of wine and a sampling of cheeses could easily run $100 or more for two for what would hardly be a substantial experience.  Hey, this is SF in 2014. What can you do?

I'd go back.  I'd probably prefer to visit when it's not as likely to be as crowded.  There is no table-side service, so if its packed, it could take a while to stand in queue to order at the bar.
author: SalsaBoy S.

description:
Great first date spot. It's cozy, hidden away, intimate, and yet it's also happening, bustling with a lot of energy, and has a pulse!! 

The best things about Hotel Biron are: The WINE SELECTION ummm and the free wine samples ;) ;) 

The awesome bartender poured my friend and I some very generous tastes of the Rhone and Pinot. It's as if he could read my mind as after describing what I preferred he found the perfect Sonoma coast wine for me (La Follette). 

The cheeses are inexpensive and lovely however the bread that accompanies them is very mediocre. I wish they had a better bread selection :)

NOT for dinner.. great for drinks for small groups. Parking is possible but will take you a good 20 mins to find. Wine by the glass averages $13. 

I wish they had chocolate :(
author: Kathy S.

description:
Went on a tuesday around 8pm. I would like this place better if I didn't like food. The only food on its menu was a cheese plate.  Cheese is awesome but optionality would have been better. 

Very small, cozy, ideal for a date...especially if you and your date are both on a diet!
author: Alice Z.

description: Cozy wine bar tucked away in a somewhat sketchy alley in a very sketchy part of town, but once you make it inside Hotel Biron is great! We tried a few wines at the bar that were recommended before settling on a couple of bottles to split between the girls and both selections were delicious!  I loved being able to taste a number of wines before having to choose and the intimate setting.  Great place for a date or to catch up with friends and the cheese plate was fabulous!
author: Raina D.

description:
Torn between a 4 and a 5 star rating. 

More than a year later and Hotel Bîron is still my go-to quiet, intimate neighborhood bar.Bartenders are still as friendly and helpful as I first noted in 2013 and their taste in wine/beer is still spot on.  I've recently started trying things off their food/small bites menu and the rilletes from fatted calf are quite delicious.
author: Jessie K.

description:
Once upon a time I walked into a bar in New York that was in an underground basement. It was small, dark and chill. I felt like the coolest person in the world!!! I was dressed up and the people were dressed up and everyone was way super important! Or at least pretended to be. I had no idea what a martini or pinot was though...so, perhaps I was not as cool as I thought. Er...probably wasn't cool at all actually. 

10 years later.....Hotel Biron

Exposed brick! Small cave-like area. It is dark and chill. I was in jeans and other people were in jeans! Hey..its SF, we really do not care what we look like. Not only did I feel cool but dammit I was cool!! I know what tannins are! Regional grapes are my jam! (ha!...pun alert) Charcuterie??? Uh....yes please! I even know that is French term for prepared meats! 

Who's the coolest? Uh...ME in Hotel Biron. Recognize.
author: Jay H.

description: Honestly, I wasn't impressed. It's a nice place, but just felt very stuffy (the air, not the people; the people seemed cool). Wine selection was alright, but probably could have been a buck or two cheaper.
author: John H.

description:
Hôtel Biron reminds me of a cozy European wine bar in the countryside that you stumble upon on a rainy bike ride. Subterranean and cozy, it's surprising how quick the place filled up over the course of a weeknight. 

There are bar stools, small tables and two large broken-in couches crammed into the space. If possible, the best place to drink would be the 4 seats by the bar. The bartenders know their stuff, and can recommend any wine based on your mood. Not surprisingly, on the night we visited, 2 of the 4 spots were occupied by a wine sales person with a cooler of opened wine -- every wine lover's eye-popping experience. 

One caveat is that all orders have to be made at the bar. Ordering becomes quite cumbersome as the place fills up and one has to navigate bodies to get to your next order. 

That being said, the cheese plate! What a cheese plate! The wine list is definitely well-researched, as it's the first wine bar in North America I've found to carry a sparking Gruener Veltliner.
author: Sharon F.

description: The space is a bit cramped, but the ambiance is quite nice for a date. The recommendations for wine are good and the selection as well. Have been over 4 times with a date and all have been good. If you're lucky, there's a love seat in the back with a table that's just about perfect. They have candles at the tables so if you have a tipsy date beware that her hair catch on fire (yes, that happened).
author: Pablo K.

description: One of the best places to take someone on a date. Its a literal hole in the wall behind a Brazilian restaurant that I would have never noticed without a friend pointing it out to me. Once inside I was really impressed by how intimate and relaxed it was. Great wine selection and a very good price spread. They also have beers and cheese that you can order. I would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for a good date spot or just a relaxing evening out on the town, great spot!
author: Josue V.

description:
(See pics)

You know those warm nights when you met friends whom you have not seen for a long time and just wanted a place to chill, a place to have great import and local wines, to have a small gathering place, to be on a quiet street, to be cozy and intimate without pretension? Hôtel Biron is it.

After Yelp Elite event a few of us came down to continue the evening. The wine bar has a great and varied list of wines, from the reliable French, Italian and Spanish, to Greek, German/Austrian and Portuguese, to Argentina/Chile, and a good section of Californian ones.

I opted for Albariño which was excellent for a warm night. They also have a wide selection of cheese, pate, salami and?. We had an order of Buffalo cheese and pate and they were very very generous portions with a big loaf of thinly soft sliced baguette.

This is an excellent hide away spot. The bar owner was super friendly and nice. We even bumped into another elite here.

And remember to look up to the ceiling while you're ordering wines and food, it's a cute ceiling of corks! Take a look at the picture.

And take a trip to the dark bathroom and look up to the ceiling which has a neat glass boat, kind of a gesture of the Atlantis!

Ooo how I love my Yelper friends! And how I enjoyed this little hidden gem that is tucked away with only a B sign.
author: T L.

description: The drinks and food are very good.  My only complaint is that the place is pretty small and crowded, so you have to get there right at 5:00 when they open.
author: Sara B.

description:
I was standing in front of this little wine bar and didn't realize it was there until I heard the sound of a friend's voice from inside. Stashed away in the alleyway behind Zuni, it's a cozy little brick-walled place to lounge about. We split a bottle o' cabarnet sauvignon from Once.

People looked like they were enjoying massive cheese plates, with what looked like quince jelly. Mm.

Back room by the bathrooms has a squishy comfy couch.
author: Kevin L.

description: I love this place for its ambience, location (tucked away in an alley), and cozy chairs.  Very intimate, but can be crowded and loud.  Its downfall?  Service.  Not very attentive to customers and very pretentious behavior.  On the more expensive side -- and while the wines they have are good with larger pours, they do not have as wide of a variety as I would like for a wine bar.  Their cheese plates are nice, but also a little overly-priced.  Due to the negative bartenders, I don't plan to return again.  Three stars for its originality and style.
author: Madison G.

description: What a treat! A little pricey, but def well worth it. Delicious, high quality food and wine in an intimate setting. This place is truly a treasure, and I'm so glad to have found this little hole in the wall. Can't wait to go back!
author: Lo N.

description:
A friend suggested meeting here for a mellow weekday happy hour and I'll admit I was a bit weary of the location...it IS in an alley after all.

It ended up being a great cozy spot with a couple couches (the kind you sink right into) and some tasty snacks (we had some cheeses and pate). The wine can be a bit pricey, but that's expected...you're in it for the ambience, right?

I loved the Momo Sauvignon Blanc and will for sure be back next time I need a low key night out!
author: Karena Q.

description:
My last review of San Francisco :(  I think.  I can't really remember all the places we visited in this beautiful city.

Anyway, we found Hotel Biron because Frank M had seen it on TV somewhere or heard it on a podcast he listens to.  We make the trip here using the muni.  It's actually pretty easy to get to if you know where it is.  It was kind of last at night when we made our way over here.  And it seems like it's in a shady part of town.  (Although, it probably wasn't)  It's just that everything around it was closed.   And the name is kind of misleading I think.  We were looking for some big hotel.  But the entrance was actually at the back of a low traffic street.  I don't even think there were any signs for this place.

Anyway, we found it fine.  Inside of the bar was nice.  I think it was a bar.  There weren't too many people in here.  They told us to sit wherever we wanted so we chose the spot at the way back.  The couches there were the kind where you just sink into it and fall asleep.   Although... reading the reviews now from other yelpers, I'm thinking we shouldn't have sat there.  LOL.

This place is a nice little spot.  And, I'd probably go back here.
author: Emily S.

description:
What a hidden gem Hotel Biron is!

The wine selection is thought out and delicious.  The owner travels the world to find the best there is, and it shows!  Same goes for the cheese.  No plain old cheese you have had before, the cheese selection is seriously unique.

Great date spot in my opinion!
author: Laura P.

description: Thought this was supposed to be a nice, cozy date spot.  Instead, the service was super slow, the bartender got scolded by another patron for serving some expired wine, and there was a constant stream of people walking in and out of the place carrying cans of Tecate (maybe the bartender's friends?).  $16 after tax/tip for a glass of wine?  Me thinks not.
author: Toby C.

description:
One of my favorite neighborhood places to sneak away for an intimate moment over good wine and/or beer.

The ambience is GREAT.  Small clusters of cafe tables.  A sofa or two.  Decent artwork to keep you visually stimulated.  Soft lighting, but not too dark.  

Yes, I am a beer drinker first ... But wine is important.  And Biron's wine list has a little something for everyone.  The staff is NOT pretentious, so you can comfortably ask questions without getting a smarmy look or snarky answer.  The staff is also very unassuming ... I never feel pressured to drink more (or less) than I want.
author: Joe W.

description:
Went here on a Sunday night and it was amazing. Great atmosphere. Scored a couch near the bar and tucked away to the side...cool artwork, super cozy, romantic setting...very European.
Great spot to go for a date!!
author: Rachael H.

description: Cute demur location with a cozy interior. Love the art on the walls and there is a great wine selection. The cheese plates are very nice for the price and the options are great. Would love to visit again and see if there list rotates.
author: Zara S.

description:
I was at this bar Friday and was ok, the bartender was nice and the wine was amazing, prices still reasonable, just the place needs a little bit of attention with cleaning even when they serve amazing cheeses....there is some other smells around ( gross!)
Aside of the lill weird smells at times, this place is nice and mellow, I will be back for sure.
author: Betty A.

description:
My first time to Hotel Biron was about 6 years ago..on stormy night..
This place always remained romantic and mysterious for me. 

Been here a dozen times since..and other things that remained consistent---Friendly staff..and a adventurous wine list. 

It is just one of those no frills wine bars that will stay on the top of my list.
author: Mimi T.

description:
This is one of my favorite intimate wine bars in the city. It's kind of hard to find, in a small alley in Hayes Valley. It's a pretty small space, so I wouldn't take a group here. It's more of a date place.

I think the snacks (cheese, meats, and stuff) are quite good, but a bit pricey for what you get. Don't expect to go here and eat something substantial. 

Their wine selection is so good! I haven't tried anything I haven't liked. They have a really great beer selection too, though, honestly, if you're going to go here, it's really for the wine.
author: Anna H.

description:
This is by far my favorite wine bar in all of San Francisco. Tucked in behind Zuni Cafe in Hayes Valley, Hotel Biron is a great place to share a bottle of wine or some craft beers with friends.

Hotel Biron has a particularly knowledgeable and helpful staff that can lead you in the direction for any type of wine or beer you are looking for.

The charcuterie and small plates are fantastic pairs to the wine and drink menu.

The wine menu is well versed and has some great bottles on it. We had the Failla Pinot and it was a great find. We finished off the evening with some Rasputin Stouts and couldn't have been happier.

I am going to be coming back a lot to Hotel Biron and using it as my own little neighborhood sweet spot for that special beverage.
author: Justin O.

description:
FIve stars for the quality, variety and value of the wine list and small plates.   Also for the friendly, knowledgeable service  (we got great wine advice & service from a great bartender who'd moved to SF from Astoria, NY).   And last but not least, for providing a classic late-night, escape experience to two wandering Manhattanites.  Where else could you go at 10:30PM on a Sunday night and pretend it was still Saturday?

Five stars for the relaxed atmosphere and decor with local artists displayed, but 1 star deducted for the inequitable seating amenities, which appear to reward one lucky couple at a time with long-term parking on one of 2 huge couches,  while the majority of patrons (many there on dates, too) are relegated to far less comfortable options.   Humble recommendation:  slim-line banquettes or movable ottomans might work better in this narrow space and offer more romantic situations around the room a chance to develop  ; ).
author: AM K.

description:
There is a certain point, around 300 reviews for a restaurant, that maybe you don't need any more reviews.  Where it simply doesn't matter because the people have spoken..... and they have an opinion, and they want you to know it.  In this case, something like 370 people want you to know it.  

It is a point where my review becomes a teardrop in a teeming river of thoughts, and experiences.  Tripadvisor didn't even have this listed, so at least I am relevant over there. =)

I loved this place.  The wine list wasn't that deep frankly, and I never figured out why.  I thought the apps were slightly overpriced.. *that is* - until the fruit and cheese platter came out... immaculate, geometric, adorned with wonderful nibbly bits.  It was a treat.  One of the more romantic spots and surprisingly pleasant experiences I have had in this city in a long time.

Great wines, very cool urbane scene reminiscent of Parisian "holes in the basement", and a dimly lit room with warm brick & interior design to gaze across the tiny table at your special lover. =)
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Dark alley and no sign.  Sweet!

This is the sort of place LA desperately needs.  Dim, exposed brick, great art, wine, diverse people and NO PLASMA TVs!   (when will you learn, LA?)  

Though the list was what it was, we had a killer time.  They have quite a few bottles on this list that are moderately priced.

I think we spent 3 hours here.  Great stuff.

Don't Half Step.  This place is best when we you go in smaller groups.
author: Brendon D.

description:
Not going to lie, a lot of times I'll enter a place and decide if it will or will not be a good date spot. This... is a good date spot. Intimate, appropriate lighting (trust me, the lighting will make you look good and 10lbs lighter), delicious wine, unobtrusive bartenders and comfortable seating. What's not to love?

I'm no wine connoisseur so it was refreshing to be able to go up to the bar and tell the bartender what I was looking for and then he let me try the various wines before I decided to buy a bottle.

It can get a little crowded and definitely a little warm because of that and no fans (plus, you know, drinking alcohol).
author: Amy L.

description: Small intimate wine bar located in a little alley. Glasses of wine start around $10. Super dim and good for romantic night out. Hard to find seating for large groups, unless, you are able to snatch up the back room.
author: Janice T.

description:
Top Secret! It's like you need a special handshake to get in here. Tucked away obscurely in a random alley in Hayes Valley, Hotel Biron is a welcome getaway. 

This spot is easy to overlook, the outside isn't very obvious to the world. Once you get inside, you are welcomed by an intimate setting. I will say, this place seems to get full fairly easily so you might need to be strategic about seating. 

Two thumbs up on the wine choices, my date knew I liked sweet wines, tried a few options and picked out a Riesling for me (one of the best I've ever had).
author: Rachel R.

description:
Hopf helle weisse, fresh figs,
wonderfully cozy little space.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
A lovely place to spend a chilly afternoon...we selected Hotel Biron not wanting to deal with a whole scene for a happy hour one Friday afternoon. We scored a cozy couch and a bottle of Vino Verde and the four of us settled into what we thought was a relaxed intimate evening....

Fast forward to more friendly service and suggestions (read: tastes) a cheese plate with some amazing olives, quince paste, and choose-your-own cheeses, and several bottles of wine and I THINK we had dinner at Paul K, nearby but I can't be sure...

You want good times, you want hotel biron.
author: Nikki M.

description:
M and I have a great friendship.  

It especially shines when we grab drinks.  He usually provides the metrosexual (but straight) eye candy for the gay bartenders who give us fantastic service.  I usually provide the location of a new potential date spot for M to scope out.  WIN-WIN.

So we hit up Hotel Biron.

It's the perfect date spot!  

Tucked away in an alley.  Cushy couches.  Dim, sexy lighting.  Cool art on the walls.  Mellow vibe.  Friendly, knowledgeable staff who ask:  Red?  White?  Sweet?  Dry?  Oaky?  Then pick the perfect wine for you.  A nice assortment of cheeses and other snacks to accompany your free flowing wine and conversation.

But for us, it was the perfect trade-your-dating-stories spot!

("He dragged me to the suburbs!"  "She dragged me to a chode bar and bought me Jager shots!"  "He said he 'loved Japanese food' and suggested Benihana's!"  "She was a crazy stripper!"  "He was married!"  "I got rejected from eHarmony!") 

GOOD TIMES.

p.s.  This review is dedicated to M.  May you find what you're looking for.  

p.p.s.  Hey single ladies - I know a great guy you should meet!  ;)
author: Amy C.

description:
Drinkin' on vaca--1-10-13
I am deducting one star because I didn't eat anything here and so I can't really wholesale endorse it.  I would probably come here a lot if I still lived in SF.  Sadly I don't.  That being said--great atmosphere, solid wine selection and friendly staff.  Probably a good date spot--wouldn't take a group larger than 4 here.  Its basically a niche place--but for what it aims to do, I am a big fan.  I will be back when I return to the bay as I do every so often.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
- Has wine for most budgets and tastes.  And beer for the rest.
- Right next to Zuni cafe, so as you wait for your table, you can nip in for a quick sip.
- Selection of meats and cheeses is great.

...what's not to love?

- The giant dumpster usually situated right next to where you enter :-) 
- Mildly uncomfortable chairs if you don't snag one of the couches.
author: Vandana N.

description: I adore this tiny charming hole in the wall.  People watching here is amazeballs.  It should be called "Internet first date wine bar".  We saw six couples meet up in the span of an hour and a half. Its like watching a live version  of "blind date".  My favorite couple was the cute asian girl that curled her hair and wore flats bc her date was short.  She wasnt into him, an obvious sign when she refused a second drink, sat so far back in her chair I got worried it would tip over, threw her hair up in a bun and zipped her jacket straight up to her chin.  Also they have weird obscure sour Belgian beers.
author: Poppy C.

description: This bartender is pretty f-in rude. He didn't want to accept my friends AZ ID cause it wasn't gonna expire until 2054 but Arizona ids don't expire for a long time and even when we tried to explain and Google it for him he didn't want to listen nor did he want to check my ID NOT PROFESSIONAL
author: Chelsea P.

description: Great wine list - really liked their sparking gruner veitliner. More of a place post sundown since the place is a bit on the darker side.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Super fun place to hang out for HH. I had a bad experience recently. The first glass of wine I got tasted strange, old or something, maybe corked. The second glass I got was red instead of white and had the same weird astringent taste. Perhaps it was an off day. Nonetheless, I'll be back. Love the location, decor, local art and usually the wine.
author: Kelly C.

description: My chard from Mendoza Argentina was fine but I really did not appreciate the stubby sommelier who smugly told my friend they did not have his preferred red available. Instead of immediately recommending something he just stood there and stared at a wall. I will give them an extra star for the dark lighting and various sofas and table seating. It was most def mehhhhhhhhhhhhhh.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Can't say enough good THINGS, this place is off the chain AMAZING!!!
Reminded me of the Marais in Paris.  
Try the Petite Brin!!! Off the chain!

The alley smells, look past that and just enjoy the atmosphere, it is worth the it.
author: Troy C.

description: My friends and I wanted to chill somewhere so we ended up here at this wine bar. Great pick. It was nice and cozy inside with couches in the front and in the back. The service was excellent and their wine selection was extensive. I found it to be on the pricey side but I guess thats how it goes when you go to a wine bar anyways. Great place chill with friends.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Cute little place for a wine bar.  There is NO way we would have found this spot without the Bloomspot deal of $25 for $50.

We came here on Sunday at 5pm, right when it opened.  You get a menu, find a seat, and go back to the menu to order.  

We selected 3 cheeses and 2 meats.  Hubby got a beer and I asked the owner if he could help me pair a wine to the meats and cheese I had selected.  He asked if I wanted red or white.  I said red.  He let me taste one and asked what I thought.  I thought the wine had too strong of an aftertaste, and asked him to suggest another.  He said all reds will have that aftertaste.  Umm...we just came back from a wine tasting event..I'm sure not all reds tasted like that.  So he goes to pour me that wine instead of offering a tasting of anything else.  - 1 star for that.

The 2nd big star minus is the music.  It would go from undergroud rap to some kind of screaming death electro metal or something.  I generally like to relax and enjoy my glass of wine. But here it felt like someone was clawing at the chalkboard.  I just couldn't get in the mood to relax.  

Some wine bars we've gone to have assorted board games or something, so you can play while enjoying your drink together, but this one had nothing, which just made the music all that worst.  

Pros is the very comfy couches.  Great for cuddling...so perfect for our 3 year anniversary weekend.  Too bad the service wasn't a bit better.  We probably won't be going back.
author: Vi Y.

description:
A vert special wine bar. The bottles are priced very reasonably, for sharing (according someone I chatted with that works there). Wine is meant for sharing, so I cannot agree more. 

Plus, the ambiance is intimate and divine!
author: Charlie C.

description: I love this place.  It's a little off the beaten path, but always manages to have a good crowd.  Nobody is too snobby or pretentious; everyone is there to just enjoy the good wine and company they are with.  Wines are tasty, unique, and affordable.  It's been around for a while, so you know it's more than just the latest trendy spot.
author: Marla L.

description:
This is not a hotel in a dimly lit back street--it's just a bar in a dimly lit back street. My friend dan h. said we were having drinks at Hotel Biron before dinner at Alexander's Steakhouse, and I was admittedly weirded out for two seconds before seeing it listed as "wine bar" on Yelp. Whew--I'm not one to go to a hotel after dinner, let alone before dinner. Haha.

I tried the 2006 Malbec from Argentina and 2009 Tempranillo from Spain, both of which were solid. The Malbec has converted me into a fan of Argentinian wine. I will be the first to confess I can't tell the difference between a $35 and a $135 bottle of wine, though.

Accompanying the wines were two sheep's milk cheese (my favorite!), Serra de Estrella and Ossua-Iraty. The first was from Portugal and soft; the second was from France and firm! Now I love soft sheep's milk, but I was so impressed with the sweet, buttery flavor of the firm cheese. If only I had fruit to cut the savory cheese, I'd be in heaven.

Great wine bar and walking distance from my hub. Why do all my friends just want to drink cocktails?
author: Liz T.

description:
I can't believe that I just found this place!  I'm a San Francisco native dammit!  Hotel Biron shoulda been included in the manual!

*Sigh*  Maybe, I don't know about this incredibly romantic spot because most of my San Francisco dating life was spent on boys who went Dutch on burritos in the friggin' Mission.

This is a great spot if you want an intimate, romantic, and/or just plain grown-up wine bar.

And it's open late...
author: R M.

description:
Warning, this place doesn't have real food, so if you're hungry, get dinner first!

This is an amazingly amazing wine bar.  I've traveled and done wine tours around the world from Italy to Australia and I'm very big on wines.  They have an intensely awesome selection that was clearly put together by a refined palate.  However, I do have to say that the bartender was not very nice.  He seemed annoyed when I asked him for a wine suggestion, any wine, any color.  I've worked in fine dining before and when someone asks me for a suggestion and can't decide between red/white/pink/sparkling, I suggest one of everything.  I don't get pissed off at them for being indecisive, especially if they can't pick because everything sounds so good!

There is no table service, so any time you need anything, you have to go up to the bar to get it.  There is one guy who runs the place, so service can be slow if you show up around 7-8 PM.  The food offerings are fairly good, but I wasn't impressed by the cost to quality ratio of it all (we got cheese, baguette, dates, almonds, olives, etc. - basically, the works).

It is an amazing space with sprawled, varied seating and couches.  And apparently they often have live music coming from the back room.  Really great, intimate space, but get there early so you have somewhere to sit.  If you're looking to impress a foodie wine girl you're taking out, this is the spot.

NOTE: People refer to this place as just "B" or "B Wine Bar" for the notorious bright yellow B sign on the outside.  However, if you need to Google map it, it is called Hotel Biron.
author: B L.

description: Such a cute little place tucked quietly on Rose St. You walk in off the gritty street and enter a very warm space - dim lighting, exposed brick, dark wood tables. I may have caught it on a good night but the place was comfortably occupied. We were one of a few parties and had our choice of the surprising quantity of seating options for what is a small place. I won't try to critique the wine selection, as I'm not a big wine drinker, but I can tell you that there is a lot to choose from and the few that we tried were delicious. The bartender was helpful, too. I think that she may have been drinking some of the wine as well. She seemed extra fun.
author: Brett B.

description:
This wine bar is a nice little hideaway tucked into the alley right by Zuni Cafe.  How did I miss this place all these years?!

It's actually unmarked, so you'd have to be looking for it.  When you step inside you feel like you're in a wine bar in another city like Paris or something.  It's cozy and intimate with brick walls and a few sofas interspersed with tables.  

The wine list is extensive and the staff can help you with suggestions.  The prices are on par with most of the other wine bars I've visited in SF.  I went with two other friends and we each had a glass of wine and then we shared a plate of cheese and pate served with a baguette.  Even with a 20% tip, the total only came to $18/person and the cheese/pate serving was a large portion.

It's not a large place and it was busy when we got there around 9PM on a Thursday, but the three of us were able to snag a table in the very back and there were a few scattered tables for two available.

I'm so glad I discovered this little gem of a place and am already planning another trip!
author: Kimberly B.

description: It was OK,  took a date there and she really liked the place.  Women love wine bars?  More of a Vodka guy myself.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description:
Had a "Girl's Night Out" with some girls from work and we had a great time at this super comfy and super cool little wine bar.  It also happens to be a block from our salon so...bonus!  The service was very friendly with just the right amount of  help choosing our wine, cheese plate cheeses etc.  We loved the wine we chose and the cheese plate was lovely!  We got here about 6:40 on a Friday night and we were able to get a table for 4...I think we had great timing- it got really busy right after we arrived.
All in all, a neighborhood gem that we plan on frequenting.
author: Shannon J.

description:
yes, it's a hotel and they have bed bugs.

tourists and bridge and tunnel folks should not even consider coming here. thank you.
author: Rob D.

description:
Still gorgeous, and still a great wine bar.

The California wines are a fairly poor selection-- overpriced, overheated, and underwhelming. There's so much to choose from and there's so little time. 

A Cabernet could have really used decanting, but we got nothing.

Seems like their popularity has detracted from their service-- which is a bit sad.

Nothing wrong with it, but there's so much more that could be right.
author: Glen M.

description:
I haven't written a review for almost a year, but this place brought me out of semi-retirement. It is a hidden gem...as many have already mentioned. Blink and you'll completely miss it, but when you've found it, it will be on your radar forever and you'll want it to be your new home away from home!

The selection of wines is extensive, the service is at the bar is attentive, the cheese and charcuterie plates are outstanding (the French triple cream is insanely delicious...we ordered it twice!)

The ambiance is nice and inviting. I wanted to buy all the art off their walls. Plus, they're open until 2 am everyday, if I'm not mistaken.  Bravo!
author: Evelyn K.

description: Ok, so I've been here a total of 3 times. The first time was about a year and a half ago and it was fine. Then, about six months ago, I went here with friends and we walked in and walked right out. Last night, I went in and walked right out. Why? Because it smells like stinky, sweaty gym shoes. It's gross. The fact that it has reeked on two totally different nights several months apart., I deemed that enough information to write a review.
author: Chloe M.

description: Wine bar--hidden little spot behind Zuni.  A friend brought me here and I will love her forever for it.  Full of life, lots of space to lounge, excellent wine selection (and not too expensive).
author: Patrick S.

description:
The best part about this bar is how difficult it is to find.  Now if only I could keep this little gem to myself...wait, why am I reviewing this?  

Seriously though, walking into this bar makes me feel like I'm being transported to Europe.  The dimly lit bar, the exposed wood flooring, the wobbly tables surrounding the bar...and all of this is only the beginning!  Keep walking toward the back and you'll find a charming semi-private sitting area waiting for your group to occupy!  My only advice is to arrive early with your group as this space tends to fill up fast.  

The wine list is substantial and can be daunting to say the least.  ASK FOR HELP!  Unless you're a European wine expert who hates to actively engage others, ask for a suggestion based upon your preferences and palate.  To this date, I have never been steered wrong.

Finally, the tasting plates are good for light tapas but don't go here thinking you've arrived at foodie Nirvana; there is Zuni around the corner for that.
author: Sean H.

description:
I am not makeup dependent.  Sometimes I girly myself up; sometimes I just dress the part and skip the makeup.

No one needs makeup at Hotel Biron.  The lighting is just so right.  

Having wine is so much better without worrying if your date can see that blemish that just materialized on your left cheek.

Just cozy up, nibble the figs and cheese, tell some jokes, and drink some carefully chosen wines.

Au natural.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Seriously...so narrow you can almost stretch out both arms and touch each side...hard to find...a nondescript entrance on a dark street...but worth hunting for!! Far enough off the beaten path that it isnt crammed with out-of-towners (except for me!).  

Excellent wine selection and helpful staff. Prices about average...but generous pours. The cheese plates are about triple the size of any I have gotten in any other wine-cheese haunt...a very pleasant surprise! We got two cheeses (both amazing), quince paste, almonds, and honey. Got a very generous portion of both cheeses, about a cup of almonds, huge portion of the quince paste, and a little bowl of honey. The biggest, and best, surprise was that you got what looked like an entire sliced baguette! You actually had enough bread to eat all the cheese...a big improvement over my hummus debacle yesterday where I got two slivers of pita to eat an entire bowl of hummus!! Only downside was that the red, although good, was served a little warmer than it should have been...but our white was crisp, cold, and perfect!
author: Tricia B.

description:
Really chill place to escape on a hot summer day, with dimmed lighting and plenty of seating....and lots of wine...you can't complain. Stopped here briefly with my brother before heading off to dinner to share a bottle of wine. Plenty of fabulous foreign wines to choose from and a no fuss staff that is able to handle managing the place with only two on shift at a time. 

Let's just say I'm lucky to have gotten out of there so cheap (thanks bro!) and as sober as I did. I can see this place doing severe damage in the future.
author: Alita M.

description:
After Harry Potter retires from saving the world from [He who has no name], this is the type of place I imagine our young adult wizard and Hermione would grab a drink. 

Located on Rose St, a small alley behind Zuni and sandwiched between Market, Gough and Page, this wine bar is nondescript and cleverly hidden. But if you take a few steps past Platform 9 3/4, the sign magically appears and you are whisked into a long and narrow bar full of exposed brick, 2 seaters, candles, and retired warlocks.

The bar itself is really small and only has 3 stools in front of it. But wedge your way in and order your drink of choice. As an avid dry white winer drinker, I made myself order a red wine. I had my friend pick a "gateway red" out for me. I settled on an Argentine Pinot Noir and really liked it. Still not my go-to, I feel a little better about the Red Community. 

They have a few larger tables, but they were all taken by the time I got there so I called dibs on the couch in the back room. The only other thing back there is a small table and the 2 people sitting there were on a first date. I felt a little uncomfortable the first 20 minutes as I was waiting for my friends to arrive and listening to their answers about jobs and where they live, but it helped assert that first date awkward conversations seems to be universal. 

The next time you're here, keep a look out for the regulars. You might see Ron hiding his ginger hair under a Fedora hat while Snape sits alone, looking ambiguous and drinking a glass of blush. Is it red or is it white? Is he good or is he bad? I'll never know.
author: Jared S.

description:
Quite the opposite of the Hôtel Biron in Paris.  This literal hole in the wall along an alleyway behind Zuni Restaurant offers an experience not as grand as the original hôtel particulier, but charming nonetheless.  

A nondescript entrance leads you to a narrow, dark space lit low with brick walls and copper pilings.  Ordering is done soley at the bar.  Delicious Spanish and Italian vino offerings, however their cheese platings impress and certaintly delight:

Old Quebec - Canadian 3yr aged raw cow's milk cheddar 
Grevenbroeker - Belgian raw cow's milk blue cheese
Serra de Estrella - Portugese washed rind sheep's milk cheese 
Mahón-Menorca - Spanish firm washed rind raw cow's milk cheese
Capricious - Californian hard aged goat's milk cheese
Petit Agour - French hard sheep's milk cheese 
Rocchetta - Italian semi-soft goat, sheep, & cow's milk cheese 
Vignelait - French triple cream cow's milk cheese

Cheese selections are $6/each and accompaniments such as dried fruit, preserves and nuts are $3/each.

Service is simple and unnoticeable while the ambiance is cozy, intriguing and almost sinister.  A place perhaps Rodin would frequent to discuss why the Paris Salon rejected his masterpiece L'Age d'Airin in 1877.  Or perhaps Rodin would visit here to ponder the nuances of the wines and essence of the artisinal cheeses.

"What makes my Thinker think is that he thinks not only with his brain, with his knitted brow, his distended nostrils and compressed lips, but with every muscle of his arms, back, and legs, with his clenched fist and gripping toes."-Auguste Rodin
author: Kalani C.

description:
Definitely a fan.  Its solid and I enjoy going with friends.  It can get a bit crowded and the patrons can be a little, well, uppity on some nights but the staff is always cool!

The wine list is solid... sometimes a bit pricey.  Staff is very knowledgable and always helpful.

Check out the bathroom -- awesome chandelier. ;)
author: Jake W.

description:
Good wine, cozy and dim ambiance, quiet enough to hold a conversation, and unassuming yet intimate enough for a date.

I'm admittedly biased because my first date with my current boyfriend was here and imo he couldn't have chosen anywhere better.  If you can't impress your date here, then something's wrong with one of you.
author: S L.

description: To be clear, this is for the bar. Another great Hayes Valley spot. Cozy and intimate atmosphere. Feels exclusive because of its off the radar location. Cool art on the walls, dark lighting. Good spot to actually talk with someone or for a date. It's small though so that you may have to wait to get a seat (never happened to me, but just warning) and sometimes it's randomly closed for private parties.
author: Ramon S.

description:
Went here before dinner at Zuni Cafe --  it's in the same alley! This is a great little wine bar, however, it gets SUPER crowded. There isn't that much seating and there's really no room to stand. I was tempted to take my fancy bottle of wine and drink it outside in the alley (but that wouldn't have been very classy). 

Get here early to get a spot to sit down!
author: Lauren F.

description: Absolutely love this place. Great location, secluded. You can't tell what's there unless you walk right by it. Dim lighting and great music and wine menu. All I can say is, this is the absolute perfect place for a date!!! ;)
author: Soseh Z.

description:
This place is tiny and can fill up quickly, so I do not recommend it for large groups.

It is a cozy, candlelit wine bar tucked away in an alley, so it's nearly impossible to find. The wine list in really inspired and really reasonably priced! They explore regions and varietals the average wine drinker might not be familiar with in addition to some more approachable ones.

If you are feeling adventurous-- talk to the bar tenders and they can steer you towards something you haven't had before, but may love! They are always really kind and helpful.

The cheese selections are equally as inspired as well! Do not come here starving because they only offer small bites.

Check out the ceiling by the bar! It's super cool.
author: KA K.

description:
Biron receives only superlatives from me. Tucked away in a hidden alley it's not a place to stumble upon but a treasured wine bar for those in the know. 

It's oozes an effortless sultry vibe and charm. If you're lucky enough to find a seat in the nest, it feels alveolate, like you're nestled in a sweet honeycomb brimming with ambrosial wine. The staff accommodates. Sink in, sip awhile.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
Awesome place for happy hour with friends, or even a work event.  There is a great selection of foreign wines, and I love how they let you taste a few if you're unsure which one to get.  The menu also offers a tasty selection of cheese and olives - yum!

The main minus is the stinky alley storefront?  It does add some mystery, and it does keep the place a nice little secret, but sometimes I don't really want to pass garbage cans on the way in?  I admit that I tend to not mind so much after a few drinks...
author: Fontane L.

description:
Would have never known about this place without yelp or Groupon! It's in this tiny alley and the front of the lounge is pretty narrow. I was a bit confused when I went in because there isn't anyone to great you. 

All the tables and seats were filled the night we went. The place is small but intimate. We had to awkwardly stand around by the "bar table" area until a table left. The guy behind the bar knew his wine's well and was able to predict what we would like, if not on the first try then the second. Me and my gfs' loved our wines and also ordered some finger food. We used our groupon ($15 for $30 worth of food) so it was worth it. After 3 glasses of wine and 2 appetizers along with the coupon, we spent about $13 each (4 people).
author: Karen C.

description:
Hmm, I feel confused about the Hotel Biron. 

Pros: 
Dimly lit in a good way 
Intimate unpretentious setting 
Good selection of wines, beer, cheese, and fruit 


Cons: 
Sketchy entrance in back alley 
Art is all above tables, so if you want to walk around and view the art, you seem like you are eavesdropping on whoever is sitting below the art. 
Wine prices start at 11 dollars/glass 
Chairs are very wobbly and feels like they will break at any minute 
Tables are very sticky...I don't want to know why! 
The back part by the bathroom is the only place that doesn't smell like feet! That is right, if you have ever taken gymnastics or been to a large gymnastics gym, it smells the same as Hotel Biron...like feet. 

So, I am very confused as to whether I like this place or not. I think it would be a good place to bring a date, but since it smells like feet, I would say to only bring a date if you can sit at the couch or table in the back by the bathrooms. Or, order stinky cheese so that the smell of that overpowers the smell of feet! I went with a friend to view the art and we ended up looking at the art in a book at our table instead of walking around because we didn't want to stand in front of each table and each couple at each table for 5 minutes while we talked over them about the art! It is a cute place and although their wine is overpriced, it is a very down to earth cozy place. I wouldn't say not to go, but it wouldn't be my first recommendation of place either.
author: M M.

description:
1 star because of the terrible experience with the woman behind the bar.  My friend ordered 2 glasses of barbera at $12 each.   I realise taste is a matter of taste... but the barbera had a taste of vinegar and a hint of mould.  The wine was bad full stop.

well the "friendly" woman (shoulder length dark hair) tells me, after I explain to her the wine does not taste ok, that i should have TRIED the wine before buying!!!  oh she also sniffed it in front of me. really!  This of course gets under my skin since there is a big difference between crappy tasting wine and something that has gone-off.   PLUS if you are going to over charge for wine at $12 to $16 each and are worry about profit then MAKE your bar staff insist on the GUEST tasting the wine first. OR maybe have the bar staff taste each bottle before serving it to make sure it's not corked, etc.  it is not rock science.   The service was just ridiculous.

minus the unacceptable service the place is nice.  Maybe a bit on the warm side if you are in the back area.
author: Aus B.

description: Went to Hotel Biron for a date recently and thought it was okay. The location is not exactly ideal for a first date... the area felt a little seedy to be walking around by myself in the dark (it's hard to miss and down an ally). The space itself is pretty cool with interesting art. Service was really really slow which is the main reason why I don't think I'd come back.
author: Gina C.

description:
Hotel Biron is not a hotel, but an intimate and romantic wine bar.  Entering feels like you're walking into a dark, candle-lit European hole-in-the-wall.  We had the cheese plate and shared a nice bottle of syrah from Russian River.  I SO appreciate when SF wine bars serve locally produced wines, as I've recently observed a few enterprises that serve predominantly European wines.  We are blessed with living in a region that has fantastic local wine -- why import and augment our carbon footprint?  

The space is not huge so it's not recommended if you have a big group.  Hotel B is, however, perfect for a nightcap with your date or one or two friends...
author: Sid D.

description: Great  bar with cozy couches, best place if you're in the mood for something chill.
author: Monica R B.

description:
From the seemingly-secretive alley entrance of this wine bar, you immediately step into a world that can be both a wonderful evening of thoughtfully chosen wine and an intimate place to get to know the people in your party.

The knowledgable staff will happily help you choose from their selections, and even pair you with some fine cheeses if you wish.

Nicole G (hello, honey!) has it right about how cozy a couple can get there.  It's a great stopping place for a date!

If the evening happens to be a crowded one there, I would skip it and return for a better, more intimate experience.  The Hôtel Biron is yet another one of San Francisco gems.  I only wish that it had additional small spaces to keep it with the same feel on its popular nights as on its more secluded, romantic ones.
author: Tracy B.

description:
*unpretentious, relaxed, hip atmosphere (doesn't set off yuppie alarm which is always my fear with wine bars)

*amazing cheese & small plates selection

*staff approachable for tasty wine suggestions

Love this place!  I'd go back a million times.
author: Danielle R.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.
Really.
I mean I know, I know. I say I love "this" place all of the time.
But I mean it. I pinky swear. I heart this place.

I was taken here by my friend F who knew of my love affair with wines and introduced me to a fabulous wine list, super cute bartender, and an amazing cheese plate.
Yup...and all for a  ridiculously reasonable price.

It is dark, mysterious, brick, candles and hidden away enough to keep the riffraff (or the scene-y types) out.

It was romantic even, with some of the crazy art but still beautiful.

I highly recommend if you're looking for a mellow and upscale place for a casual or romantic glass of wine.
author: Kathy K.

description:
This small, quaint, place is quite deceptive. You would never think this little hole in the wall would carry such such a diverse selection of wine.

I was here two weeks in a row. Night one was quite fun. I discovered a liking for mixed wines particularly,  Malbecs from Argentina. Though, I thought the bartender from night two (long hair, spanish) was very knowledgeable and much friendlier than the bartender from night one. The snacks (cheese, dips, crackers, pates) are very affordable and paired well with most of our wines. 

A bit dark, eerie, I thought the place was romantic, but casual and the noise level was comfortable. The only downside is that seating can be very limited. Other than that, I have them written down as a place to come to for a glass of good wine even if I was in sweats.
author: Alesia T.

description:
It was wonderful to discover that my favorite secret weapon, romantic, eclectically cozy wine bar is just as effective as ever.  

Still tiny, still dark, still full of wonderful wine selections.  
Still crowded with couples holding hands over small rickety tables.
Still capable of offering a wine I didn't even know I wanted to try.
Still able to ramp up a date to that next level.

Yeah, I could be giddy from the company, but at least part of it was the location...
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Always a fan of places tucked away in alleys, hotel biron is super chill and has a great selection of wine and unique beers.  We had a great chocolate stout last week that was like drinking dessert.  It's also very easy to get a cab here late night since its close to some of the busiest streets in the city.

I always forget this awesome bar, need to put it on my favorites list.
author: jessica b.

description:
Update:  It most certainly does fill up later in the evening and especially on Friday's.
+++

My honey and I love the Hotel B.  It feels like our private, secret, afterwork, decompress-zone.  We go almost once a week.  We enjoy one or two glasses of delectable wine accompanied by just the right amount of cheese and baguette and a little apple or pear or olives and melt away or into each other.  We've always gone early in the evening and early in the week, so I imagine that it fills up and becomes much more lively later on...
author: Mac M.

description:
Hotel Biron is a great place for a glass of wine while you are waiting to eat at Zuni! 

I love hidden San Francisco and this place definitely qualifies.....Who would ever guess that such a cool place (with great exposed brick walls that I dig!)hidden in an alley right off Market? I dig the couches and the relaxed environment.  Place is just makes with a sign that says "b."

They only have wine/beer--no cocktails.  Just an FYI for people who are looking for other things to imbibe.
author: Katharine A.

description:
This cozy little place is serious about wine.  Hidden in the alley behind Zuni and marked by the B, it can be hard for those who rush through life at a fast pace.  For those of who like to take it easy and relax, it's hard to miss.

Great tasting wine too.  Your credit card may not know what hit it.
author: Jean K.

description:
Are you seeking a wine bar that's unpretentious, comfortable and hip?  You'll find it all here at the Hotel Biron!

The place is right off an alley and the space is great!  I've been here a few times and each time I leave wanting to bring more friends to experience the HB.  The selection of wine is not only affordable, but delicious.  Their choice in beers is also a winner, where there's something for everyone.  This is a fantastic place to meet friends before a show of after dinner.  It just oozes relaxation here!
author: Lisa R.

description:
I LOVE IT HERE!

Hidden away in the alley behind Espetus and Zuni, this is definitely a locals in-the-know type of spot. It's got an extensive wine list grouped by countries (US, France, Australia/New Zealand/South Africa, Portugal/Spain, Germany/Austria, Chile...) with a nice range in prices, depending on your reason for stopping in. Tonight I popped in for a casual night out with a couple of my best girlfriends and we shared a bottle of refreshing Fámega Vinho Verde. They also have some tasty cheese plates, a decent beer selection, and a few types of sake.  

The best part of all though is surely the ambiance. It's cozy, intimate and sexy with (good) rotating art on the walls - a killer date spot!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
This narrow alleyway wine bar is wedged between buzzy Zuni cafe on Market Street on one side, and ever-congested Gough Street on the other.  But once you find Hotel Biron in all its discreet glory, and step inside, you'll be amazed at how divine of an experience you can have.  

I recently came here on two separate occasions - once on a Friday night at around 9pm, and once on a Sunday night at around 8pm.  It seems that Friday nights are infinitely more popular (as is with any beverage or dining establishment) and it took me a while to warm up to the place.  I couldn't hear my bf talk, let alone myself, because the aluminum siding on one side of the room made everything echo in addition to amplifying the voices.  We had to stand for a while, too, because there was nary a spare seat to be found.  We got lucky and landed the comfy couch right next to the bar, and from there we were able to really enjoy the intimacy of the place.  I sampled a red from France and a Napa rosé and preferred the French more.  

Our Sunday night excursion was MUCH, MUCH more enjoyable.  We found a seat immediately and had a glass of the Dow's Port and a Murphy's Irish Stout.  The cheese selection here is fantastic.  I've had the Grevenbroeker (blue cow), the Capricious (hard goat), the Vignelait (creamy cow), the Robiola (soft and creamy) and the Rochetta (semi-soft blend of goat, cow, and sheep).  All are tasty, but I prefer the softer cheeses to the harder.  Goes great with the baguette they serve you, or you also have your choice of fruit.

I love how international the wine list is, and the art on the walls is fun to admire as you sip your worries away.
author: Kira K.

description:
The Good:
- Being here feels like you are in a secret club where only cool hip people hang out.
- You get to drink wine

The Bad:
- They don't care all that much about helping you with wine. 

Thats a bold claim. But if you look at the wine list...its pretty obvious. They don't have wine flights. They don't offer taste size or half glass portions.  They have a really high mark up on wines by the glass. That means, you don't know if you are going to like something...you just gotta buy a glass of it and pray. 

But for most people...who want to feel fancy because they are drinking wine in such a charming atmosphere, and don't care about the price as long as they get "big pours of something red" this will suit your needs nicely. The romance of the place really makes you want to not fight it and just drink...
author: Rondeep C.

description:
Found this place by searching yelp for a good date spot... and I was not lead astray.  Came here on a Wednesday night around 6:30 and it was perfectly crowded.  We weren't the only people in the place but had no problem finding a secluded little bench on which to enjoy our bottle.  The bartender was nice and helped us chose a wine.  The cheese was oooooo so yummy.  Will definitely go back.

thanks yelp!
author: Meagan C.

description:
Hidden gem of Hayes Valley.  It's a just a short walk from Zuni Cafe tucked away in the back alley. If it wasn't for the letter "B" outside it's door, one can easily miss it. 
I've been wanting to check this wine bar out for months, but just never had the chance to until last night. 
Dimly lit candles throughout, cozy couches  and intimate tables makes it a perfect date place. The French / jazzy music playing in the background stimulated my senses... yearning to be back in Europe.
