My date ordered an Italian red wine... I can't remember which grape or winery, but his tasted spicy, which I didn't care for. I had a red Zinfandel from Napa... I'm blanking out on the name of the winery, but it was exactly what I wanted... fuller body & fruit forward.  I like that their wine list is categorized by countries or regions: Italian, French, Spanish /Chilean, California... I wanted to do something relaxing & mellow and that's exactly what we did.
author: Myra M.

description:
Charming place for a drink. Quaint, busy (but not crowded) and not stuffy or pretentious.  Not your after work happy hour bar; the small tables are not good for groups. 

Hotel B is tucked away in an alley off of Gough. It's like a little cozy secret. Great date place. :) 

Parking can be a little challenging in the area.
author: Cindy Y.

description:
I should first confess that I'm not a wine connoisseur.

That being said, I love this place.  Located in a tiny alley with discrete signage, it has a very cozy interior with walls bearing interesting art.  Both of my visits here have felt really special and intimate -  and reminded me of my time in Paris.  It was not at all crowded either time, and to my untrained palate, the wine was great.  It's a bit pricey, but well worth it.

Little details - I also appreciated the nice stemware and accommodating servers.

I want to go back tonight. :)
author: Grasshopper R.

description:
My friend took me here last week, and I loved it! A little hidden place with a great selection of wine. Relaxed and intimate atmosphere. Highly recommend their cheese plates.

Great date spot!
author: crystal e.

description:
Groupon.com deal of the day: $30 gift certificate to Hotel Biron for $15?!? Don't mind if I do!!

Tucked away in a small alley in Hayes Valley this place is a wonderful find! Identified only by the circular red "B" sign fixated above the door, this place is easy to miss. It's a small and narrow establishment with lots of round tables all around the room and a couch in the back. Pictures of naked women grace the walls. The dim lighting and soft flicker of candles makes this a great date spot. 

Great wine selection. Cheese, salami, fruit, nuts and olives are also available to nibble on. 

I would have given this place 5 stars had it not been for the bartender. He was a bit snippy with me but I'm just going to assume you were having a bad day. Grab a glass of wine and chill, dude.
author: Tina Y.

description:
A little pre-dinner buzz.  After a long day at work, its refreshing to sit back and relax with a couple glasses of wine over good conversation.  Actually, make that interesting conversation.  Did you know that animals believe in monogamy?  And that male animals have the right to an EPC (extra pair copulations) but if the female were to do the same thing, she would be shunned?  Yeah i didnt either.  Just goes to show that double-standards not only exist amongst humans, but the animal kingdom as well.  Males....cant live with em, cant live without em.  

The white wine i had was fantastic and im kicking myself for not remembering the name, but it paired well with the cheese, Vignelait, a triple cream cow's milk.  So soft and so creamy, i would have eaten more had dinner time not been slowly approaching.

I like the secret location of Hotel Biron.  Its tucked away in a side alley you would never know it was there.  Very cozy and quaint wine bar, almost hallway-like with a few tables lining the entrance and a backroom with two couches.  And its extremely dim in here with candles illuminating each table.

This cute little hide-a-way wine bar is the kind of place i can enjoy multiple delicious bottles of wine with someone, and then ditch their body in the alley when im done if i decide their company is no longer needed.  4 stars!
author: Juv C.

description:
Any place that has a crystal pirate ship chandelier in their restroom automatically gets 5 stars from me. 

I mean, it screams class without being pretentious. Right? Okay, maybe it actually screams "You wish you could have something so fucking tacky in your place and still come off being chic and cool", but whatever.

Cool and chic, yet unpretentious, is exactly what makes Hotel Biron so great. From their great wine and cheese selections to the semi hidden location to the dim lighting and exposed brick and edgy artwork, this place draws you in and makes you think "Hell yeah, I am getting me one of those chandeliers because I am classy shit!!"
author: Drue C.

description: This place is teeny tiny and seems to be on some sort "best places to take a date" list.  I love the casual appeal, dim lighting & varied wine selection.  It can get super hot in so dress in layers.
author: Helen F.

description:
Cozy, intimate, dark, romantic...perfect date spot. Split a bottle of wine or sample a few delicious wines. The brick wall and candles create a fantastic ambiance. It is a low key crowd, usually just the right number of people in the bar. 

Loved it! Will definitely go back
author: Jennifer W.

description: I dig this place, they have a good selection of wine. It's also kind of dark inside which works for it. It's urban but not pretentious, like it could be in the Haight or Mission - on a week night I should add.
author: Chris M.

description:
I had absolutely no idea this tiny, dimly lit, gem of a place existed. 

My friend and I perused the very impressive wine list and thoroughly enjoyed our glasses. 

I absolutely love discovering new, cozy places like Hotel Biron in San Francisco.... It's the perfect place to visit for a very relaxing glass of wine and delicious cheese plate- especially on a gloomy and cold night. It would also be a very hott and sexy date location. Just saying.
author: Laura D.

description:
Strangely comfortable, this sliver of a space comes in through the ironic door and somehow out the other side based on merit.

With a spare smattering of chairs and couches atop a patchwork hardwood floor, the first thought is "you're velvet-roping me, yes?" But the overall feeling in this thin space was not-so-much velvet-roping -- overcoming their difficult location and off-kilter flooring, Hotel Biron was simply charming.

The red t-shirt-wearing guy behind the bar was kind and adaptive when I asked him what his sweetest Reisling was, and what cheese would go with it. He hung with it, and got us the finest items to fit the bill. He didn't need to, but he did.

Romantic? Yes. Hotel Biron is full of nooks and crannies in which to get your romantic on, whatever your situation. Grab a candle and some wine, and see if you can get your date to laugh.

This is an odd (in a good way) space in SF, and you can have a good conversation here. It's better than it should be and I appreciated that.

Recommended? = Sure.
author: Chris R.

description:
If you are looking to be pampered by cajoling staff who think you are the reason the sun rises, then take your $@$#~!@# American over entitled attitude, shove it up your #@$#^%@ arse and go somewhere else.

However, if you want a place that's full of energy and atmosphere, requires you to be a bit assertive to get your way AND has a great selection of wine and cheese/charcuterie (with a knowlegable, albeit overworked staff) then look no further.

This place is more like the best of Europe than any other place I've been to in the city.  It's small, tucked away location makes you feel like you've found some hidden treasure the Wharf-visiting-wrong-clothes-in-summer tourists will never know about.

Can it get crowded? Yes. Lose the personal bubble.
Will you have to wait a bit? Sometimes, Yes. 
Will you get 4 star service? No. This isn't French Laundry.  
Will you have great wine?  Yes.  And they pour well!
Can you get good charcuterie/cheese?  Oh yes.  "Barnyardy, not putrid"
author: Michael S.

description: Went there with a friend on a Saturday night - full but not crowded - had a table the entire time. A pit pricey but the wine is really nice and you just can't beat the unique somewhat exclusive atmosphere.  Its sort of like stumbling on a well-kept secret.
author: Keith C.

description:
If someone didn't open the door for me, I probably would've walked by this place about 10 times looking for the entrance. Situated on a charming little alley, and by charming I mean dirty, this is the kind of place that if you are not purposefully going there, you will walk right past it. But, maybe that's a good thing because it's so small that if more people frequented this place it would be less of a wine bar and more of a cattle pen. 

I'm not a wino, so I don't often think highly of wine bars. But, the perfectly dimmed lighting, the different styles of seating (i.e. I can sit on a couch OR a garden chair, oh boy!), the intimate feel (not stuffy and silent), and the friendly service make this quite a fine establishment indeed. It's small enough, and has enough little nooks, that you can have a close conversation if you'd like, or you can pretend to be listening to someone while you're actually listening to the highly inappropriate loud chick at the next table. And, if you order cheese (which you should), they give you far more than you could possibly ever need or want. Certainly enough to last you through the night, or bottle. 

I can't say I've been won over by the wine bar lifestyle, but Hotel Biron put out one hell of an effort to convert me.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Cozy small space- great wine, excellent service. Perfect for a date, friend catch up, anytime you want to actually have a conversation.
author: Nors P.

description: Hotel Biron for a first date?  A hotel! That is a little presumptuous.  Who have you been talking to?  Oh, it's a darling little wine bar next to Zuni Cafe.  Oh yes, that sounds lovely.  They have cheese?  Even better.  With fresh baguette.  What time is check out?
author: Monica L.

description:
This place has great foreign wine selection, and the cheese platter enhances the experience.  I especially like the spanish and the italian wines.

The decor is small and cozy, slightly on the dark side, which gives off a pretty intimate setting.  I used to come here with a friend at around 10ish and just chit-chat till closing time, polishing off a bottle of wine between us.  The place gave off an relaxing mood, and its relatively busy even on weekdays.  Try to take the sofa seats, its more comfortable and easier to maintain conversation.  Good place to bring your date to after dinner.
author: Jim H.

description: It was a random Wednesday night and my BFF and I decided to have a girls night.  Starting point, Hotel Biron.  The bartender was very knowledgeable and even made some great decisions for us in terms of wine selections and cheeses.  Can I just say YUM!  We had a blue cheese sprinkled with honey, a hard one, and a soft cows milk cheese, all really good.  Point for the bartender for making a decision for us and totally getting it right.  This is a great place to meet with friends, but a big group would be hard to seat or to take a date.  It definitely has that European feel and hidden gem atmosphere.  The wines are great, although a bit pricey.  It''s also a great location with Cav and Cafe Zuni around the corner for food.
author: Inga W.

description:
I can't believe I have never reviewed this place. I spend a lot of time here drinking wine and eating cheese with friends and cute boys. 

The service is superb - the ambiance is sultry and rustic and the wine list is well planned but not overwhelming. 

The vibe is extremely cozy, the lighting is flattering and one is able to taste a spot or two before deciding on a full glass. 

This is a must - especially if you like little places tucked away in charming alleys.
author: Katherine B.

description:
I returned to Hotel B with the intention of inventing a new memory of this place. It was easy as pie. Gorgeous, really.

The scene on Tuesday evening was cooled chic. Around 6pm, the place was chill. A few couples cuddled or mingled with their wine glasses. As more downtown workers left their offices, they began to filter in with the hopes of being transported to a European wine cellar. And they were!

Wonderful wines. I'm still blown away each time with the exotic selections. No two-buck chucks here (not that there's anything wrong with that). I have yet to try their cheese plate; it looks fabulous. 
Go if you want to be surrounded with sophisticates and great company.
author: Maureen S.

description: Ahhhmazing wine list ... I was here on a date and it was magnificent with the ambience and the flickering candles. I'm mostly raving about the wines we had though, which were incredible ... Haute medoc for round two and a Sonoma syrah for round one. My date equally enjoyed her wines, though I can't remember which ones she had
author: Brandon M.

description: Very cool, quiet little wine bar. Pretty decent selection of wines, quietly tucked in an alley way near Zuni Cafe. Perfect for  a night cap.
author: Julian R.

description:
I think SF has a way with film-noir-type ambiance. A rainy, foggy or misty night is best spent in a nook, down the alley (named after one of SF's famed harlots? or just the flower?), around the dumpster, and yes, in the brick buidling. The wine selection is varied (many countries are featured) and sure to fit everyone's taste. I wish there was more variety with the food though, but I understand you don't come here to eat, only to nibble. I also like when you can order a mix of cheeses without ordering full orders of the different kinds...you can't do that here. I also think the layout could be cozier (the chairs need to be different). 

All in all, a cute place with a unique feel to it.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
You know the Sex and the City episode where Carrie and Big are just starting to date, and he always takes her to that Szechuan restaurant that is filled with couples who don't want to be seen by anyone they know?  Well, that's kinda the feeling that I got from Hotel Biron.  OK, so not everyone in there was on a date, but it seemed to be very easy to "hide" from the general public if you wanted.  Yes, I was on a first date, and I definitely prefer to be incognito on first dates, since I'm already self conscious as it is.  

So, I actually did like this place, as it does have a pretty cool vibe and some interesting pieces of art on the walls.  My glass of Cava was tasty (I love bubbles!).  And the whole place doesn't actually feel like a hideaway; it actually started getting quite lively by the time we were leaving.

I'm sure I'll be back at some point. . .when I need to hide!
author: Danielle B.

description:
This place is like a hidden gem. If I lived closer it would be my regular after work spot. As is, it's a great spot to meet friends who are driving into the city because it's close to the off ramp and there is easy parking near by. 

It's cozy with dim lighting and lots of little circle tables, a comfy couch, and a short wine bar. Because of the lighting and the narrow space it seems very private even though there are people around you. The kind of place where you'll tell an inappropriate story in public without even thinking twice. It's perfect for a date or getting together with friends to catch up. They have a great wine selections and some snacks that pair well with wine.
author: Jackie G.

description:
The perfect wine bar, the most lovable and heartfelt I have seen anywhere.  Where can I start?

* Most wines are $9-12 for a generous pour in a burgundy glass, $30-40  a bottle.  Mostly European with a smattering of South America, Australia, and US, they are interesting and well-chosen, which means you will get a tastier glass of lesser known wine at this price than paying half more at most restaurants.

* The cheese plates here are even better than the wine, and if you ask they know the menu and are great at pairing.  Huge hunks of thick cut cheese from all over the world and half a loaf of sliced baguette.  A $6 plate plus a $2 quince paste or almond side can substitute for dinner.

* The place is comfortable and completely unpretentious.  A dark candlelit cave off a back alley, there is barely a sign, just a slightly illuminated blue B.  You nave to know where to look.  But what an alley!  It's in the same cluster as one of SF's landmark restaurants and another great but expensive wine bar: Zuni and Cav.  Half the crowd are neighborhood regulars who have been coming  for years.

* They play good music, mostly eclectic alt rock, noise pop, post punk, 60s psychedelia, and European pop, at high volume from a good sound system considering the space.

* It is open until 2AM.  Every.  Day.  

If I found Biron in any city in the world I would write home how good the wine bars are there.  For this to be in our little town makes me happy to be here.
author: Gil S.

description:
It is Woohoo! As good as it gets! as Yelp would say. Hotel Biron is so incredibly romantic and cozy it should be an actual hotel! But alas, it is "just" a deliciously, dimly lit, haven of all havens wine bar in SF. 

It's tucked into a small alley behind the ever popular Zuni and the small sign and single entrance door is just enough to detour the "non-locals", but screams out to any levelheaded San Franciscan to come on in! It's dark, it's comfy, and the wine list is good. I always tell the bartender what I like and they always give me a good rec. And if you like cheese, there are always some delish ones to go along with that wine rec. 

It is hands down my favorite date spot in the city! And being on the edge of the Castro even this gay yelper feels completely at ease tucked away on one of its couches.
author: Shannon K.

description:
Beware the walk to the bathroom...  The stank of love-making was in the air last night, that's for sure.  

So Hotel Biron is a nondescript wine bar/art gallery tucked away on Rose street off Market.  The only distinguishing signage is a big orange B out front.  If you see that, you are only moments away from a great selection of wines, and if you're lucky like we were last night, a free porno show on a couch tucked away in the back of the restaurant on your way to the bathroom.  

Wines by the glass or bottle are available, and the full gamete in terms of selection.  Reds and whites from the US, Argentina, France, Spain, Portugal, and several other countries.  We tried the Malbec, and a Portuguese wine, then a Spanish wine...  All reds, and although the last one smelled like wet dog at first, it actually tasted amazing.  The smell could also have been a result of the sour stank from the lovebirds in the back.  They were back there for some time; hands exploring, loins burning and erupting in passion and lust, tongues and lips locked in a heated embrace.  Hahaha...  There is also a small menu, I believe, although we had just eaten at Zuni, so we didn't partake.  

The atmosphere is my favorite part of this experience.  I really enjoy art, especially when I am buzzed and can make up funny shit about the artists' state of mind during the painting.  I like to try and reconstruct just what the artist was feeling at the time, and it is usually really far-fetched and typically pornographic in nature.  (I'm just a man...)  There were plenty of art works in here to keep me busy.  It's dimly lit, candles at each table, a few sofa chairs, many tables, and even a little bar.  As I mentioned, there is also a couch in the back, but I would imagine it has seen more action than the "hottub" at the Welshley Arms Hotel.  (See YouTube SNL skit for details.)  But in hindsight, the atmosphere may just encourage some "beernt chicka beernt beernt."

I will definitely go back.  Great little place to relax and enjoy wine and company!
author: Sean O.

description:
I had high hopes for this place after reading reviews on yelp, but unfortunately, I ended up walking out of here before even enjoying a glass of wine. 

Upon entering the half-packed bar, I looked for place to grab a seat with my partner. We ended up playing musical tables for a while before settling in towards the back because the tables along the wall in the front were either sticky or stinky. (Think of mildewy clothing.)

I approached the bar to ask one of the patrons if there was table service since the bartender appeared to be busy, but before she could answer, the bartender interrupted to tell me, "No." 

I grabbed a couple of menus and returned to our table. Once we decided on what to order, I walked over to the bar again and waited awkwardly behind the people who were seated at the bar for far too long, while the bartender seemed to be preoccupied in the kitchen. When he finally poked his head out and I told him that I would like to order, he informed me that he was busy making a cheese plate and I would have to wait until he was done. 

I don't know if the place was understaffed or what, but I just think that there is a better way to take care of your customers, especially when those customers have been waiting and everyone else in the place seems to have at least a glass of wine.
author: Kristin A.

description:
I really like the space, location and ambience...but it's really small and it's pretty hard to find a table on a busy Saturday. Prices are also a little steep ($12 for a glass of prosecco) 
But i'll be back!
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Loved this place! We almost missed this place since it's hidden in a back alley. This is definitely not a place for groups its more for a date night or a night with your best friend. 

The wine list is huge. We took forever choosing our wine. However, I don't think it was possible to make a bad choice there. 

Next time I come here, I'm definitely splitting a bottle and some cheese.
author: Ashley B.

description:
This is the kind of joint that 10-year-old me expected old-enough-to-wear-lipstick me to be hanging out in someday. I wish I could bring her here and show her it's everything she hoped it would be. 

I'm talking about exposed brick, dark sexy back rooms, bohemian beers and stemware, discussions about art and culture and technology? She would love this shit!!  Also, getting children drunk is always fun.
author: Megan W.

description:
I was recently planning to meet a friend at Cav Wine Bar but they were closed (closed on Mondays for their Summer Schedule). So we went around the corner to the Hotel Biron Wine Bar. It was great.

The wine list is very interesting and we found a great bottle of Red Bandlo at a very reasonable price. Red Bandol is usually rare and I was surprised to find it there. The wine was very good and not too young.

The atmosphere is nice and the decor has some interesting artwork. 

Highly recommend it!
author: Reza M.

description: Great hidden spot. Walk to absinthe.
author: Jared M.

description:
Hotel Biron is one of those places you discover and want to keep all to yourself.  Too good to be true, you watch in pain as it explodes in popularity.  

Situated in a back alley in Hayes Valley, the B sign over the door is unassuming and its gates are reminiscent of a Parisian dive.  Intrigue is compounded when you enter.  The lights are low, the walls are a dark red and hung with fine art.  

The wine list is tastefully curated, especially the reds, and draws from international hot spots like Chile, South Africa and Spain.  When complimented with a full cheese plate, you can be assured you'll stay late into the night.

A tip -- if you've got a hot date, try the sexy back room. It's excellent for make-out sessions.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Well slap me on the booty and call me happy, cuz I just found my new favorite neighborhood wine bar! ....And it only took 7 days! Saahweeet :) 

Hotel Biron isn't a hotel, unless of course you want to take your palate and good time on a little vacay. Then by all means, this is a 5-star adventure into the land of cool. The exposed brick walls, the warm colored walls, the purse hooks, the indirect lighting, it was like being at home, but better because the place is filled with cool peeps and an even cooler staff! 

Chris and Josh were workin the bar last night and if they weren't already scoring points with the colorful banter and stellar wine recommends, they pretty much solidified a place in my heart when they played not one, but TWO ELO songs for me. And they don't even take requests!! Yep, I love this place and I will definitely be back!!
author: Stephy S.

description:
Adorable, amazing. The cutest little European hotel / wine bar I've ever seen in San Francisco

Came here for a drink before dinner in Hayes Valley. It's tucked away in an alley off of Gough near Hayes street.  It's tiny, romantic, and perfect for a date or to meet up with girlfriends to have a glass of wine and chat.  

Non-pretentious at all. Everyone was super nice and the bartenders were attentive and gave great recommendations.  

The wine list is pretty extensive, mainly with European (French) wine options, a few from Australia, South America, and Napa/Sonoma.  They also have a good beer list. NO LIQUOR, which is fine.  They also have hors d'oeuvres (which we didn't try), but I'm sure the cheese selection would be quality.

I def, def, definitely plan on coming back here. It's so cute and romantical!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Me likey.  I wanna love it and squeeze it and bite it and sip it and lick it and hug it and then spend the night in one of the uncomfortable chairs.... joking, joking.

I went here a few weekends ago on a Saturday night when a couple of friends and I were looking for a place to go that wouldn't be too sceney.  We found it!  Albeit, after checking out Plac Pigalle(smelled like BO that night, but overall I like that joint), and Suppenkuche (we were originally craving beer out of a boot).   I must say I really love Hotel Biron!  I love that you can order almost any bottle of wine off the menu and it's good, real good.  I love the cheese plates you can order - be sure to ask the bartender her suggestion.  She suggested a bomb ass cheese plate with some kind of cheese that I could have made a mattress out of and given away for Christmas presents. yum!

Good place to start a good date, or end an amazing one...
author: Kelly H.

description:
The only thing that I like about Hotel Biron is that it's tucked away like a hidden closet in a castle. 

Unfortunately, that closet isn't so exciting once you enter inside. The selection are acceptable and the pours are decent. But it's more of a pit stop on a night out.
author: Jason C.

description: Eclectic selection of beer, cozy atmosphere. Um... dunno, it's missing *something* for me to want to come back.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I recently went here for the first time, and very much enjoyed this place! The intimate feel and decor of this bar reminded me of a restaurant I visited (and thoroughly enjoyed) on my first-ever trip to Amsterdam, and their selection of wines was quite extensive.

Since I'm not a wine connoisseur I can't speak to the prices, but the wines we had were excellent. The staff was also quite friendly and helpful with recommendations, and I felt very comfortable hanging out here. No pretentiousness to be found in this place...

I'll definitely come back in the future, and next time I'll have to take note of the artwork that other reviewers mentioned...
author: Art D.

description: Like others have said, it's hard to find, but worth the search. Decor might be offputting for some, but my friends and liked the unpretentious vibe, and there was a nice mix of people there. Not my favorite part of town, but it's worth checking this place out. I'm no sommelier, but I know a fair amount about wines, and there were several choices on the menu that I wasn't familar with. Fortunately the staff were helpful and knowledgeable. We plan on going back....
author: Scott G.

description: a hole in the wall wine joint in the middle of nowhere really..but it has its charm.. its practically a one man show for the bartender has to take everyones order..they a couple of cheese plates but the wine list is pretty good considering how cheap the bottles were. Great place to start your night or wind down for happy hour.  Great find in the mission area...a must visit. 3.5/5 judochops for uniqueness.
author: Dustin G.

description:
Best wine bar in the city (that I've been to thus far).

Love the cozy interior, wine list, cheese selection, and service.  

This place is great to take over with a group, have a meet up with a friend, or have a drink with a honey.  Totally casual and comfortable.  They pour a nice glass of wine, and they'll work with you to try something new or find something you may like.

I love it's location on Rose Street.  It reminds me of a curious little alley somewhere in Europe with a SOHO sign.  I'm a sucker for design and curb appeal.

There's really nothing more to say.  You like wine?  Go to Hotel Biron!
author: James M.

description:
Only a few words can describe this place.

Secluded. Intimate. Small yet very comfortable. 

The selection of wine is listed from country to country. I enjoyed the Pinot Noir and 39*. Very delicious!

Perfect for dates and little social get together.
author: Stanley K.

description: Love this place! It reminded me of the types of coffeehouses I used to frequent in college. It has a very comfortable vibe with they cool, edgy art on the walls and the dimly lit setting with broken in couches and comfortable low slung chairs. The bartenders were cool and had great recommendations based on our feedback. We pulled up a spot at the bar and chatted it up with them about music, wine and the neighborhood. This bar is located along the same block as Zuni Cafe and Esperetus Brazilian BBQ. It's a great place to chill out on a date or hang with your friends in a low key setting.
author: Aunny B.

description: I'm shocked that this gem is still open after all of these years and is thankfully still a hidden spot. I first found Hotel Biron on a trip to SF back in 2003 or so. I fell in love with the chill, dark, hip vibe of this wine bar/gallery in the alley. On my trip to SF this weekend, my friend mentioned this place, and I remembered everything about it. It still looks the same inside and has a nice young crowd. The wine list is extensive and has something for everyone. Prices are a bit high, but I hear the owner is willing to pour a variety of tasters if you ask. Had a nice cava rose for $13/glass. It's a great place to go to get away from the crowds and to enjoy nice wine but in a hip environment rather than a stuffy one. Look for the orange circle with a B in it in the alley behind Zuni.
author: Catherine N.

description:
This is a place to remember, boys...
put it in your back pocket & take your perspective honey here.

Hotel Biron is a darling, long, narrow wine/champagne + beer bar just off Market St, behind Zuni. It's sketch outside, but inside, it's like your own mini European vacation. (Especially since they serve alcohol from France, Italy, Spain, Germany- Australia, Argentina, & America too). I love the exposed brick, the dark romantic atmosphere, the clever artwork, and the terrace-like tables and chairs. All this & it's still got the loungy feel. And dont worry about having to be a wino (or champagne-o). It's low key and completely unpretentious. 

I'd go here on a date, or with a group of girlfriends...after such delicious champagne you are likely get smoochy with anyone you're with.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I am in love with Biron. Winemaker friends turned me on to this back-alley gem when they first opened and I have spent many a night, 3 bottles deep on the Biron Back Couch, only to leave with a dizzy head and starry eyes. The vibe at Biron ranges from slow-motion dreaminess to edgey chaos.  Biron's wild side is reserved for the weekends, when the crowds pour in.   Midweek is a great time to enjoy Biron's quieter side.
The wine selection is excellent, with many price points covered and great variety in the wine itself. The folks manning the wine bar are extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and friendly. They really know their stuff and are passionate about what they do. They have cheeses and snacks available, which becomes critical after that second or third bottle...
author: Autumn K.

description:
Wine Bar Mecca.

Literally. Just....amazing. 

I like my wine bars to have a hell of a lot of pizzazz to them and this one lived up to all my expectations. It's located in an alleyway that anyone could very well pass, and the entryway in unassuming and unpretentious. It's small, dimly lit, perfect for a romantic rendezvous or a meetup with friends. Their wine selections are diverse, with many great international picks. The pours are generous and the cheese that is paired with the wines are divine. 

This place, after one visit, has quickly become one of my favorite SF winebars, hands down. 

Go. Experience. Enjoy.
author: Aisha K.

description:
Nice selection of wines, and both the glasses we ordered were smooth and generous-sized pours. They do have cheeses which I didn't try even though they looked tempting.

The other big plus is the ambiance. It's not trying to be cool; it's just cozy -- but with class. And when we went early Saturday evening, it wasn't crowded at all. Great for a pre-dinner drink. Definitely will be back.
author: Tamara M.

description:
Non-descrip alley behind Zuni cafe reveals a very cozy, intimate wine bar that you'd only figure out is there by word of mouth.  This is a great date spot with a solid selection of wines, cheeses and other goodies.

Honestly the markup here is higher than you think, which is why its not 5 stars. They are killing us!  that nice Aussie red you like so much that you've never heard of? Biron will prob charge you 12 bucks a glass for a wine that costs 17 bucks for a bottle. With that said, this is still one of my favorite spots to go with just one person or a very small group where we can get a small table and talk.    I really like the small back room that seems to be empty most of the time. Score.
author: Morgan H.

description:
Pity the value shopper here. While the selection is impressive, do I really want to pay $12 for a thrifty pour of South African red? You folks know how personally I take bad pours, and this place had an abysmal price-to-pour ratio. Nothing was cheaper than $8 or $9, and sometimes that is tolerable if the sturdy stemware were, say, partially filled with the wine. Mais non. Not so much. We're talking $11 pours far, far, below the equator, people, and when it's so low, it doesn't matter if you're drinking from a goblet: you feel robbed. 
 
The third star, by the way, is because the service was low-key and unpretentious, and the place itself is cozy and brick-lined and reminded me of a wine bar or two near my old digs in Brooklyn.

But if you want wine, check out Cav nearby. Similarly pricey, but seemed a bit more accessible. Or, stumble down Market Street and move on to cocktails at Martuni's. (See my review.)
author: Kathleen G.

description:
this place is awesome. so hard to find, so lovely!
the wine selection is quite nice.
apparently they do serve snacks too. though i didn't try them.
author: Joe G.

description:
This is the first time I have tried a place based on Yelp reviews, that I just did not care for! 
If you are looking for a dark hole in the wall on a dirty street, then look no further! I literally had to steep over a homeless person to get in the door. When we walked in, there was this horrible smell, kind of like dirty socks. 
After standing around for a few minutes, we got to see a wine list. They do have a good size by the glass list, just nothing I would really care for. I guess if you want to try some random wines, this would be a good place. For me, it's not what I think of when I think "Wine Bar"!
author: Lisa A.

description:
What a gem of a joint.  I sampled two spanish white wines at the bar - neither to my liking.  The barkeep did not bat an eyelash and found me a delicious crisp Italian wine that was refreshing.  Such hospitality.

Nice cheese options.  The triple creme was so spreadable and sinful.  This could become a habit.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Celebrated a friend's birthday last night at Hotel Biron and was VERY please to note that the artwork has changed! The interesting but unappetizing surrealist paintings have been replaced with innocuous sepia prints of cityscapes, coffee shops, etc. Plus one star for pleasant artwork!

And thanks again to the bartenders for recommending excellent and reasonably priced bottles of wine. We had a fairly large party and drank our way through several bottles - all delicious, not a single miss. One word of advice to large groups: try to arrive early and dominate the back room. Seating in the main area is scattered, so our party was split between two tables with several people having to stand.
author: A M.

description:
A lovely little wine bar tucked in an alley way... how speakeasy of it! 

As time passes and I mature from a "beer, cocktail and shots pounding dance club goer" to a "my liver can't handle more than a couple glasses of wine and I'm really just looking for a good conversationalist," Hotel Biron is a place on my regular list.

They have an extensive list of wine and with their impeccable taste, it's pretty much guaranteed that you'll get a good bottle not matter what you choose. That and the DELICIOUS cheese menu...OMG I love, love, love cheese. Overall, I'm just a happy camper.

The space is quite small and if you're lucky enough (getting there early) you can score a couch seat or the backroom. Otherwise, you and your mates will have to hover around like vultures to pounce on the next free table. The music selection isn't bad... very indie. (Whatever that means anymore.) But it's not played too loud so you can carry on intelligent banter if you wish. There's also usually some nice looking art on the walls (as this place doubles as an art gallery) but let's face, we're here for the wine.

Some minor complaints: It is on the pricey side (ex. paying $2 for half an apple to accompany your cheese plate) and the last couple times I went, the place smelled like a public swimming pool. You know, musty sweat and chlorine. It was weird but I got over it. 

On the plus side, parking's never usually an issue. Franklin St. pretty empty when we go. Just don't take our parking space, now that I've revealed this secret!
author: Viv C.

description:
Kept wanting to say to my friends, "I am Batman, I am Batman!" Watch Batman Begins, find cave, light with dimmer on "uber low," add some sleek furnishings, compile an assortment of wines -adding a $5-$10 markup per bottle, cue soft ambient beats, and VOILA! like crack to the 'heads the "hipoisie" come a runnin' to empty their wallets. Only in SF where the per capita of wine bars ah-springin' up is surpassed only by cafe's and startups. 

On the plus side, the cheese plates are a smart pairing with any of the wines.
author: Johnny C.

description: A pretentious sucky place with super tiny bar that forces you to interact with a bartender with no personality.
author: Kyle K.

description:
Biron couldn't be any more hip if it were tucked up James Dean's rectum.

It wouldn't be any harder to find either.
author: Patrick A.

description: One of those places you'd never find unless you were looking for it but is definitely worth the search. A cute, tiny wine bar hidden off Gough and Market around the corner from Espestus. The lighting is low with a four seat bar and tables spread around the long, rectangular space. Probably could only seat 20 people at capacity. A full two pages of wine ranging from new world to old world and a good spread of both reds and whites. From the prices of glasses ($12-$17) you'd probably be better off with a bottle. A nice selection of cheeses as well for those of you looking for some sustenance. Overall a great find a place to hit up when your in the Market/Hayes Valley area.
author: Rebecca D.

description: This is a lovely spot to have a drink after dinner at Absinthe. I like the nice comfy couch, and if you park yourself there, you might just stay all night.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Since they tore down the old abandoned building next door and built condos the place has become a yuppie haven and is always packed with loud self important assholes who for some reason feel that screaming their anecdotes make themselves sound more interesting than they actually are. 

I miss the days when this was a quiet hole in the wall you could take a friend, get a table, sip wine and catch up.
author: Geoff W.

description:
This place is our living room.  From the first time we walked in it felt cozy and familiar.   You'll see the same faces of old-time Hayes residents night after night mixed with young professionals who just discovered it.  Fortunately, if you gave most people a map a compass and a boy scout they still couldn't find it.

The art installation is usually evocative (sometimes provocative) enough to inspire conversation until it changes the next month.  Chris changes the wine list regularly and our only complaint is that the sparkling list is a bit uninspired and doesn't change that often. They're open until 2am, so this is the perfect place to stop and have a glass or two when you're not quite ready to go home, but aren't really in the mood to go to a club.
author: P J.

description: This place is really small. Way smaller than you would think it would be. The guy working there said it was named after somewhere in France. He was very nice and the beer and wine selection here is amazing. I really appreciate places that have both a good ambiance and staff who both friendly and knowledgeable. It is a great place to take someone on a date, I don't know if it's the kind of spot you want to roll in solo though.
author: Nicholas A.

description:
This place is dark, cavernous and sexy.  The wine list is expansive and the mixed media art on the walls really adds to the ambiance. A friend brought me here for my birthday and it will certainly become one of my regular haunts once I move to the city (and definitely when I visit in the mean time).

Strongly recommend you try the Vignelait  French triple cream cow's milk cheese with your glass of Zin.  It is simply put, divine.
author: Emily G.

description:
It's not a hotel, first off.  :)  

It's a little hole in the wall, industrial vibe wine bar.  

The bartenders know their sh*t.  They keep it simple and do it well: wine, champagne, and beer.  I told the guy what I like about wine, and he suggested the perfect drink.  I liked it so much I want to go back and drink it again. They offer a few items to munch on.  Simple seating, not a whole bunch of fancy decor, just raw natural ambiance.  I think the place probably holds no more than 30 people.  Perfect for a cozy and intimate atmosphere, outside of your living room.
author: Denise B.

description: If this neighborhood gem had yet to be reviewed, I wouldn't want to be the first to let the cat out of the bag. One of the very best spots for a great glass of wine, a beer and small bites in San Francisco. Great ambiance in a cozy space featuring work by local artists.
author: Kelli G.

description:
Intimate and old-worldly, and often impossible to find standing room in, Hotel Biron is in a class all by itself. Its tiny, cavernous-feeling space evokes continental Europe, where the gastronomy is second place to the conversation and communion of people.

That this place is located in Deco Ghetto makes it all the more oddball.

I don't necessarily call B's limited wine selection a fault, or a con. The space just seems too small to accommodate anything more.

That said, the selection is good enough, and the people who work here are always friendly enough to help you find something should you need it.

A standard pairing of cheese, meat, and olives rounds out your tasting.

As Nicole G. and Tara R. have said, the place is unassuming and cozy, which works well when it's cold or hot.

If you care for wine at all, and love getting out of the house to drink it, Hotel Biron is a must.
author: Jeff H.

description:
My favorite sexy, cozy, friendly, chill out spot in SF. I've been a devotee for 6+years. Where else can you walk up to the bar, describe what style of wine you're in the mood for (crisp, mineraly, austere, interesting, white, red) and get 3+ amazing choices to sample. Glance at the menu, tell 'em what you like and let 'em choose the wine.

OMG. Did I mention the cheese?
author: Sirima S.

description:
When did I end up in Paris... I didn't realize I even left SF.  Oh wait, I'm still here... look at the ugly alley I just walked down to get here.  Once you get in from that nasty looking alley you are greeted by warm light in a very Parisian environment.  They have a great wine selection and many great cheeses to go with it.

Highly recommended.
author: Jeff S.

description:
Petite. Lets say INCOGNITO...because lord knows I have walked by that ally plenty of times...and never NEVER did I notice this cute little wine bar! So the atmosphere is relaxing, rusticky sort of you can say. Small seating, there was a fairly large group of us sitting on and around a couch. It was fine, not tooo tight, a bit snug though. To snack they have cheese (of course, its a wine bar!) your choice either a baguette or some crackers, and your choice of fruit to compliment the flavors of the cheese. We ordered the....forot the name, but its third in the list...nice Brie like cheese, but smoother...very nice on the tounge. With Apples...an excellent combination!! The wine was yummy. They have a good selection of wines from either Australia...Napa...Italy...France...Argentina....and more. 
Check it out....Get your cheese your bottle some olives...mmmmm, and your good to go.
author: Marivel M.

description:
"We're going to Hotel Biron...."

"What, have you been kicked out of your apartment?!"

"No, it's a wine bar, silly!"

I seemed to have miss this trend of naming places Hotel when in reality, there are no rooms being rented there by the night....or so we think! 

Hotel Biron is located on a small little alley in between Gough and Market in Hayes Valley.  The night we went there, the power happened to be out there and in a two block radius!  But that didn't stop Hotel Biron from serving their wine....no, they pulled out these funny things called candles which made for quite a mood.  Who needs technology, eh?  Well, we did when we found out it was cash only...d'oh.  Walked two blocks to where the power was working to the ATM.  But once back in Hotel Biron, yes,  we were feeling like it was the middle ages....bring me my mead in a tankard!  Minus the minstrels and codpieces of course.

The staff were very friendly, they had plenty of flashlights for patrons to peruse the menus, and even managed to come up with some snacks for our friends.

Wine was good although I thought maybe they'd have more of a selection being a wine bar.  I enjoyed myself and the company immensely.  I hope to visit i again when all the workings of the 21st century are in order!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I feel bad reviewing this place--I've always wanted to keep this place to myself, but seeing how I only learned about this place from friends and HB already has been written up in Zagat and the NYTimes, the jig is up.

Great selection of wine, friendly staff, and their cheese/olive/fruit selections pair extremely well with wine and friends. Be sure to get the quince paste, walnuts, and pear.

Flattering candlelight abounds for you and your fabulous friends/date. (Not so good for admiring the artwork, but that's not why you're there, is it?)
author: Richie K.

description:
I really wanted to like this place more than I did.  It had promise.  It was a teenage girl with braces and sorta bad fashion.  She might grow up someday and be really hot, but in the meantime, she's gonna leave some teeth marks on your, uh...

Well, maybe that image is a bit much.  There were some couches and comfortable chairs peppered about, but if your group was larger than three or four people, someone was getting stuck sitting in a wooden folding chair.  It was much louder than it needed to be.  The wine selection was good, but there wasn't anything "particularly daring or interesting," as the wine aficionado of the group pointed out.  Indeed.

Also, I noticed a Grateful Dead picture on the wall.  Minus one star.

It would be a good place to take a date or a friend or two.  A group of six or seven?  Not so much.
author: Alissa K.

description:
Came here with my friends and had a bit of trouble collecting enough chairs to sit together at a table.  I should point out too that the iron wrought chairs made for an uncomfortable sitting experience.    But I didn't come to the bar to just sit.

The artwork on the walls were the images my dreams are made of, and I scribbled the name of the artist on a receipt after we left, but our Maytag rendered that artifact into paper pebbles and pocket lint.  Anyhow, I didn't come to the place to just look at pretty pictures.

It was a bit of a wait in front of the little bar stand -- a bar window sill, I should say, because it was that small.  I'd advise to just keep a general idea of who would be next after whom because they kind of just bunch up.  Me I'm short, so when I have to assert my position, I do so to the effect of looking like a little girl looking up to tug at a grown-up's shirtsleeve. But I wasn't there to be a baby about waiting at the bar.

I hadn't really checked out the wine bar scene in SF and cracked the code for unlocking its new popularity among those within my humble sphere of influence.  So we hung out for about an hour or so before "last call".  I would find more enjoyable wine bars in my future, including one I went to last night, but all in all, I left satisfied and a bit tipsy, so yeah, mission accomplished.
author: Marjorie B.

description:
Hotel Biron is one of the places i miss most after leaving San Francisco.   They have a great selection of wine/food...but so do most other places in SF.  

What sets it apart is the atmosphere.  Its dark, moody, and sexy-- much like myself.  Its great for catching up with a friend or trying to snag the secluded couch in the back for a make out session.  Its pretty quiet...with a constant din that makes conversation comfortable.  

Great date spot!
author: Janna V.

description:
This is a great place for wine and cheese!  And for whatever reason, the cheese choices are so frickin good - it seems like cheese consumption is not the same outside of these 4 walls...
small downside is that it is small - and sometimes difficult to get the coveted couches if you are a party of more than 2.
But the woman who runs the bar - super nice and informative about her wines!
author: Square P.

description:
Dear Hotel Biron, 

How lucky I feel to have found you, wondering the streets at 11pm looking for a place to rest my stilettos...

I knew as stooped into your warm and dimly lit interior that I had found my match.  Dark leathery couches, unpretentious, inviting...I could tell at first sight that you were someone I could really settle in with.  

And it's not just looks, Hotel Biron, that keeps my heart afloat.  You got SUBSTANCE.  I mean, look at that wine list.  Australia, France, South Africa, you are so CULTURED.

But, like any good relationship, things started to become shrouded in doubt.  I loved your spirits, but my soul hungered for more.  

Wait, what's that you say dearest?  You have tasty tidbits a plenty?  Well in that case, I'll have the triple cream brie and sweet medjool dates.  Yeah, just like that...

Darling, as long as you continue to pour your heart into making mine happy I think we will have ourselves a life long affair.

Until next time...
author: Becca A.

description:
Inconspicuous. Chill music and crowd. Comfortably intimate. Wide selection of wines and fine beers. A self-service approach to drink ordering. 

This place rocks and another reason why City living is the best and why Hayes Valley is climbing my list of best areas in SF to hang out. A perfect spot for many things: pre-dinner drinks, post-dinner drinks, casual meeting to catch up or a date.

Do it, done.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Hotel Biron has all four pillars essential for a bar to be truly great - Great Decor, Great Wine, Great Clientele, and most importantly Great Staff.

When you come to hotel Biron, you feel almost like you are part of a family - a large, sophisticated, yet incredibly cool family. A family that enjoys life and shares stories. A family where you could potentially face legal consequences for the feelings you have for your siblings.

It's not a cheap place, but quality is something worth paying for, and here quality is relfected in all aspects.
author: Kevin R.

description:
Hotel Biron's website states that "This pint-sized wine bar and art gallery brings a touch of Paris to a San Francisco backstreet." and I could not agree more.  It rests on Rose Street in between Gough and Market in the most tucked away spot only recognizable by the letter B outside of their cave like space.  Wine selection is huge, but I tend to ask for a recommendation and have yet to be disappointed.

Although it's been there for some time I consider Hotel Biron a welcome addition to the Hayes Valley.
author: Catrinel A.

description: Good date spot. Quiet, low lighting, good wine. Never would have found the place on my own. It is tucked away on an alley type street. If you are looking for a chill place to spend the evening, chatting over a glass of wine...this place is the way to go.
author: Aubs J.

description: I really enjoy the atmosphere of Hotel Biron.  The wine list has a lot to offer, although I wished it offered more.  As a fairly experienced wine drinker, I want a little bit more originality to the wine list, although I think it is still great.  The candles, cozy tables, chairs and couches, and artwork really offers a creative energy.  I like the hidden room in the back as well.  I had a very memorable evening here, the bartender was extremely nice, and the atmosphere made the experience that much better.  If I lived closer, I would be here more often.  It is a place to bring a date, have good conversation, or go by yourself if you are trying to explore more wines or want to read.  I definitely think it is worth checking out.
author: Ashley W.

description: It's one of my favorite wine bars in SF.  Small lounge tucked in an alley in Hayes Valley and it's never over-crowded.  Quiet enough to have an intimate conversation, but not so dead silent that you feel like everyone else in the establishment can overhear your conversation.  Dimly lit mood lighting that's great for a first date, excellent wine list and unpretentious!
author: Janet L.

description:
Rotating wine lists with a good balance of Old World/New World.  If you're looking for a cheapo wine bar, this is not it (if I remember correctly avg glass price was somewhere btwn $10-20).  However, if you are hoping to run into a delighful Savennieres from France or a great Pinotage from South Africa, then you will have some luck here.  

Whatever the list says on their website, it won't be true when you get there so don't plan in advance (note how they don't put any prices up on their site!).  That is also what makes the place fun, every time you go you can explore the new list and they have a very healthy by the glass selection.

This is the kind of bar for people who know wine or want try something outside of what they get in their local liquor store.  They have some of the standard Cab/Chard/Merlots, but they shine with the alternatives and you won't be disappointed with the quality of the wine, worth every penny.  That, and the cheese and pate plates are a real treat if you want to spoil yourself a bit.
author: Spencer J.

description:
After checking this place out a couple times, Over time, this place was a great little secret that is now out.  

Excellent looking crowd last night.  

Luigi Bosca
author: Michael R.

description: Ever shoot a PBR at a wine bar? Well, if you hang around Hotel Biron long enough, you might find yourself doing one with the cool (but not too-cool-for-school) owner, Chris. He has a heavy hand with his wine pours, AND chooses good art to display each month. And good lord, the cheese... delish. This is one of my favorite places in the city. Great for a birthday gathering or an illicit rendez-vous.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
this place is fucken awesome !

When I hear wine bar i think of a marina club house, where the men wear sweaters as scarves, and the women have their faces pulled back so many times that it looks like a rubber mask. if thats the place where you would want to go get a glass of wine, this is not your joint.

the decor, art, and the wine menu will keep me going here while im in the city by the bay.
author: Ishmael V.

description:
The wines and the cheeses here are brilliant. I love the dim-lit ambiance with the comfortable chairs. And though it's posh, it's not pretentious. Rather it's warm & inviting, and my favorite wine bar in the city.

Admittedly I didn't find Hotel B myself, but an old flame brought me here to talk and catch up. And he definitely knew my taste, as I fell in love with this place immediately.
author: Sally M.

description:
I HEART Hotel Biron!  It comes across as possibly being pretentious, but it's really not at all.  A great combo of hip, cozy, and casual.  A perfect place to end a romantic date or a rockin' girls night....    

The wine selection is pretty great, and the cheese plate is YUM!  The staff is super knowledgeable. All you have to do is tell them what you are in the mood for... and they'll match you with the perfect wine.

I want to move to Hayes Valley so I can go to Hotel Biron all of the time....
author: Jennifer K.

description:
I felt like one of the cool kids who was in on the secret last night when we strolled into this bar!!!  

I was like, "Take that, I'm not a dork!  I am a cool kid!"  Luckily, I said it in my head.

Anyway . . . good wine, hard to get a seat, 30% off for restaurant industry peeps on Mondays - wait last night was Monday, what the hell was I doing drinking wine?  Oh well, that's what the cool kids do!
author: T-Bag S.

description:
I came here after work and before an event at Herbst Theater to meet a friend for a drink.  The interior of this place, while a little tight, was nice and cozy.  The bar was a little awkward, but I didn't have a problem getting a glass of wine. I was a little disappointed that after perusing the wine list there was not a single glass under $10.  So, I don't know if I'll go back here for drinks, but it was nice while it lasted. 

Oh, and the alleyway you have to walk through to get here? Hella sketchy...
author: Maryam S.

description: I love this place. It's hidden away, has a cool, dimly lit wine bar ambiance (just the way I like my wine bars), eclectic wine list with tons of amazing wines that you won't see just anywhere and the owner is typically behind the bar. Feels good to support a local small business and get great wines and experience at the same time. I often do drinks here first then dinner somewhere in Hayes Valley
author: Brooke h.

description:
Pretty good wine bar in the Hayes valley area.  Hidden in an alley where a homeless guy is always walking around with a golf club (not sure why) :)
Great wine selection and the atmosphere is great for chatting it up with a friend or someone special.  Also check out Cav which is around the corner.  They have more of a food selection.
author: Mitch A.

description: Sweet cozy ambiance for a date or small gathering of friends who want a nice glass of wine. The food menu is very  limited... and expect to pay $3.00 for like 8 almonds or 3 dates as a side munchie. Other then that, the wine selection is tasty.
author: Amaline B.

description:
Many, many years ago when I was in Paris with a girlfriend, one night we met these two guys. I was translating bits and pieces of my friend's quickly blossoming vacation romance (the only language they had in common was the language of love), as well as managing my own new 'friendship' and having to think quickly enough to say in French, "I don't CARE if your apartment is just around the corner. I don't WANT to come to your place to take a bath." I am so not French. But hey...things can change, actually. ;)

Anyway, on another night they took us to this bar called " le Caveau du ...something" as I recall. It wasn't in the guidebooks. It had no sign. It only had a guy sitting on a stool at the entryway, with whom one of our friends exchanged a few words. 

And then we descended a set of old, narrow, concrete stairs into the bar. The room was actually a sealed off intersection of two drainage pipes in the old Parisian sewer system. It was darkly lit. The sound was not echo-y, but a little muffled, so voices didn't carry. There were nooks & crannies. There was hip, but mellow music playing. The whole place was just sort of clandestine & oh so sexy...

I tell this story just to offer a point of reference. I was hoping to find a similar sort of vibe at Hotel Biron. But needless to say, I was a little disappointed. It's not that it's a bad place, but based on others' reviews, my expectations were a little out of whack. 

It has potential, definitely. I liked the little room in the back, the selection of wines is huge, but I was shocked to see a Chilean Santa Rita wine for $8/glass. That's about what half a bottle of pretty decent chilean wine costs. The bartender was quick with recommendations & definitely knew her stuff. 

It was packed and loud, and the music was this metallic screeching that actually seemed to amplify the din of the crowd (I could hear 2 other tables' conversations besides our own), and I found it annoying. I would have liked to have heard some Massive Attack or something...just something smoother or darker. And maybe some fabric on the walls or ceiling to soften the acoustics? A decent place to go have some good wines with friends, but not what I was expecting.
author: N B.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.

And NO, it's not a hotel, it's a wine bar tucked in a little alley in back of Zuni Cafe.

It's super teeny, dark and warm inside and they have a nice selection of reasonably priced wines, cheeses and goodies to munch on. 

It's the perfect spot for a rendezvous with your favourite someone, do some naughty things because nobody is really paying attention. As good as it gets...
author: Nenette Y.

description: I am a fan of this place because of the vibe. I am an industry person so I usually go by myself and talk to the staff who have let me sample some things for free. The location and list are good but it is primarily a space that is waiting to be activated by a social scene, all the potential is there, soft lighting, old materials and a good layout, minimal setting and a wine list.
author: Josh L.

description:
Man.  You know I want to give this place five stars just because it's so beautiful and serves most of the food groups necessary for survival (chocolate would have pushed me over the edge).  Drawbacks:  maybe it was that bottle of wine we downed, or the fact that it was a sultry August evening, but  it was seriously stuffy in that little spot.  Biron, you're trying to *emulate* a cave, not *be* a cave.  It was also stoopid expensive.  There comes a point where a hunk of cheese just isn't worth $20, no matter how hip everyone is trying to be.

On the other hand, it has candles on the tables, and the night was gorgeous and hot and ripe.  I'll definitely go back if I can trust myself with that wine.
author: daisy s.

description:
On a cold, rainy San Francisco night its places like these that really make me appreciate and love this city.

I'm a wino. And I'm not usually a discriminatory wino, in fact me and Mr. Two Buck Chuck have been involved seriously for quite sometime...

However sometimes its really delectable (like that word usage? me too)to do the wine "thing".

I love the environment in here. Very small, very cozy, very maroon. Their wine selection is amazing and they have a great industry deal on...shit. Monday? Tuesday? One of those days....dammit. where was I?

Cheese.
I love cheese. I love olives. I love nuts (hahahahahaha). You put wine in that mix and I'm pretty much in heaven.

Best part? ITS IN MY NEIGHBOORHOOD!!!! Booya.
author: Stacy L.

description:
Why haven't I been here before... what an absolute gem of a find..

It was Fides b-day and Hotel Biron was the selection. It's in a dark alley behind Zuni Cafe.. It's a small quaint brick room with very funky artwork. The wine selection was delicious.. the cheese and meat plates artistic.. I do love this place it brings me back to nights in Paris.. Ambiance is sexy and sleek.. It's a bit small so it may get crowded and hot, but it's worth the experience. 

This place is a must!
author: Monica S.

description:
Comfy couch to whisper about who shagged who on the studio floor- you know who you are!

Felt like I was in that scene from Funny Face, the one where Audrey Hepburn dances around like a kook and the beatniks just do their thing. 

OK- I'm really talking about myself. 
Hope they don't have security cameras.
author: Krismet C.

description: I wish they had a bigger selection of cab francs.  Great painting behind the counter!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Good wine selection, if a little expensive, served out with a friendly and informal style. There are not many wines available by the glass, so for the high-octane testers amongst us, the novelty factor quickly disappears, but the selection is pretty good, if a trifle conventional---you won't see a lot of exotic fruits and varietals here.  I lost my wine-tasting virginity here and in the process, discovered the D'Ardenberg "Footbolt" 2002 Shiraz, and the Coldstream Hills Pinot Noir here, so it's got a special place in my heart.

Update: I have since lost a little faith in HB. The wine selections haven't rotated as frequently, and the crowd has become a bit too boisterous for my tastes. Yes, I understand that a true devotee of the wine bud should be oblivious to distractions when pouring his energies into his aesthetic dialogues with a wine, but there is a certain amount, and perhaps quality, of chatter that simply defeats my most Zen-like abilities to concentrate.
author: Sameer S.

description:
Hotel Biron is a quite small but very cozy wine bar and art gallery that lends touches of Paris to its comfortable and appealing ambiance. Very dim lighting, modern yet comfy decor, a handful of copper tables, wrought-iron bistro chairs and zinc-green walls decked with a revolving exhibition of local add to the mood, and form the perfect setting for an after-work get-together or romantic rendezvous. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and the wine list is interesting and not expensive. If you can, it makes sense to buy by the bottle as for the most part bottle prices are only 3 times that of the glass prices when offered. A brief food menu including cheeses, seasonal fruits, charcuterie, and olives is designed to complement the wines.


I arrived a bit earlier than my friend and luckily was able to snag a table near the bar area, and ordered a glass of 2006 Sur "de los Andes" Torrontes. It was light and refreshing, but lacked a fruity quality that I had hoped it would have. Once my friend arrived we tasted a few red varietals, and decided to go with a bottle of Jenke Vineyards Shiraz from the Barossa Valley. It needed to breathe just a bit, but notes of berries and a strong earthy quality made it really delicious and interesting. We also tried a couple of the cheeses. Old Quebec, a Canadian raw cow's milk cheddar aged for 3 years was rich and creamy, and Serra da Estrela, a Portugese washed rind raw sheep's milk cheese, was also decadent and delicious. Hotel Biron is really an adorable spot I hope you get a chance to check out if you haven't already done so. It's just off Market Street on Rose just behind Zuni Cafe.
author: Leah B.

description:
Im not a big fan of this place- so you've got exposed bricks? wowie???
It was pretty cold inside and SMALL.  There's an alcove room with the couch and the wine bar and the bar stools in the front- not comfortable if you're in a dress!  Its probably worth a stop by if you're early for your reservation at Zuni's- but that's about it!
author: Arissa C.

description:
So much to like...just hope it can stay that way. With luck, many of you will have too much trouble finding this place and it will somehow remain relatively undiscovered. Eh, what am I talking about? It's hopeless! I mean, I'm writing a review telling you to just look for the little B outside on the creepy side alley off Market Street...But I digress...

Where was I? Oh, yeh. Hotel Biron. Charm abounds. A wee small, and kind of hard to find a seat at prime hours, but look, you wanna get there early anyway, because there is a lot of good wine to taste, and a lot of great cheese to be washed down, and it is going to take some time. 

Oddly, the prices are even reasonable here, especially for the eclectic selection of beers. Wines range all over the globe and various styles, with something for everyone. And if you dont know any of them (which you might not) just ask one of the friendly keeps to recommend something based on what you DO like. 

My only minor teeny tiny complaint is that the front part of the place can get quite cold when there is a lot of in and out traffic on a blustery night, so definitely get in and move toward the back, but not all the way in the back. Back there, the scene changes a bit, and youve got bathroom crowds to contend with. The middle section is perfect. Closest to the bar, and warmest, and great people watching spot. And I must say, there's many a peeps worth watching. 

Enjoy.
author: Geoffrey D.

description:
What's up with the Klu Klux Klan-ish photo in the bar? I know the photo comes from some other European origin, but it's provacative without being informative. Since we live in the United States and are still experiencing extreme racism, I found it to be inappropriate.

Other than that, I did enjoy a delicious glass of Riesling and a nice plate of blue cheese with pear. I also love how it's tucked in a random alleyway off of Market St. like a true insiders hang-out.
author: Thanya S.

description:
I am in utter disbelief and shock at the appallingly rude service I received recently at Hotel Biron.

I went there with my husband to celebrate the five-year anniversary of the day we met (a day that's always been very special to us).  Given the easy location, the late-night hours, and the romantic atmosphere, I thought it would be the perfect place to share a bottle of wine.

I was treating, so I ordered a bottle of Malbec from Argentina and we brought it to our table.  When my husband tried the wine, he noted that it tasted very acidic and seemed to be past the "good drinking point."  Although my palette is not as refined as his for wines, when I tasted it I had to agree that it did not quite taste right, a bit on the sour side.

My husband approached the bar and let the bartender (or wine steward, or whatever he calls himself) know that the wine was not good, suggesting "try it and you'll see."  The bartender smelled the wine and said, "It's a Malbec."  My husband responded, "I'm from Argentina, I know what Malbec is supposed to taste like."  

At that point the bartender turned around abruptly, opened the cash register, took out the amount corresponding to what the bottle of wine had cost, and shoved it into my hand, sneering at us indignantly, "You're done!!"

I have never experienced anything even remotely like this in any restaurant or bar.  Any decent establishment would have offered an alternative wine, or at the VERY least, an apology to customers who were not satisfied with the quality of what they had ordered.  Instead, the staff treated us as if we were some kind of low-life scum and kicked us out of the bar.  And the most astonishingly insulting part of it was that I had to ask the guy to give me back the gratuity that I had left him.....apparently he was planning to keep his 20% after insulting us, kicking us out, and basically ruining our special and romantic evening??!!

I know Hotel Biron looks charming and all, but in fact it is the snottiest, rudest, most pretentious place I've ever been.  Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else where the staff exhibit some shred of basic human decency.
author: Holly P.

description:
Hotel Biron is my second favorite wine bar in SF after Hidden Vine. Although Hotel Biron probably offers a slightly better selection of wine by the glass,  the bartender (Chris?) is always helpful and knowledgeable, and the space itself is very cool in that exposed brick sort of way, there's something about the place that always leaves me wanting just a bit more. Can't really put a finger on it, but I'll keep coming back since it's in a great location for starting or ending an evening.

p.s. if you go with a large group, try to get there early and snag the back area - you'll feel like you have your own little VIP area save for the occasional dude wandering back to take a leak.
author: Chris B.

description:
Really great spot. I would never have found this place had I not been introduced to this place by a friend.

Really good wine selection from all over the world, Including Portugal, Germany and Spain - along with lots of great local wines from Napa and Sonoma.

They also had a good selection from Australia, my fav.

The bartender was really helpful describing the wines I was interested in, and in making recommendations.

The glasses of wine I had ranged from $10-15, so its not super cheap, but hey, you get what u pay for.
author: Lee M.

description:
Just jumped in to say hi to a friend, I was totally impressed with the small comfortable feeling that I got from being here. 

If I had a group that wanted to mingle and be together, I think this would be a great location. 

I didn't have a glass of wine, but they sure looked delicious in the very large red wine glasses. 

I want to go back for further exploration.
author: Danielle V.

description:
I thought this was a great hidden find.  it's quiet, dimly lit and a great place to start out the evening with a special person or a couple girlfriends.  

They have wines and cheese and it's just so cute and perfect.  I had a great time here.

Good company is essential.

Also, it's right by Zuni Cafe, fyi.
author: Angie C.

description:
Category: Wine Bars
Neighborhood: Hayes Valley

I've been to quit a few wind bars in the city, and this is my favorite so far.

Met my friends in the back otherwise known as the as the "make out room" in the back on the couch. I was overwhelmed with the wine selection and quickly excused myself to order for us.

Ordered a bottle of Italian Petite Syrah and some Paive Vecchio cheese.
The cheese was amazing, completely blew the wine away, while pairing with it really well.  I felt like a baller as Chris let me try between three different wines and I chose my favorite. Some cougar the bar tried to hit on me but I had  lady waiting for me in the back.

"Peace out Cougar, maybe another night"
author: Adam L.

description: Went there last Sunday around 7pm pre-dinner and it was fairly empty. Had a nice glass of malbec upon recommendation from server and a portuguese cheese with quince which was quite goood indeeed! Like the ambience and will definately go back again!
author: Renuka V.

description:
Love this place! 

Very impressive wine/sparkling selection considering the size of this place and the hidden location! I went a couple of times with different sets of friends - every time was a blast! Last time I went was a hot night so my friends and myself sat on the bench outside and drank up a bottle of delicious bubbly!! The only drawback was the dumpsters nearby. 

The bartenders are really cool and definitely know what they are selling - I like professionals explain the goods with personal experience and knowledge.
author: Penfan S.

description:
A somewhat hidden gem, tucked away from discovery in the alley behind Zuni. It's not a hotel, but a cozy, very intimate wine bar, with helpful sommeliers, a healthy selection of domestic and international wines, and tight-knit, candlelit seating for dates and small groups.

The cheapest glass on tonight's menu went for $8, and everything else was about $13-26. Bottles are also available. If you're not sure what to try, let the sommeliers recommend something. They're very genial and patient, and if you tell them a little about what you like, they'll be able to find you a suitable wine or champagne, and which of their cheeses and meats to pair it with. Most of the items on their food pairing menu went for $5 each, with enough to share, and certainly much better than the supermarket-grade stuff I've seen in other SF wine bars for triple the price (tsk tsk!). Between baguette or cracker, I'd say their crackers are a good choice. Yummy!

Another thing of note: I noticed there was nearly all professional female patrons in this tiny wine bar tonight. Just two men came in the entire 4 hours I was there, and one left quite early. Indicative of the normal scene here? Hmm.
author: Clar L.

description:
Stopped here before having dinner at Zuni - it's right around the corner so it was way more convenient than fighting for a spot at Zuni's counter. 

Really loved everything - the atmosphere, as well as the drinks. My man was happy to see they had a beer list as well, and I was surprised that they had some unusual beers not even I had tried. The wine list served us well - I had a lovely sparkling wine. 

If I had known about the fabulous cheese plate beforehand, we would have allowed more time before dinner. Which would have also allowed for more drinks. Live and learn.
author: Shal J.

description:
It's a little on the small side, but what a find. The wines I had here were amazing - some flavors I've never had before and I wish I could remember the name of this one white wine that was the most delicious i have ever tasted.

The atmosphere is very intimate, and the bar is teeny tiny, just big enough for you to order and then go sit down at a table, but it is a cool spot for a date.
author: Kristen W.

description:
This is a nice place to relax with a friend or a hot date, enjoy a pricey (starts at $10) but generously poured glass of wine and maybe one of their lovely cheese plates as well.  A perfect medium between swanky and laid back--you don't have to dress up to go, but if you happen to be sporting your fanciest duds you won't feel overdressed either.

The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable about wine and cheese and all that good stuff--a great place for people who aren't quite sure what their tastes are when it comes to wine--they even let you taste the wines first!  Yum!

It does get a little claustrophobic sometimes...a good place to either start or end your evening, but not necessarily a whole evening unto itself.
author: Kevin H.

description:
This place is super chill.  Nothing about it is pretentious.  Just a solid wine list, a friendly bar staff (super helpful!), and a cool create-your-own cheese plate on the menu...(I love that!)...

I don't quite remember leaving that night (maybe TOO much wine?), but I remember having a blast and being completely satisfied...
