FYI...A little off the beaten path and hard to find...but worth the effort.  Cozy.  Lovely.
author: Susan L.

description:
Super cozy atmosphere. Yet very sophisticated. The wine selection is great, they answer any questions you may have and they encouraged us to ask them. Which in my book is a thumbs up. you are spending a pretty penny on a beverage and you want to know what it is you are drinking. I loved it!
Cheers
author: erin D.

description: Tucked away in an alley like a speakeasy, the space is a dimly lit brick-lined cavern. The wines by the glass were excellent and the cheese plate was delicious. Prices aren't cheap ($8-12 glass, $5 for snacks). Also there is no table service, so you'll have to order at the tiny bar. Because people were crowded around the bar, ordering was a bit awkward.
author: Jeremy S.

description: I almost don't wanna review Hotel Biron even though all us locals already know about it.  It's nice though b/c of how cozy it is and it's a great place to close a "deal" :)
author: Gene X.

description:
My friends just called this place "B" for the longest time since that's the only sign they have on the outside.. Hotel Biron is a wonderful place to take someone you want to chat with -- it's small, intimate and quiet enough to carry on a decent conversation.  The wines are delicious and the staff is friendly, and it's never too crowded to get a nice seat... 

And it's on Rose street.. such a good name...
author: Dennis Y.

description: It is everything it claims to be. Warning: a bottle of Vouvray and a plate of chevre and salami taken on the couch in the back room can lead to love not so fleeting.
author: L W.

description:
You'll probably get more out of a review written by someone who wasn't already drunk when they got here. From what I recall, it's an out of the way, tastefully decorated (if somewhat dark) place with a carefully selected wine list. 
Just about everything we tried was good; If you're trying to impress someone special, bring them here and when you pick up the menu furrow your brow and appear intensely focused, then point to anything on the menu and say "I think you'll enjoy this." Chances are they will.
author: matthew r.

description: Try to sit on one of the comfy couches and don't be shy to try wine tastings. everyone is really cool here and you can either sit at the  bar and hang out with the staff or enjoy the pleasantly romantic, dark decor and couches. Eclectic wine menu too!
author: Laura F.

description:
Have been a huge fan of Biron for as long as it's been there. Chris & Zach always take great care of us. I found myself eating (and relishing!) a truffle cheese that I was sure my mushroom hating taste buds would disagree with. Being the winos we are, there has never been a miss at the B and the artwork I see there often finds its way to my house.
Be sure to hit up Jess Imports around the corner...she's part of the family and her jewelry rocks!
author: Colleen B.

description:
Know how you're sometimes afraid to plug a place because you don't want it to be too trendy and loose it's luster? Well, I think it's safe to talk about this place because there are plenty of other alternates in the area to go to.

Several times I've found myself going here, thinking I'm kicking off with a few glasses of wine and then going for dinner elsewhere... only to end up sticking there and eating great cheese and drinking more great wine.
author: Joe R.

description: This is probably ironic, but I think Hotel Biron's weakness is that it is not big enough.  The best of the Biron is that it is small, intimate, and all nooks and crannies.  So for four couples, you get the full Biron experience of romance.  Everybody else just gets to attempt to enjoy their conversations while wishing they were one of the four chosen folks who got their seats early.  This is not to say that the wine selection isn't top notch or that the winekeep is not severely knowledgeable.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I'm writing this review after having been to Hotel Biron a number of times.  Every time my experience has been nothing short of 5 stars.  

The wine list has a good selection and because I ask for help/tips (unlike some other reviewers below, apparently) I always end up with something delicious.  Because I like to jump around on the list quite a bit and because I tend to go alone, I usually get wine by the glass; recently I noticed that prices range from $9 to $14--clearly this will depend on what the current offerings are when you visit.  And, again, with a list so large and diverse, I would be shocked if you didn't find something you liked (and I would kindly suggest you stick to drinking home alone).

The bottled beer list (from $3 to $10) is also great; the selection isn't as huge, but it is appropriately diverse and offers something for everyone when you aren't in the mood for wine.  Biron also offers sake and non-alcoholic drink options.

The bar area, while small at three or four seats, leads to fantastic conversation with the staff and other customers.  I tend to go alone and I am fine with talking or not talking (I could talk or not talk all day); Biron's staff and customers have always been accommodating to my mood or adjusted it for the better.  The seating area is not too huge either, but I've never seen a group or couple unable to manage when they arrive.  When you come in, stop at the bar and get a menu and order at the bar.  The artwork changes occasionally, and along with the music, adds to the mellow atmosphere.

The tasting plates--cheese, meats, fruits, nuts, etc.--are a great way to enhance the experience.  $6 each per cheese or meat selection, and $3 for side--includes plenty of slices baguette, or crackers if you choose.  Don't know what to get?  Crazy thought....ask.  

Bottom line--good wine, beer, and tasting plates.  I'm always discovering something new, whether it be a friend, food, or drink.  I love this place.
author: Jason S.

description:
Walk too fast and you'll miss the lighted letter B above the doorway in Rose Alley behind Zuni Cafe.  It's a difficult place to find if sending friends for the first time.  But well worth the trouble especially after you spend a good half hour scouring the streets for parking.  

A small front room with intimate tables and couches leads into a narrow hallway, and then to a backroom that's big enough to fit 5-6 people.  They have the usual cheese, pate, olive platters along with a nice selection of wines.  Though prices aren't cheap, they won't charge for getting a taste of the wine first.
author: Kimmie N.

description:
Went here because it's the top-rated wine bar on Yelp.  Ehh.  I wasn't totally blown away.  The neighborhood is borderline sketchy.  The available seating is minimal and uncomfortable (didn't get to try the couches).  And it took us a while to realize that we had to go up to the bar and order.

For the first round, we got a bottle of Alsace Gewurtztraminer and it was decent.  Kinda weird having to pour it ourselves.  Then the second round, we contemplated getting some cheese or something but decided against it since the place already smelled enough of cheese.  We just ordered glasses of whatever we wanted instead.  I got the Riesling Kabinett only because they didn't offer the Spatlase as a glass.  Sad.  But it was still good.  And before we knew it, it was last call.

Can't really say much for service since there wasn't much.  But at least they weren't rude.  And the art was great.  Amusing.  I think I'll try some other wine bars before returning here.
author: spiff e.

description:
Love the decor - raw wood, large photos of spain (or someplace Mediterranean), low ceilings, very small.
The wine and cheese were very good - just a bit more pricey than I like to pay.  But, the pear on our cheese plate was PERFECTLY ripe. And the cheese itself was amazing, so you get what you pay for, for sure.
The staff was super helpful when we asked questions about the music, the wine and the cheese.  They also helped shim our wobbly table (tho, it would have been nice had that already been done).
Overall, it's a sweet, secret spot for an excellent bit of wine, cheese and friends.  
When we left, there was a group right out front, on the chairs from inside, smoking - which, if I were a smoker, I'd be totally into.
author: Adriene C.

description:
Hotel Biron. A Hot Bed of Honeys and Breezies.

I'm exaggerating, of course. What Hotel Biron is -- an unpretentious place to take a date or hang with your friends. I came here on a recent Sunday night, after the ballet and drinks at Absinthe. It was the ideal spot to cap the night. We ordered sparkling wine: a rose and a prosecco. The prosecco parched my thirst nicely.

The establishment is cozy, in a charming European way. Simple furniture. Exquisite candlelighting. For real: the lighting is phenomenal. The pictures here don't do it justice.

Caveat: based on the reviews here, I expected a sprawling lounge. There is only one sofa here, though, (fellas expecting play, take note), and a small room in the back that can seat a group of eight. In any event, Hotel Biron is one place in Hayes Valley I would go back to, again and again. Even without honeys and breezies.
author: William L.

description:
Hotel Biron is a Perfect place to go if you:

1) Are meeting E-Harmony date # 4 sans make-up.
2)  Want to seem "cool" and in the know - people will think that you are taking them to some hotel bar but they will be pleasantly surprised that this wine bar is located in a small alley.
3) Love cheese - their selection is great.
4) Are not hard of hearing - this place can get loud.
author: Clarice V.

description:
I had my third visit here recently and have not been disappointed yet.   You wouldn't think it much from the street, but just a few steps inside and you feel like you are in a basement cafe in the Latin quarter of Paris.  I wouldn't call this a place to go wine tasting, although that can be arranged.  Rather it is a cozy place to hang with friends when you are in a loungy bohemian mood.  

The wine list is excellent, though.  And they have a great selection of cheeses, and other light fare.  Highly recommended!
author: Kurt L.

description: Hard to find parking around here, but a great spot otherwise. The cheese/bread plates are huge, and the pours are generous. I always have a great time when we meet up at Hotel Biron
author: Lady D.

description:
The owner Chris is amazing and very friendly.  Every time I need help finding something I like he has a recommendation.  He will even let me taste.  They have an amazing selection from France, Italy, Spain, Portugal, and US wines.  

My personal favorites are Bordeaux and Brunello.  Some you can buy by the glass and others you need to wait when you are with friends to buy the bottle.

The pate is delicious.  Fresh bread, fresh snacks.  You can certainly leave here spending $50 bucks easily.  Since it's all so delicious.

I've even made out with a girl that hit on me at this bar and who thought I'd be meet a lezzie at a wine bar!  She did point at her girlfriend afterward though.  I love San Francisco.  I don't care for dives.  I'd rather meet someone at a wine bar.
author: Sabrina A.

description:
I love Hotel Biron. 

First of all, it is owned and managed by a fellow Iowan, and he totally represents. I doff my proverbial John Deere hat to you, my friend. I have never once had a less than stellar wine recommendation from you. 

The atmosphere is sophisticated without being pretentious, and last Thursday, even with several hundred madly churning cement trucks outside the door (there is a team of like 10,000 workers on the job overtime building a mystery structure across the street- I asked one of them what they were building, and he backed away from me slowly, claiming to know nothing- very odd), it was pleasant inside the wine bar. 

Despite being small, this place is versatile- good for pre-dinner drinks, night caps, small parties, snacks, intimate chats or falling down drunkenness. If you've never been, I highly recommend a trip down there soon. Just look for the sign with a "B" on it, in the middle of a bunch of cement trucks and frightened construction workers.
author: Angie R.

description:
If Harry Potter's Leaky Caldron came to SF, got a little pretentious and mildly yuppie, this would be it.  I love it, even though none of my friends like to go because my favorite wine is 13 bucks a glass and they'd rather drink tecate light from a paper bag-covered can (sometimes this is more fun, admittedly).  Yeah, sometimes the art is stupid, and sometimes it is hard to find a seat, but everybody knows that teeny, tiny things are always, always, always more fun--that's why girls like dollhouses, and this is the dollhouse of bars.
*An aside: I love the pens they have for you to sign your tab, but that's just me.
author: Jamie H.

description: I had the pleasure of going to Hotel Biron on a date. While it didn't work out with the guy, this spot was definitely something to remember. It is a bit snug, but super romantic. The staff is great and VERY knowledgeable about their wine, and the artwork that was on display was fabulous. I would have bought everything there if I had the money. I didn't get to try the cheese, but I guess that gives me something to look forward to.
author: Natasha T.

description:
I love this place!  Get there early and grab a couch!  Glasses are typically priced ($7-12), or you can buy by the bottle.

What I love most is the fact that you can order nibblies, and they're really well priced.  From what I recall, you can get cheese for $5 and fruit for $3.
author: David S.

description:
Very cool atmosphere!  One of my favorite things about San Francisco is the random small alley ways...not necessarily the ones you find off of six street, but the kind you stubble across that may remind you of a random old alley way in Paris.  This is how I found Hotel Biron...just walking along and oh how cute, there it was!  I really loved how you could either sit in the front and still see outside or hide away in the back and relax on a couch.  

The wine was great.  I'm no wine expert, but I do feel I know a thing or two about gross versus great!  I'm also not rich, so I often go for the cheaper items on the menu and hope for the best!  I ordered a glass of red,  2007 Ochoa, Navarra, Garnacha & Tempranillo.  Wow, it was great.  Great smelling and great tasting.  The guy behind the bar was super friendly and obviously no snob, as he indulged my silliness when I remarked how it smelled like butter.  He gave it a sniff and agreed.  He then suggested why I may have smelled what I smelled.  I love being able to have a glass of wine without feeling I am being judged too much on how old I may look or how black my hair is or whatever superficial thing it may be.  This place is an A+++  for friendliness, location, and of course WINE!!!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Marked by a solitary "B" hanging from the building and tucked into an alley, Hotel Biron is a quaint little gem of a wine bar. Perfect for a friend's night out. I took some friends visiting from Canada there last night and it was the perfect place. Intimate, dark and with a great wine selection. They had been tasting wines from Oregon to Napa by the time they got to SF, so they were stoked to find an extensive wine menu and a knowledgeable bartender. 

It does get crowded but grab a glass of wine and wait a minute, tables turn over quickly.
author: Corey F.

description:
I read about this place in the NYTimes 36 hours in SF place last year and was like, wow, this place sounds awesome!!!  It's actually right by where I live and I dragged a big group of other kids with me finals last may.  we had a pretty good time and I had a german dessert wine which was fantastic - super sweet (just like me, of course!).  

anyway, the place was nice but not phenomenal.  maybe I would have liked it better if I came w/a few people instead of many/hadn't been so hyped b/c the NYTimes description.

but, if you're in the area, you should def. check it out. :)
author: F K.

description:
Hotel Biron is a total Gem. Nicely tucked in Rose alley and still somewhat a secret. I have been here for at least 3 or 4 small birthday gatherings and have had a great time. The space is very intimate and cozy. 

Of course Bambi has no clue when it comes to wine but I have heard that they have some of the best selection in the city. 

Always a treat...
author: Teddy d.

description:
It's all about atmosphere in a wine bar, right?  Great unassuming place with a cool ambiance and a good crowd of people.  I almost felt like I was in NYC.  I will be going back to this place.

Good place to go on a first date or a fifth date... It's a good place to go any time!
author: Jason R.

description: It's a cute hole in the wall, with a splash of upscale Brooklyn (brick walls and all that jazz).  The layout is a bit odd, so, you often end up sharing tables with people.  It lacks a little bit of ambiance, but overall and ok place for a drink or two.
author: Laura D.

description:
Great selection although they do have a fairly high markup.   This can be offset by tasting what you are thinking of trying first free of charge.

It can get a little crowded, but that affords you the opportunity to hear various first date conversations that range from respective blow habits to what the median SAT scores are for private high schools in Philadelphia.
author: Matt T.

description:
Yeah, I spent all of 30 seconds in there. 

 I wanted it to be a new cool little spot I could go with my girlfriend to quaff some wine and munch on stuff.   So what was my (our) problem that 30 seconds was the duration of our stay.?.....?..?

How 'bout a HARD smack in the face with ganky-ass stink upon opening the door.  And, no, it was not a rainy night.

Now, I'm no sissy, mind you, ...I'm blue collar, rough hands with splinters, get down and change someone's toilet w/o freaking out on looking down the poo pipe, not afraid of spiders, crawl around your stinky attic to fix....get the picture?

Do they keep a stock of cheese that does this and I am too much of a Neaderthal peasant to understand? Unsophisticated olfactory pallet?  Do the people in the place not have smellers?  

Or, does this place just downright smell like a busboy's shoe?

I've been in hippy houses that were less offensive.

Sorry Hotel Biron, I can't write about the staff, the wine selection, etc....just the smell.
author: Jason L.

description:
Well, after a few friends had clued me in on how great this place was I finally stopped by with a friend this weekend and wasn't disappointed. It's a narrow space, nice and dark, and offers a wide selection of wines from around the world. The bartender, Allison, was well-informed and nice.

They offer a small but nice food menu which is something that any good wine bar should have to compliment their wines. The duck pate was especially nice. 

One thing that I would like to see here is a larger bar space. With only room for about 4 bar stools, it can be difficult to reach the bartender once the place is full. Overall though, I met some great people, drank some very nice wine, ate some good complimenting foods and enjoyed myself.

Go enjoy this European-style environment for yourself.
author: Gabriel R.

description:
The only thing this place is missing is a cloud of smoke hovering around the ceiling.  The alley entrance, the dim lights and brick walls, the cast iron touches on the bar and tables, all feel like some European underground hangout of pre-War intelligentsia.  We're holding out against the fascist threat!  We're wearing all black and talking about existentialism!  WE'RE GETTING DRUNK WHILE WE DO IT!

It's more expensive than places I usually go (hey I work for the love, not for the money...er....), but an oenophile has got to indulge occasionally.  And Industry night on Monday nights makes the indulgence a bit more doable by, say, easing the guilt of ordering a $16 glass of auslese.

The staff is knowledgeable and friendly.

Vive la resistance!
author: Ashley B.

description:
Wow. this is definately 6-star ready. HB is understated, and gets a cool, underground cred from its location on an alley, and the understated sign- extra points for a nice ambiance (exposed brick) and even more extra points for the heavy pours.

Their wine selection is always changing, and is almost like an "around the world tour" of wines....and their amazing beer selection always impresses me (nummie belgian beers beyond the chimay/duvel/hoegarden regulars).

For a hilarious story, ask why the keep a baseball bat behind the bar ;)
author: Tim V.

description:
What a great place! I definitely credit Yelp for helping me find it. I love how it is tucked away so uanssumingly, no sign of the entrance except the inconspicuous "B" sign above the door.

Fantasic wine selection -- a nice amount of variety without being overwhelming. The staff is excellent and unpretentious. Prices aren't super cheap but I've never had anything here that I didn't enjoy. Cozy atmosphere great for a small group of friends or a pre-/post-dinner drink with a date.

Not crazy about the outdoor/style table and chairs. They look nice but are not all that comfy. Try and grab the couch if you can!
author: Jill M.

description: LOVE Hotel Biron - what a great little find in Hayes Valley.  And yes, it is a find - the first time I went here I thought I was totally going the wrong way and there it was all tucked into nothing.  It is such a cute intimate place and a true SF gem!  The wine and cheese plates are just lovely and it's just such a cute, intimate place.  You can can chill out and relax on the comfy couches or sit at the bar and chat.  A nice, dark wine bar - can't go wrong with this place!
author: Carly P.

description:
love this little place....

You must try the dry jack cheese and pears...

fab!
author: aynne v.

description:
On some nights, this is my favorite wine bar in the City.   These nights involve getting a spot on one of the two cozy couches in the front room and enjoying interesting wines with great company.  

On other nights, it's crowded, standing room only,  and slightly less appealing.  But don't get me wrong, I'm big fan of this place regardless.  I'm just bummed the word got out.
author: Peter G.

description:
Excellent.  Love it, what a cool place...  I had not been here in a few yrs. and I went there last night on a great date and it was stellar!  Although I was not the one choosing the wine, from what I observed there was a very extensive wine list and we had to great wines.  One from Cote du Rhone region and another from Italy.

Make sure you do not get the small table in the hall, other than that it, is excellent.  Super cool mellow vibe you will for sure dig.
author: Nicole F.

description:
It was a cold and exceptionally windy Sunday evening. I approach a friend and she whispers, "look for the B in the alley." The surrounding empty streets worry me that it's either closed or vacant - neither are ideal situations for my brother's bday outing. After missing the alley about 3 times, I see the gently lit round orange sign with a white "B" in the middle, and I realize that we've found our destination. 

We open the door and find that we've not only found Hotel Biron, but perhaps another world. I peek behind me as I let myself in to make sure that the SF street outside hasn't disappeared! 

Upon entering the narrow, cozy space, you're hit with a warm glow of light and the murmur of European tongues in lively conversation. Edgy art adorns the rustic, pale dijon walls. The inviting bistro tables, few tall bar tops, and loungey sofa and coffee table set you up for intimate seating and chit chat. 

Our group of 6 is able to snag the living-room-like cushy couch and coffee table. After tasting a few unimpressive less expensive wines, we opt for a bottle just a smidge above our original target price range. 

Although the bar looks more like a check-in desk at a bed&breakfast or boutique hotel, rather than a bar, don't be fooled... no hotel rooms here.
author: Sharon C.

description:
When visiting the Bay Area this is a stop I am sure to make.

Serves as a perfect interlude- 
sitting on the couch with their selection of wine and cheeses leave my palate warm, and my mood sublime. A great visit with a date, or with your friends for a fine social time. 

LOVE the selection of fruit plates! You create your own perfect mix of sweet and saucy.

Prefer early and late nights, when the crowd is less invasive-
author: Christine E.

description:
Update: The service here is super friendly and so nice to visit.  Chris the owner and all his staff are always all smiles.  The wine is selection is always good.  I have become a wino and a regular at this awesome SF bar.

Biron is a very sexy setting for drinking a lovely bottle of whatever your preference...nice selection of regional wines from the top hitters in the world.  I also adore the cheese selection for $5 a plate. Last night I had a semi-hard goat cheese that was delicious.  

Other than that, one of my very favorite spots to feign sophistication in.
author: Amy H.

description:
5 stars, baby!

I never even heard about this place for years. Then, one day, I heard about it. I've visited several times, and enjoyed them all, except for the one weekend visit. It was a bit too crowded, and the place doesn't work well with crowds. With the hard floors and brick walls, it tends to get a bit noisy. 

And the wines! Excellent selection of old world and new world moderately priced wines. Just swagger up to the bartender and tell 'em what you are looking for. Next thing you know, you'll be sampling three or four. How cool is that? Clean, quality glassware makes the wines taste and smell their best.

For those of you complaining about prices, I actually thought they were reasonable. The normal markup for a restaurant is to charge bottle price for a glass of wine. Hotel Biron usually beats that, and they are a wine bar!

My dream someday is to do the Zuni Cafe-Hotel Biron linkup...
author: Raoul D.

description:
WARNING: If the Redwood Room is on one of your top lists, then this is not your spot. 

Delicious little wine bar! My favorite part of it is all the little nooks created  by the odd spaces in the raw brick. And it comes as a lovely surprise on the rundown little side street it inhabits. Typically a bustlin young crowd, and if you're lucky you might sneak one of the comfy leather couches.
author: Jeremi M.

description: This place has a great rating and over 400 reviews for good reason. If you want a comfortable spot to spend an evening with friends, and a wine selection that's *always* spot on, Biron delivers. Christopher, the owner is always behind the bar and making excellent suggestions. I recently celebrated my birthday there: Guests who had never been were delighted with Biron, and guests who were familiar with Biron before were glad to be back, like seeing an old friend. I just wish there were more places like it in San Francisco. Until then, I'll be coming back often.
author: S O.

description: What an interesting, classy, fun, funky, understated gem. The owner is knowledgable and down to Earth. Wish the prices were as right as the ambiance and wine.
author: Andrew K.

description: Amazing wine list, and nice and knowledgeable staff.  They give great recommendations based on very vague and confusing responses to questions such as, "what do you like?"  Not snotty at all, in my opinion. (though the other patrons might be, as Ed to the M pointed out.  I dont' talk to them though.)  Comfy couches and table seating - very dark and romantic.  Amazing cheese.  A perfect post-dinner spot and in my opinion, the best wine bar around.
author: Molly B.

description: For the record, we arranged to go here before it was "discovered" by the NYT. I've been to many wine bars in the city and this place has great parisian brick arty little nook feel.  We ordered two bottles of wine and two cheeses with olives -- only $24 per person!  Quibbles: it suddenly became crowded with people with asymmetric haircuts, ironic and/or striped tees and supertight jeans around 8:30. That kind of place.   Also, the bartender didn't pour us our wine -- just the first one to taste. Then handed the bottle and the glasses over.
author: Vanessa H.

description: The perfect getaway spot after along day....sip and snack your way to bliss.
author: James B.

description:
True class, all the way.  Wonderful selection of wines, extremely knowledgeable staff, incredibly cool ambiance.  Probably my favorite place in the city to get a great glass of wine and just chill.  It does a great job of being a social place if you want it to be, or being a place where you can nook up in a corner and enjoy the ambiance.  

To the reviewer below who complained about the "$12 to $16 prices for a glass of wine".....uh.  That is pretty standard in the city, and for the quality and selection of wines at Biron, and the knowledge of the staff, I think it's pretty darn fair.  I have never been poured a glass of wine without being offered a taste first, and I have been going here for years.  Not sure what your issue was, but it is way out of line with what my experience has been here for years.  

Five stars for Biron, all the way.  Thank you guys for all the years you have provided us with a warm, wonderful, quality place to enjoy some really great wine.
author: Sienna L.

description:
The perfect little wine bar, Hotel Biron is way off the beaten track, distinguished only by a small neon "B" in an alley-way off of Gough.  Make a bee-line for the back room and try to score the lone couch, the perfect trysting spot for late-night/low-light encounters...

Edit:  My most recent trip to Hotel Biron made me realize that this little gem is no longer off the radar.  It was packed on a Wednesday night and the combined effect of loud music, a bar full of people trying to talk over it, and all of it bouncing around off of the brick walls made it a lot less intimate and a lot more clamoring.  

Still a great spot, but had to demote to four stars for the noise factor spoiling the intimacy factor (unless, of course, you happen to score the couch in the back room - that's five stars all the way!)
author: Katie C.

description:
My very favorite hidden spot in the city. I am happy this place is not popular, as it doesn't get super crowded. Love the bricks and the laid back attitude the stuff has. Laid back, but still nice and attentive. 
The back private area is awesome if you are planning to have a little gathering with friends.
author: Liza A.

description:
I just love this place. Chris has such an amazing selection and fabulous taste.  He buys really crafted wines at great price points. I especially enjoy the German/Austrian selections. He has great finds. Plus he even offers a fantastic fromage plate. Added bonus is the Fatted calf pate! Perfect for newbies as well as wine geeks. Get off your ass and drink some wine. I enjoy coming here during the week. The weekends do get crowded. It is a fun place for friendly people. 
My friend and I sat looking at the construction across the street pondering if we should buy into the housing development they are building across the street. How cool would that be to live across the street from Biron.
author: Jennifer S.

description: So happy to find this place.  Will definitely be going back many times.  Great atmosphere, cool art, and the cheese plates aren't mini.  The regulars are wonderful to chat with on a Saturday night.
author: Emily B.

description:
With the intent to establish a local, neighborhood bar for myself, I walked the two blocks down the hill from my apt to meet  a friend here. I had been happy before (see previous review). Sadly, I had not factored in the appeal of this wine bar (there are several others within 100 feet) on a Saturday night. Ultimately, I was disappointed with the crowd and found it to be a bit older, stodgier, and "old man who just tried to win over a much younger, prettier lady with dinner at Zuni." (i.e. ewww, please stick to the marina, dudes)

Outside of that, the wine selection is reliably good - but then, of course, I'm not an expert and am quite happy with any alternative to Chardonnay, Chablis, or Merlot.
author: Angela N.

description:
Would be 5 if they weren't sold out of 4 out of 5 things I'd wanted to order from their wine/beer menu, and if their cheese plates and snacks were a tiny bit better.

Still my favorite wine bar, I think.  Pretty full on a Monday night around 10pm, btw!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Wine Diary Entry #1

Bordeaux
Was it the 2005 Alain Graillot, Crozes Hermitage, 2005 Domaine Denis Carr,"La Perrire," Hautes Ctes de Beaune, Burgundy, or 2005 Domaine Bouletin, Vacqueyras? Whatever it was, it made me fall in love with reds again.

Wine industry people hang out here. Received a great recommendation for a 2005 Chardonnay. What is it? Sh! It's a secret, until you read the next review. Giggle.
author: Cathy H.

description:
With all the word-of-mouth it gets, I'm not sure how Hotel Biron maintains its cozy, intimate feel. Perhaps it's the odd location, or perhaps it's the prices that keep it from overflowing. Regardless, it's a great place for a few glasses of wine.


 Walking in, you almost feel as though you left San Francisco and have walked into a chic East Village lounge in New York. Only it's a bit more welcoming, and probably less expensive.


 At first glance, the wine list and small food menu are pricey, until you see the portions. The pours are generous, and the plates of cheese, bread, charcuterie, etc. suddenly seem worth more than the going price of $5. Everything is tip top - even the cheaper wines.


 The atmosphere is casual yet classy, and the iPod hooked up to the sound system is diverse enough to ensure that everyone will hear at least something they like. And this is a very good thing. Because there's nothing worse than having good wine, good cheese and good company, only to have it ruined by crappy tunes.
author: Omid T.

description: I like this place a lot. The lighting is perfect, cool art, good wine and cheese. I've enjoyed this place with friends as well as a date.
author: B K.

description:
Wine bar, with emphasis on bar. This is a place to meet friends and have a good conversation and they happen to serve wine by the glass. The deco is hip and interesting, but not warm. 

Wine selection by the glass is smaller than some other wine bar.
author: hsiao c.

description:
Delicious selection of wines by the bottle. I took two out of towners here along with a local (his 1st time) and all were impressed by the selection & snacks. I was enthralled with their fromage, mmmm stinky cheese!
Once you have your seats, its kind of a hassle to walk up to the bar everytime you'd  like to place an order seeing as it is slightly small & cramped, but I just use that as an opportunity for more people watching & spying on who's tasting what at the bar.
I found it to be low-key on a weeknight & probably would avoid the scene on the weekends due to capacity issues.
All in all, I highly recommend this little wine bar for those of us who like to enjoy our vino, talk amongst friends and chill in dark corners.
author: Claire S.

description:
Wow, My first wine bar...

Great cheeze...

Had some good wine..

Outstanding. Great intimate enviroment. Not so great for 5 guys and one girlie friend.
author: Larry L.

description:
Without pomp, pretense, or any of the other characteristics of your typical wine bar, Hotel Biron serves up a tasty glass.

I suggest the 2003 Vigneti Massa, Monleale, Piedmont, Barbera... balanced blackberry and raspberry notes, deep luscious red color without the tannins of a Cabernet.

I was surprised that there was enough seating for our group of seven because it was quite cozy, and small. The intimate setting lent itself to being a date place though plenty of groups were sitting for an after dinner bottle. 

This place is as tortuously sexy as that drop of wine after a pour that meanders down the side of the bottle and stains the label of a '77 Montebello. Hit it.
author: Kevin S.

description: Yield is better, but Hotel Biron is more romantic.  I would recommend only going around 6 for a pre-dinner glass of wine, or for some appetizers/wine for dinner.  Go later than 7 or 8 and the place turns into a loud, almost obnoxious scene.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Hotel Biron continues to be one of the best kept secrets in all of San Francisco. The max capacity at this place is probably about 40 people. The decor is exposed brick combined with an assortment of small couches, small tables, and chairs. There is one very small bar in the middle of the place and the service mantra seems to be "come and see us at the bar once you know what you want." The bartenders are exceptionally helpful, though, and they can recommend a drink to fit your price range and budget. The wine list includes a good mix of domestic, old world, and new world wines by the glass.

Aside from a very pleasant atmosphere (which is a function of the fact that the place really only has seating for about 40-50 people), Hotel Biron has one of the best beer selections in all of San Francisco. They consistently have hard-to-find European beers that you can't find anyplace else. One of my pet peeves is when a bartender serves a fine European beer in the wrong type of glassware -- the bartenders at Biron are smart enough to know better.

This is a great place to share a bottle of wine in a couples setting, to end a first date, or to get to know someone better over a drink a pleasant atmosphere. It is really hard to find this place if you don't know where it is. It is also not in the best neighborhood. Don't let either of those things stop you from checking it out.

And, if you like Belgian beer, try to get your hands on a bottle of Scaldis. They don't have it very often, but it's out of this world.
author: Charles H.

description:
I rate Hotel Biron so highly.  Why? 

Well, Hotel Biron is one of those semi-hidden gems of a city, the type you reference now and again (ok, more now, than again, in casual conversation, constantly), and never go to enough - would every night be enough?  But when friends are in town, this fine place is always high on the list of places to attend to - especially on a week day, as other yelpers have said.  On the weekends it *can* be more crowded, but it's not a guarantee.  I've been there on a Saturday night, sat down with mi amiga and had ourselves some wine, some cheese and some pear, no crowd and no sweat.  And it is always lovely.. 

The exposed brick and low-lighting of Hotel Biron is the backdrop for a constantly rotating art exhibit of, I believe, paintings by local artists.  The friendly barkeeps and kitchen staff are the source for a on-point wine recommendations (if you wish), simple conversation (if you wish), or a board or cheese and fruit (also, if you wish).  I usually wish two out of the three; my wishes are also, constantly rotating. 

In short, I highly recommend.  Find the "B" sign in the alley behind the Zuni Cafe and you know you've arrived for a night (or maybe just part of the night - a start or end?) of good wine, some nibbles, and a chance to share a few secrets with your comrades, old or new..

By the way, if you or your co-conspirator are not into wine, there is a short, but very good beer list here as well: Celebrator and more!
author: Eric H.

description:
Loved this hidden gem. Tucked away on a little side street, it's easy to miss. The space inside is small and funky while being warm and inviting with some cozy tables, a leather couch or two and dark atmosphere. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable and if you play dumb (or really are dumb) and ask for suggestions, they will pour you some reasonable sized-tastes. Definitely the kind of place I can hang at all night! They even have sake and some good beers. 

The only hassle as other people have pointed out is having to walk up to the bar for service as the night goes on and it becomes more crowded. When I went to leave, some people had set up a table right in front of the bar, making it nearly impossible for anyone to pass. Silly, people... why would you block your own and everyone else's only way to obtain alcohol?
author: Scott T.

description:
They lose a star for being too hot and loud on weekends, but that's not really their fault.  Well, on second thought, rugs or acoustic ceiling tiles would do wonders.  And maybe a ceiling fan in the back.  But I don't really go out on weekends anymore, anyway.

I love this place with all my heart and love it more on an early Sunday evening.  (Don't you all get the same idea.  Leave me and my book and shiraz in peace.)  

That said, I've had more blind dates there than I can shake a stick at, and if you look around, you'll notice others doing the same.  Luckily, I'm now happily coupled, so I no longer have to suffer the embarrassment of the staff recognizing me with a different guy every week.
author: Leigh A.

description:
Hotel Biron seems to be everyone's hidden little secret. It's the perfect place to impress your date. If....you date someone who likes to dress up a bit and is impressable by such things. I would say go to Zuni around the corner, and then take her here. The door is in a slightly scary back alley where a homeless person once scared the crap out of me by popping right out of a dumpster. BUT, if you can get past that for 20 seconds, walk right into Hotel Biron.

Here's a hint - It's not a hotel. 

This tiny little cozy hidden bar is a fantastic place to escape cold, foggy, blustery nights in San Francisco (approximately 85% of all San Francisco nights). They have a solid wine list and, surprisingly, a solid beer list including Ayinger Jahrhundert (100 year) beer. Any place that can introduce me to a German beer I didn't know about, and one of this quality at that, impresses me endlessly. Like I said, this is a great place to take a date or two or three of your closest friends.

The one problem is that the customers are fairly upscale pretentious. Think "I escaped from SOMA and I'm 35 years old and I have to impress this woman because I need to get married" pretentious. Part of it is that aforementioned spill over from Zuni, but still, at times, it's a bit much. Or way too much. If you like bars for people watching, only go here if you're in a particularly vindictive or judgmental mood. Otherwise, go here because it's awesome.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Biron if you are out there we liked the walls when they were darker before they were repainted, my friend and I will volunteer to repaint them back to their old mysterious ways.  Dark was part of the thrill! 

This said, great bar. For those ragging on the yup factor, this is not Biron's fault- this happens to almost all bars in SF these days. Pick a time before businesses close on Montgomery Street and Upper Fillmore and you'll be just fine.
author: Mister T.

description:
Brent and I ducked into this perfect little spot after drinks and dinner at Zuni.  It feels like a slightly more modern version of a neighborhood-y enoteca in northern Italy with its narrow walls, warm lighting, and small copper tables.  Very intimate, very romantic.   

They kick off the menu with the Classic Vintage Brut from Iron Horse, so I knew I was home.  Add a fireplace and unlimited access to the cheese room, and I might move in.  We only stayed for one glass but they had a great international selection, including some rare finds from Argentina and Austria.  Stumbling distance from where we live, this could easily become a family favorite.
author: Julie B.

description:
Cheese, Wine, facinating people.  What more could one ask for in a city of intellectuals and refined tastes?  Hotel Biron is tucked away on a little alley amongst the clutter and banter of Market Street, but as you walk through the doors, you are transported to a time beyond the present and sheltered from all the glam. 

Enjoy, be merry and just be yourself...
author: Aimee C.

description:
This place is just fantastic. It's intimate, cozy, romantic, perfectly lit, and has a wonderful selection of wines and small plates of food that complement the wines. I love dessert wines, and the sauternes that I had was amazing. The wines aren't cheap, but they are worth it. 

Sometimes it can get a little warm in there, but it's part of the charm.
author: Joyce G.

description:
Upon walking into this place, one lady said, "I feel like I'm in Paris."  Hey all you dreamy traveler people out there -- you're not in Paris, you're in San Francisco . . . give the city the credit it is due!

Because this place is/was sort of a secret spot, I'd rather not tell you that it is the perfect wine bar.  Quaint setting, great music, very nice and hospitable bar tender, good selection of wines and yummy treats (cheeses and snacks).
author: Mandy S.

description:
OK...I know I am in trouble when I live across the street and have not been.  I finally made up for it and now know I don't need to frequent..but I should show up once in a while.

I felt transported to Europe.  Unfortunately the crowd made this apparent with their (to quote from Ed to the M.) "nouveau Hayes Valley" vibe....we were the unpopular Americans in the midst.  Also, not a glass under $11 dollars was steep, considering the bottle was only 3x the price.

Perhaps if I go again I will be able to give it more stars.
author: David S.

description: I wish I could say that Hotel Biron was a frequent stop for me--it's conveniently located, has a great wine selection, and it's nice and cozy....but (there's always a but) every time I've been here, it's packed. Not just crowded but hot-packed, on the verge of steamy, even on cold evenings. The huge glasses are gorgeous to hold and sip from but when you worry that you're going to get knocked while taking a sip, it's a bit awkward. That said, the art is always interesting, the wine selection is varied and reasonably priced, so come early or late and miss the crowd for the best experience....
author: Hannah R.

description: Combo of urban brick, sheep cheeses, cherries (& other assorted fruits n' nuts), and world-wide wine selection. All this amidst cosy couch and bar stool tables low lit. A short walk from our flat, we like the sensibility and service is educational and swift. The coveted fifth star? Round out the Sake selection, offer a crunchy sliced pear in lieu of mush (or offer only seasonal fruit?) and woo me with the likes of Harley farm goat cheese..
author: Rachel S.

description:
I caught up with some old friends here last night and wished I had arrived around 5 instead of 7:30.  That said, the wine list was extensive and well rounded.  I asked for a wine in the $30s and low acidity and the bartender did a fair job providing an easy to drink bottle suggestion.  I was annoyed that we waited like we were in a crowded bar at 10:30 on a Friday night... though apparently Thursday is the new Saturday. 
 
All in All, nice place close to home that I might go to on weekdays but would avoid as it gets closer to the weekend.  Liked the mysterious location with the single B (i had passed it earlier that day and wondered and was surprised when a friend suggested it).  Wish I had tried the cheese.
author: Sidrah G.

description:
this place has so much potential, but i felt that it falls short. maybe i was just there on a bad night, but not sure that i'll be back any time soon either. i love the ambiance inside, it's really cozy with some sofas around the room and also tables. there's a very small bar area and there's a back room that seems a bit more private, like someone's living room. i liked the exposed brick walls and the art hanging around. so, what is it i don't like? 

well, if i'm going out i like to actually receive some service, otherwise, it was cozy, like being at a friends place. we had to go to the bar to get a menu, put in our order and then i had to bring the bottle of wine and glasses back to our table...really?! soooo....the only added value in this experience is that someone opened a bottle of wine for me? thanks, but i'm perfectly capable of opening my own wine, and would perhaps rather save some bucks and just drink at home. this is NOT service! 

we had a bottle of torrontes which was pretty nice. but i have pretty nice wines at my place too...
author: Angela W.

description:
Checked this place out for the first time last night with some friends of mine on a rainy evening not really knowing what to expect as it was my first real SF wine bar experience and I have to say it was a very positive one. 

The comparisons to Parisian hole-in-the-wall joints is certainly justified, it reminds me a lot of a few places I used to go hang out at in the Marais. There certainly is something really cool about utilizing a very small physical space in a location that is a bit off the beaten path for a place of merriment and congregation. Even though this place might not be much a secret any more being there certainly feels like it. I can imagine it a great place to take a first date to impress someone or for a night out for a birthday or other celebrations.

The artwork that was on display was really cool, a bunch of silkscreen-ish prints of San Francisco scenes in bright colors. Although it looks like it changes quite a bit it also looks like they have really good taste, if I had money to burn I would actually consider buying one! 

This place being a wine bar I should probably say something about the wine. We split a bottle of Malbec from Argentina which was really tasty but wasn't the best wine I've ever had (then again, it was one of the more affordable bottles on the menu). The bartender was really helpful and chatty, letting people taste several different wines before making a choice. The cheese was some of the dankest (that's a good thing) I've had this side of the pond and the olives were spot on as well. The only thing that makes this place a 4 star and not a 5 star in my book is that you really have to spend a decent amount of money to have wine and snacks (all cheeses, meats etc. cost $5 and fruit costs $2). Still its certainly worth it to go every once in a while for a chill night out and I can't wait to find an excuse to come back again!
author: Nicholas B.

description:
What a pleasant surprise.  Of course, being out on a Wednesday night is a great way to appreciate any establishment in SF.

Bartender was laid back and generous with info and tastes.  Loved the recommendations.

The art was a bit disturbing, but it was a cozy way to spend the night.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I used to go there often with my friends lived in Hayes Valley, and revisited here for my friend's birthday party for the last weekend. This bar is very cozy and comfortable which is hard to find in San Francisco. They have great wine list which covers California to Europe. Cheese plate was good when I tried it a year ago. 

I like the decor of this place, too. They usually have cool arts on the wall.
author: Yoko S.

description:
The decor is nice and intimate. Sexy, even.

However, the wine was terrible. For a wine bar, you'd think that they'd carry nicer wines, or perhaps the bartender would know how to properly open a bottle of red without inducing a look of "WTF?!" on my friend's face. She actually looked offended. I appreciated that he sniffed the cork to check if the bottle was good, but it was done like he was taking in a whiff from a questionable sock found on the floor. (Like, is this clean? When did I last wear this? Why is this wet? Whoa, there's a dollar in here!)

I had a cote du rhone and my friend had a sancerre. Neither of us could finish our glasses, and we are not ones to ever waste wine. 

Might come back again for ambiance, but may opt for a cheese plate instead of a glass.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Looking for a very crowded wine bar/lounge on a Wednesday night?  Well, look further, this is it!  :)   (Actually, I think it's always crowded here)

It's dark, it's young, it's hip, and down to earth, I think this place is great for people in their 20's & 30's that enjoy hanging out at wine bars rather than dive bars.

They also have cheeses and fresh fruits and nuts, which goes oh so well with wines they offer.

The only thing is that since the walls, floor, the ceiling and everything is brick/concrete, it can get pretty loud in there.
author: Sophia F.

description:
This place is magic.  I was brought here by a friend, she really wanted wine and I am really not usually a wine drinker.  Ok I whine a bit, but don't do wine at all.  We walked in and I fell in love with the ambiance.  The art on the walls is amazing.  Then we spoke with one of the bartenders, I told her what types of flavors I like, and what I tend to dislike about previous wines.  She picked something out for me that was absolutely perfect.  I wanted to live there forever and ever and never leave, living the entirety of my life off of that glass of heaven.  

This is a super hot spot for dates, and I highly recommend it for those that would like to like wines, but just haven't found the right one yet.
author: Meredith N.

description:
a glowing orange "b" sign was the only thing marking this wine bar.

it reminded me of the wine speakeasies in nyc which light a red bulb to signify that it's open.  like a speakeasy, it was so dimly lit that i could barely read the two sided domestic and international wine list.  they also have a decent beer list with some cheese, fruit, nuts, and charcuterie.

order at the bar with the bartender to collect the wine - the food plates are delivered to your table.

although small and intimate - who doesn't look good in candlelight?
this place was a wee loud.  try to score one of two couches in the place - there was one in the main area and one in the more quiet nook by the single bathroom.

if you are a full red lover like i am, the malbec was solid but i really liked the bourgogne which was bold and smooth.
author: Anh V.

description: This is the BEST wine bar in SF! THe Soms are so knowledgeable and always know what I am in the mood for. It feels like I am sitting in my living room enjoying wine, it is SO cozy. The cheese plate is out of this world, always get the French Triple Cream :) It is a small space but that's what makes it so warm, it's the perfect place to go after a long day at work. It is a must for anyone who lives or is visiting SF.
author: Tara W.

description: Great European style ambiance. Brick walls harken back to the wine cellars and bars of old! A great selection of vinos, both red and white, and the cool Hayes Valley crowd make it a hit afterwork, before a show, or before you hit the sack!
author: Shelley T.

description: Great selection of wines by the glass - I loved the White Burgundy which is unusual to find even at a wine bar.  However the service was a bit odd, there was only 1 person waiting on the entire place and you had to walk up to the bar to place your order and retrieve your drinks.  We probably caught it on an off night.  Great place for a date - the lighting is perfect and comfy couches -cheese plate isn't bad but a little pricey.  Make sure to check out groupon.com for specials.
author: Mishel F.

description:
Love it, love it, love it! Once of my absolute favorite wine bars in SF. Reminds me of about six European cities but fortunately it's right here in SF. 

The owner is wonderful and really knows his wine. The cheese is fabulous and the wine selection is amazing.

Can't say enough good things about it!
author: Susan B.

description:
Super low-key and hidden; and it's 2 blocks from Destino (yum!) which makes a great dinner/drinks combo.

I love the art, and the generous pours, and the exposed brick.  And I have to say, the couch in the little back area is private, but with a good view to people-watch through the hall.

Very attentive staff, even came by to relight our candle, which was a sweet touch.

But really what gets this place 5 stars is the sweet, sincere homeless guy wandering outside-- he said good evening to me and my boyfriend, then told us we were a "real nice-looking couple."  Now why can't everywhere have a nice homeless guy like that?
author: Tracy D.

description:
Love it.  Great wine selection, fantastic interior, and I love the constantly rotating art collections.  Minus one notch for occasionally spotty service.

Grab a couch and enjoy.
author: Jesse H.

description:
Love the vibe (during the week).

The by-the-glass list could stand to be larger. I feel like I can drink my way through it in a couple of visits a little too easily and if it was a little cheaper I would.
author: Joe D.

description: This place is one of my favorite spots. It is kind of in a random spot, but I think that makes it all the more exciting. Great selection of South African wines which is sometimes hard to find. The atmosphere is cozy and intimate. The service is always excellent.
author: Cristina C.

description:
I came here the other night expecting great things.

The good:
o The place oozes industrial chic charm, and you feel like you've really found a secret oasis once you walk in.
o The meats and cheeses are varied and yummy, and come in large portions.

The bad:
o I'm no sommelier, so I  prefer when wine menus have short blurbs about each entry's features. 
o The acoustics in here are terrible. The music is too loud and even with small crowds you feel like you are in a baseball stadium. This is a shame since Hotel Biron would be incredibly romantic otherwise.
o When I was here, the were no waiters or waitresses. All orders were handled by a single bar back. To be fair, I didn't have to wait at all, but this could be a problem.

In summation: come here to impress someone with your knowledge of the city. Don't come here to have an important conversation.
author: Keith C.

description:
i've been here dozens of times but never bothered to review it before... this is really what a wine bar should really be like.  big selection of wines, many by the glass. funky furniture and cave-like appearance and architecture (probably unintentional).  unusual but not altogether bad, local art on the walls - rotated out often.  and lastly, difficult to find.

hotel biron is a name take from the Paris Rodin Museum.  the building has a long history that you can learn all about from wikipedia but apparently, it's been a private home, an artist's hotel, and when Rodin handed over a bunch of his work to the estate, it became his museum. of course, the san franciso version is not really a hotel, but it does suffer from having "hotel" in the name thus causing some confusion and thereby making it slightly difficult to tell your date that you're taking her to "hotel biron."... her first reaction is usually: "oh, we're going to a hotel?"  no, it's a wine bar.  anyway. 

the wines are excellent and the person pouring (the owner?) knows about as much as you could ask about any of the wines.  the food isn't bad but it's just light nibbles.  nothing of any substance since there really isn't any sort of kitchen on the premises.  it's fortunate that's it's surrounded by so many great restaurants: Paul K, Zuni, Absynthe, Espetus, plus all of hayes valley ... it's a great place to start before you make it to your dinner reservation and since it's open very late, it's also a good place to finish up for an after-dinner drinks.  mood is set nicely with the dimly lit comfortable surroundings and interesting art.
author: dan h.

description: Hotel Biron is sort of a neighborhood gem you want people to stop finding out about because it's so small and crammed already.  It's perfect during the week but a weekend visit can be too much.  Love the walls inside though and the little back room is comfy if you don't mind sitting near the bathrooms.  Great wine selection and I highly recommend ordering a cheese plate if you're hanging for a while.  Just don't tell too many people about it, ssshhh.....
author: Laura S.

description:
The selection of wine is enough to satisfy a wine newbie and the appetizers are wonderful but small portions. All in all, this is a great place if you live nearby or to bring a couple of your B&T friends and drink wine and discuss the problems of "life." 
Just remember that the chairs are somewhat high and uncomfortable, making the ambiance a lil' unsettling and unrelaxing. Other than that, the decor is great and the place is one that you will come again.
author: Manuel S.

description:
Great neighborhood bar in the neighborhood bar wasteland that is Hayes Valley.  The wine selection is excellent, the bar staff is knowledgable, and the atmosphere is chill and comfortable.  

The space is also an art gallery and the curator is fantastic.  The art is quirky and unexpected.

The only negative thing is that the place can get crowded on the weekends, but for a relaxed happy hour with friends on a tuesday or an intimate night with a hot date, Hotel B cannot be beat.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Loved this place.  Went here with my date for a few glasses of wine after dinner.  Wasn't sure what I wanted, but the bartender was great!  She poured me four different types of wine to try.  Great service!

The ambiance is perfect.  Dimly lit with candles at each table, with brick walls, along with comfortable couches and tables throughout the place.  The back room is cozy too.

The art on the walls was interesting!  Loved it!  I heard from someone last night that this place is an art gallery!  

IMO, this place is perfect for a date night going very well:)
author: Kat M.

description:
It makes me feel like I'm in the bat cave.  Bat man will come out in lounge gear and take a few sips from my glass, then sleep away into the night on Rose. 

Great place, low key, no drama...

They even dim the lights per request for those special nights.  :)
author: Mayah C.

description:
this place is exactly what I want on many a night.  a nice glass (or bottle) of not-too-expensive wine, some cheese, some fruit, and a little coziness.  If you get a couch, you have majorly scored and really have all this place has to offer.  they used to have these amazing handmade chocolates, not sure what happened to them, that made me realize how fantastically red wine and chocolate go together.

for any occasion/social gathering this place works.  first date. check.  out with an ex. check.  with some friends. check. out with your main squeeze.  definitely check (then you especially need the couch though).
author: Amanda S.

description: This place is a cool place to go to if you are looking to consume wine, beer, and cheese.  The atmosphere is small, dark, and cozy, with the noise level at a perfect volume, allowing for a conversation to take place.  You walk up to the bar to order and there usually is never a wait.  The wine selection is decent and the prices are affordable.  Check it out!
author: Carolyn D.

description:
When you take the back alley entry way onto Rose Street, the Bold B hits you like a shotgun of authenticity. There is something well thought out about the decor and location that makes me want to go there at any time of day and have a secular beat poet experience with a glass of wine.

As a group spot, it may be a bit tight if it's already crowded, but this is a perfect spot to go for couples or with a good friend who loves pretending to be a sommelier. Hotel Biron provides an experience deep in the city that makes you forget that this is the city.
author: Mario G.

description: I really like the atmosphere here. It's dark, hidden but cozy. Perfect for a date night. They have a decent selection of wine. And even though they don't offer the tasting size or a flight, you can ask to taste the wine before you buy a full glass. The art on the wall gives the place a character. They play pretty good music here too. The only thing I would complain about is that it's way too packed on the weekend.
author: P. L.

description:
Great find. Interesting and tasty selection of wines from California, France, Italy, Argentina/Chile and Australia. Very good and unusual cheese selection, and other nibblies.  They have quince paste - which is yummy and unusual. Tons of funky comfy ambiance. A terrific date place.
The prices are not cheap - most of the wines are in the $12-15 a glass range, and the cheese and salame selections are $6/for each small serving.  But... I will definitely be going again - often.
author: Nick C.

description: Absolutely adorable, tucked into an alley and hard to notice so it has that speakeasy feel.  I ordered a random champagne off the menu and liked it so much I had another.  We got a compliment of cheese and bread to go with our wines and for the second round my date asked for a complimentary cheese to go with my champagne.  It was a fabulous recommendation that we both agreed was perfect.  The acoustics were off, everyone sounded really loud so we didn't get that quiet intimate date vibe but more of a comfortable sitting place with your friends vibe.
author: Loralyn S.

description: Descend the small staircase into this netherworld of wine and cheese bliss! Forget really where you are, and just realize it ultimately doesn't matter as long as you're well fed and watered. THAT will doubtless be the case in this great little Hayes Valley find!
author: Lorna M.

description: Talk about being hidden right out in the open! Okay, it's on a random alley, but is only a stone's throw from some of the busiest streets in the City. Entering Hotel Biron (oh, and it's not pronounced 'Byron' -- it's like burr-own), you feel as though you've just stumbled onto some meeting of a secret, cave-dwelling society -- but one with a penchant for cozy furniture, good vino (including sparkles), nibbles, and an exuberant staff. I get such a thrill bringing people here because you can see it in their eyes when they can't wait to bring someone else there and pretend THEY discovered it.
author: Gregor G.

description: Last night was probably my 5th time at HB, and I am still in love. By far the best wine bar in SF because of it's subtle design, kick ass list, and super smart staff. The vibe is relaxed but its obvious the concept behind Biron was executed in a serious way by a true wine enthusiast. Note the well chosen lighting, furniture, and menu elements that tie it all together. The alley location is also a secret obsession of mine because it seems the crowd must have chosen to be there, not just stumbled upon during some sort of crude marina pub crawl. Guys, this would be a great date spot to impress, elegant yet understated. Perfection.
author: Kylie S.

description: Especially good when it's freezing, like it is now, in this bleary San Francisco August. Time and time again, they put time, thought, and skill into their wine selections, so A+ for consistency and quality over the years.
author: Tara R.

description:
hotel biron is not a hotel.  it might be a biron, if i knew what a biron was.  but aptly named or not this little wine bar is a great place for a romantic moment, or just a quiet drink with friends.

i'm not exactly sure how one would find this place if they didn't know exactly what they were looking for.  tucked in a sketchy alley off market, and across the street from a parking lot, its not a place you would happen upon. 

its a small place, and oddly shaped, gives it odd private nooks which lends a sense of privacy.  all you red brick fetishists will love the walls here.  because of its out of the way location, i doubt it is ever crowded.

oh, and the wine was good too.
author: Steve S.

description: At first glance, this place is a dump. Mismatched chairs, dark lighting, and a small space all combined look like someone's unfinished basement. But it grows on you. Service is friendly! Wine is delicious and the cheese is pretty tasty. Don't do the olives, not worthwhile. Get there early if you'd like to really converse with someone as once it gets busier it's pretty noisy.
author: C T.

description: They had me with the NYC MTA like B sign on the outside.  A great place to polish off a bottle of wine in under 60 minutes (that's just how I roll, okay?) & eat some stinky cheese.  Exposed brick is always sexy. Even the homeless guy that was hanging outside was charming. A winner.
author: Maria D.

description:
As I was driving past Hotel Biron this morning, I started thinking about my last visit.  More specifically, my last visit versus my first visit.  
The first time I wandered into this lovely hidden gem was on a dark fall night with some friends.  I loved how moody and European it felt - I have a major crush on exposed brick walls and this place had them in spades.  The fact that I can drink wine to my heart's content was a definite bonus.  Little nooks and secluded corners for more romantic encounters, and larger tables and more open areas for chatting with others.  I was smitten and vowed to become a regular.
Fast forward to ages later when I finally made it back in.  It's now for a late spring happy hour and I've gotta say, I was nowhere near as twitterpated as I was on my first visit.  Maybe it's the daylight.  Maybe they covered up some of the brick with plaster, and the plaster was all chippy and nicked.  Maybe the new seating isn't as comfy as the couches I seem to remember.  Maybe it was the weird smell or the fact that I didn't love my wine.  I can't be sure but whatever it was, it knocked a star off my initial impression.
I still have a soft spot for the space and I tend to love the artwork they have on display, so I'll definitely be back - I think I'll just wait until it's dark enough to gloss over some of the flaws and put me in a more forgiving mood.  Mood lighting isn't just for making your dates look better kids!
author: Jennifer D.

description: Biron is tucked away on the alley behind Cafe Zuni, which makes it a great spot before or after dinner. The place doubles as an art gallery and they the artwork changes about every month. I always ask for a good wine or beer recommendation when I stop in - the staff is great about recommending something special.
author: Nish N.

description:
Normally I'd say when your date takes you into a dark alley in a seedy part of town you should run away. Yet the superb Hotel Biron is hidden away in such an unlikely place and you'd probably pass it by if someone didn't point it out. The wine bar is literally in an alley not too far from Market. I'd expected a place akin to the questionable surrounding establishments, but it's quite a contrast to what's outside.

The low lights, candlelit tables and exposed brick give the venue a bit of a cave-like feel. There are spots for groups to lounge and small tables for two people. It's a cozy place with a relaxed feel. It's neither too yuppie nor hippy, and the vibe from the nearby Hayes Valley crowd comes through. Despite being a small place it didn't get too loud or crazy. This is certainly one of the best wine bars I've been to in the city. The wine is good too, but I was so enamored with the setting I forgot about the wine after my second or third glass.
author: Junius G.

description:
I feel obligated to write a review when I read other reviews that make no sense. I love the location because it adds a little mystery and is totally safe. Zuni Cafe is half a block away and there are usually valet parking guys hanging outside which deters any knuckleheads. 
The art is on the wall because where else would it go!? Say hello to the person sitting under it if it makes you uncomfortable getting so close.
The only funky smell ever encountered was the cheese plate I ordered. 
The regular guy pouring wine is a nice guy and has generously poured a different wine when I thought mine might be cooked and not a pompous hipster like the guy at the biodynamic over priced place on Folsom. 
The only downside of Hotel B are the prices. Even in SF ,  wine bars should offer a glass of wine under $10. Plenty of good wines out there that can cover the margins in the $7-8 range. 
The other is that the space does not absorb sound, so when it's busy , it's loud. I'd give them 5 stars if they offered a glass for under $10.
author: Jamie C.

description: One of the older wine bars in SF and definitely my favorite.  The staff is always willing to suggest a wine and the cheese plate surprisingly good.  Want to impress on a first date?  Take 'em to Hotel Biron!
author: phil h.

description:
sometimes it's a fair trade to pay a big markup on wine to have it in a nice glass in a hidden back-alley bar surrounded by expensive art.  they'd get 5 stars if they had a better selection (it doesn't seem to change that frequently).  this place makes me want to move out of the mission.

Update (12/7/2007): They tacked on a few dollars to my credit card bill (yeah, I actually cross check these things).  Kind of annoying.
author: Neha N.

description: Cozy little spot. Great for having intimate conversations.
author: Marissa A.

description:
So occasionally I'm kind of lazy.
I know it's a shocker to you all but it's true!
This is a good bar to be lazy in.  I know a lot about wine but I just didn't feel like analyzing the ample selection here and just asked for recommendations.  The helpful and friendly bartenderess gave great suggestions and my companion and I enjoyed a few glasses of red and a few glasses of bubbly while catching up with one another.  The atmosphere is casual, dimly lit and can be rather loud as it is conducive to chatting.  The seating is comfy but the footing is a little uneven so mind how much you drink if you can't pull off a good drunken stumble maneuver.  Despite there being only one bathroom that's unisex I never waited in line the three times I used it (hey I drank a huge bottle of water before going!).  It may not be as nice as going to wine country itself and doing your own tasting but it's close enough to make me happy.
I'd have no problem coming back here and being lazy again!
author: Jill D.

description:
love it.  tucked away european artsy winey foodie fun.
especially with the man in the back vip makeout room  

;)
author: Kimby T.

description: Great atmosphere, small and off the beaten path. The cheese plate was spectacular from what I can remember.
author: Tim H.

description: I've been here a few times. As another reviewer said, the place is dark, cavernous, and sexy. Cool art for sale on the walls. They have a fairly big selection of yummy, not too pricey wine. Excellent glassware. Bar service only. And the bad thing about cavernous is that the low ceiling makes it get uncomfortably warm... and as a result, the red wines (sitting upright on a shelf behind the bar) are usually served at this mid-70s room temperature, which is about 20 degrees too warm for red wine.  Still, it is a nice place to relax and enjoy a glass of wine with a friend or two after work.  On weekends, it's a complete zoo, however... hard to find a place to sit, so loud that you can't have a conversation, and sweltering hot.
author: Michael C.

description: Wine bars are en vogue right now, but this hidden little side pocket-sized one is unique to me in that it probably has the most gritty, urban New Yorky feel to it of any food and drink venue I've been to in the City. Its tucked down the side of an alley across the street from a huge construction hole, and squeezed into a narrow slot between two large apartment tenements.  Rain leaders and wires are strewn about the building's facade, there are trash cans and dumpsters laying around, and the little alley is dirty.  Inside it is amusingly narrow with exposed brick walls and little candles on all the wobbly tin tables.  A tiny 4-stool bar sits in the middle of the space, and there is a more private back room with a small couch.  Nice selection of wines and the bartender is helpful in making selections.
author: Rick H.

description: Delicious wines, a cool atmosphere, and what's not to like about fromage?   A good place for a pre-dinner bottle of champagne, too.
author: Laurel B.

description: Now this dark, cavernous little spot is easily missed unless you go down the alleyway behind Zuni Cafe and see that large size awning with a "B". Walk in. You're in a a modern day speakeasy. The wine list is extensive and from all over the world. Their selection is one of the more creative and interesting in all of the City. They do have some things to eat such as cheeses and other small plates that can all be ordered at the wine bar. Then you can sit down and enjoy the ambiance of this wonderful little spot. I found myself honing in on a Siduri Pinot Noir so stopped there. But I could easily have found my way to a fine Austrailian Pinot or South African Pinotage. I have been there but once, but I promise you, I WILL be back. I highly recommend it as a spot to bring friends from out of town as it is definitely not on the usual 'to see' spots in SF, at least not yet.
author: daniel k.

description: First time I walked in here I was ready to walk back out - then something kind of transfixed me. It was that smell of wine from European cellars. A favourite spot - the platter of almonds, dates, apple and cheese - the range of quirky seating arrangements - the closed in zinc bar - the huge range of bottles open and ready for a glass. Sure there are some drawbacks - a corked wine from time to time, the art exhibition that seems more trash than class, the overbearing din when the place is packed. But it all seems to hang together. But there is something of a celebration of wine about the place, coupled with the enthusiasm for wine that you sense from the staff. The wine list is just superb. An exhibition that states "bacchus drowns more than neptune" didn't take me where I expected - the bassins of Versailles. With that I have added a shot of the "bassin de bacchus" - which indicates the spirit of this lovely little wine bar.
author: Vera N.

description: A good glass if wine willl do me just fine, and I can easily find that at Hotel Biron.  With knowledgable bartenders, delicious cheese and fruit when you get the muchies, and always interesting, sometimes daring art to strike up a conversation, you couldn't have a better solution to unwind from a long long day.
author: Gemma P.

description: This place has a great a selection of wine and art, it is a dark cozy spot. It's kind of pricey but you get what you pay for, and the staff is knowledgable and fun.
author: JIll H.

description: I would take that new guy I'm dating here on our 4th date, after he hasn't kissed me yet, and I'm thinking what the heck is going on?  Maybe Biron can work its magic and help the situation.  If not, I'll bring my secret affair who'll know how to appreciate the surroundings.
author: Yasmine G.

description: Hmmmm.....a small wine bar tucked away in an alley behind Zuni. The smell of cigarettes wafting in from the street.  French wines (and some Californian ones too). Wondrously stinky cheeses. Exposed brick interior. If it wasn't for the San Francisco natives adorning the couch and chairs, I could pretend that I was actually in Paris. And lovin' it.
author: Suepattra M.

description:
this is the best wine bar in SF, hands down. nice people, no pretension. the wine selection is wonderful and they know their shit without making you feel like you're a complete asshole if you just like to drink wine and get a little drunk. i really appreciate that. they also know their cheese. every single cheese i have tried here has been amazing.
