the space is quaint and intimate, with art installations and mellow music. it is tiny, but if you get there early you can get a table or a couch and have it all night. and i think the size just adds to the charm. you do feel like you're all cozied up in a hidden corner of SF. 

the service is friendly and fair. normal people own this place. the guy actually works behind the bar and is really nice. and the crowd is always good. i think that's the great thing about having garbage dumpsters right outside the door. you weed out a lot of the doubtful types.
author: rachel p.

description: What a lovely, lovely place. Great selection of wines and cheeses; friendly, knowledgeable staff; and a laid-back atmosphere. (Well, except for the table of loud Marina girls next to us.) Great date destination.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
Quite the hidden gem!  And believe you me, it's hidden.  Wandering the main streets of SF you would likely miss out on this little diamond.

The vibe is industrial chic yet warm and cozy.  Brick walls, ever changing art, tables, and big comfy leather couches.

The wine list has wines from around the world.  I would suggest buying a bottle, you will have a greater selection versus wines by the glass.  To compliment your wine get some cheese, fruits, or meats.

Now that you've got your spread, it's onto the 5 S's... See, Swirl, Sniff, Sip, Savor.
author: Ashley Q.

description: A great spot to meet a friend or two for a drink or two. Pretty small / limited seating though, so I would avoid going with more than 3 people. I have had a great experience every time I've gone, and find the staff to be helpful and friendly in helping with wine selection.
author: Tadeek P.

description: The other reviewers are spot-on.  Love the dimly lit interior with the brick walls and bistro tables.  The cheese really IS great and bartender is totally approachable and has recommended some wonderful wines.  It is spendy, but hey, its worth it!
author: Kyla B.

description: Uber cool wine lounge with a very intimate ambiance.  This is a great date place.  The cheese platter ain't bad either.
author: Amber L.

description:
I am a sad and disgraceful wino and take it from me, Biron is the best wine bar in the city. I was first introduced to Hotel Biron by Laura V., who shares my love of establishments that provide really great wineglasses. She also shares my philosophy that wines by the glass are reserved exclusively for those drinking alone. Why have a glass when you can have a bottle? As a child of the 80's, I'm a sucker for exposed brick and as a resident of San Francisco, a lover of the readily available parking space. And as a blatant snob who loathes this trait in others, the staff is friendly and funny, having no problem with our ordering $30 bottles of wine and taking up a leather couch for the sole purpose of batting our eyelashes at anyone remotely attractive in candlelight. 
In closing, I have always, always, always had a great experience at Biron and will most likely be found here at midnight on Friday...
author: Beth S.

description: I have visited Hotel Biron a number of times. It is a really great bar that deserves 5 stars! It is a bit hidden - entrance is in an alley - which makes it even nicer and quieter. Great date place. The wine selection is top notch and being constantly updated. Chris knows his wines.
author: Adele P.

description:
This place has a very European vibe, the exposed brick walls and dimmed lighting in this cavernous place make you feel you are someplace in Prague or Warsaw or something.  

I have consistently enjoyed their wine, their cheese, the art on the walls and the long conversations had on their couches.
author: Localista I.

description: Personally, one of my favorites bars in the city.  Cool art on the walls. Dark moody lighting. Big comfy couches. Tons of wine and excellent cheese.  Seriously, what gets any better than that?
author: Homechicken P.

description: I love this place (we went here on our first date...so I might be somewhat biased). Great wine and they let you taste a lot before deciding and don't just shove the expensive ones on you. The cheese plate came with more bread than you can shake a stick at which is good given all the wine. I also like getting to choose from a long list of cheeses. They have some great wines. It can be a bit crowded, but it's an excellent pre-dinner stop. Is it cheap? Of course not, but you weren't expecting that, were you?
author: Brian B.

description: The very definition of hip. Hidden away on a tiny side-street with little more than a red "B" to identify itself, Hotel Biron continues to draw a crowd with its fascinating international wine list and utilitarian, almost Eastern European, decor. I love that the wine list is organized by country rather than varietal because it really changes the way you think about ordering wine. While the food menu consists solely of an a la carte cheese plate, you will not be disappointed with the artfully arranged and generously portioned platter of cheeses, fruit and baguette. Service could be a bit friendlier, but it doesn't merit dinging Hotel Biron a star because a smiley-faced sommelier would so NOT belong in this place.
author: Heather F.

description: Mmm. Fantastic. I don't go here often, because it's somewhat spendy and not an atmosphere I want every night. But I love coming here late, after a nice Zuni dinner, and learning about wine from Chris, the nice man behid the counter. And something about the smell of the place reminds me of being in an alley in Paris, which is never a bad thing.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
Hotel Biron is a cute place that has a great vibe. I would recommend this for a place to hang out with a few friends or even a place to check out on a date. The space is on the small-side so wouldn't recommend as a venue to throw a party but a cool place to recommend if you're looking for a trendy yet low-key venue. 
The wine selection is decent; however I don't get the feeling that they want to help you select a good wine; especially if its busy. I was hoping someone would allow me to try a few options before getting a glass.
author: N S.

description: I'm not a huge wine lover but according to the great reviews this seemed like a good place for a first date. I went on a Friday at 6:30 and it went from moderately busy to pretty full in the span of an hour so for a more quiet time I recommend a slower night. I ordered a Riesling and it was only so so for $10 - the cheese plate was better deal at $5. It wasn't until I got home that I realized I was shortchanged by $5 - either that or I left a $5 tip (instead of $1) for my glass of wine. I'm not exactly cheap but I never intentionally tip that high on a drink unless it's called a Blow Job because it comes with an actual blow job. The highlight of the night was that my date looked and sounded uncannily like Marisa Tomei and that's pretty hot. It would have been a 4 star evening had I got into her pants.
author: Colin S.

description: I love this place for the wine and ambiance. Good prices for bottles. I've been there a few times on dates and with friends and always noticed the service was just okay. This last Sunday night (1/11/08) I went there with on a date and he ordered some cheeses to have with the bottle of wine. The server behind the bar was rude. She actually started arguing with my friend. I was embarrassed because I spoke so highly of this place. I have worked in the service industry and know the golden rule#1 that the customer is always right. Rule #2- refer to Rule#1, right?  Perhaps the bartender/server should re-learn this.
author: Olivia R.

description: I went here on a first date with my last boyfriend and it turned into a few years of good red wine... and whining!  (But seriously, folks...)  A full bottle of their offerings may lead you to the couch in the back room.  Be careful that it's not just the alcohol kicking in when your date turns into a dreamboat and says everything that you ever wanted to hear.  The cheese and meat selections are great, salty sidekicks to their offerings, and the funkyfresh art on the walls lets your wandering eyes go free.  Be brave, be free, Biron!
author: Shelley T.

description: Cozy atmosphere in a little alley by Gough.  Love the brick walls and the art on the wall.  Yummy cheese and fruit pairing.  Really knowledgeable people working there, they'll answer any questions you have and even tell you if you shouldn't get a certain kind of wine.  Went on a weekend and got seats pretty quickly.  I love the fact that its not super crowded.  Plus, we met some wine industry people.
author: Amelia S.

description: Dark, secret, low key, mellow wine bar. great selection of wine and people that know what they are talking about. Good for small groups or a cute date - cheese plate is delish!
author: Jordan V.

description: This is an incredible little hipster wine bar, without the self righteous attitude found in most spots with the hipster stamp.  I've been here for numerous bottles of wine with guest lists ranging from 2 to 12.  I hosted a surprise party here a few months ago and while reservations aren't available (which is fine with me as it would most likely always be booked), our gang was able to snag the intimate, yet very warm, backroom on a Friday night - but we did have to arrive early, as the place absolutely fills up.  Fabulous cheese plates, an amazing selection of bottles in the $20 range, dim lighting and a wide range of eye candy.
author: Kati S.

description: I love places like these. Very tucked away and unlikely to be spotted amongst the construction and dumpsters and loonies and other fixtures of a big city. Had drinks here with Sav B and we were intrigued by the presence of sake on the list, so we each had a chilled glass (can't remember the name though). Sav also had a unfiltered sake that tasted very good. I don't know much about wine but I'd like to try something on that huge list. I like the layout, furniture, ambiance, and the cozy bar, definitely a romantic date spot. But since it's so small it can get loud when it's crowded. Oh the art on display at the moment is ugly and way too small for the space. Please put something else up there.
author: Linda L.

description: Love this hidden little treasure. Decent wine menu and tasty nibbles, although it would be great if they had a wider selection by the glass. Great place to hang with a date or meet small group of friends. It gets toasty when packed, so prepare to strip down the layers.
author: Dani D.

description: This place can get pretty packed--and with good reason. The wine list is excellent and atmosphere hip but laid back. If you have an idea of what you want, but aren't sure to order, ask the owner/bartender. You will be delighted by whatever he pours for you.
author: Leigh M.

description: Not sure how my friend who had just moved here from CHICAGO knew about this place, and I, after being here 6 years had never heard of it, but she introduced it to me and i was so glad. Small, intimate, "european" feeling, good wine selection, small food plates to pare it up with, and it's NOT a hotel in spite of the name. Parking isn't too bad, either if you just loop around the block once or twice. Definitely check to see what time they open though before deciding to head in for a glass. If I recall correctly, they may not open when you'd expect them to... but do love this place. adorable little room in back if you're lucky enough to be the small group who gets to hang out there.
author: beth l.

description: Great wine bar.  One of the most romantic places in the city.  Amazing selection, and some really good cheeses.  The server is very knowledgable, and they usually have some interesting art on the walls.
author: Liz C.

description: Getting a drink can be a pain, but that doesn't significantly detract from everything else they've done right.  Come here, not Cav around the corner (or, don't; easier for me to get a drink).
author: Jenn S.

description: Absolutely love this place!! The most wonderful selection of delicious wines from around the world. The owner is awesome and lets you taste until you find the one that suits you ( for a man with a very discerning palate it is a huge plus.)  I've frequented all the wine bars San Francisco has to offer and I confidently say nothing holds a light to this place
author: michael L.

description: Cramped. Expensive wines by the glass. OK for one or two people. Wines themselves were good.
author: Justin C.

description: Hotel Biron, it was quite the mystery to me-it's very well hidden which made it all the more intriguing.  And with Zuni Cafe just down the way what's not to love?  This place feels like something out of an old movie-it's so dark inside and the main source of light comes from candles-which makes having a glass of wine even more relaxing.  There is also a very wide selection of wines to choose from to please a variety of palates.  Surrounded by art work, people tucked into tables and corners, and a very late night feel (even in the middle of the day)-this place brought nothing but good feelings!
author: Steven K.

description: Cute space, super tiny, very hidden away.  Huge wine selection as can be expected and delicious cheeses as well.  The only thing I disliked is how crowded it was the night I stopped in, making seating for a group of about 8 kind of difficult.
author: Melinda C.

description:
wine her, dine her and ... ah well! rest is up to you:) But for the wining part let me recommend hotel biron:) The place is a hidden gem. the ambiance is cozy and the air is mischievous. You can go with friends and be loud around a table or take a date and be invisible in one of the purposefully lit corners and whisper all night. 
if you do end up going there, be sure to order the ruby port.. mmmm.
author: Nabil B.

description: This is probably one of my favorite wine bars in the City! It's close to my house and walking distance (far walk but walking distance none-the-less!) It's off the beaten path and down a side alley so its nice and private. The ambiance is really nice, the people are nice and knowledgeable, and it has a certain feeling of relaxing comfort. I like how they swap out artwork on the walls and support local talent. And they have a really good cheese plate too! A must try!
author: Carol B.

description: Love this place -- although it's a bit on the small side.  Great selection of wines in the center of the city.  Friendly staff who don't charge you for a "taste."
author: Alex C.

description:
perfect. i could see why people wouldn't want anyone to know about it.
it's got more style than most places in sf:
quaint size, dim lighting, great local artists' (better than most galleries i've been to), nicest bartender, cute crowd, wine and cheese you dream about, reasonably priced, the greatest alley in town, and a nice selection of loungy music.
dig it
author: kirsten k.

description: I love this place!  Great wine, a great atmosphere and I'm sooo happy that this place is in my neighborhood.  Have been to several wine bars in the city now and this is easily my favorite.  The only thing that I might be able to complain about is that it has the potential to become a little bit sceney and pretentious at times.  That is easy enough to ignore because the place is so damn cool though.
author: doug s.

description: Fantastic place to visit midweek. This was my favorite and primary lounging spot when it first opened years ago. Although it's undergone a number of changes, the heart of the place is still in tact. Nice gnoshing dishes, fabulous wine, beer and random beverage list, beautiful art in an amazing little space.
author: Tanya P.

description: This was a lovely place for a small group of gals to gather for a birthday.  Charming decor, great mix of music and a delish wine menu.  Suggestion: order by the bottle as it makes a ton of economic sense (duh) and more fun to share.  Also fun that its in such a tucked away place near busy Market Street.
author: Britta D.

description: Good wine. Cozy. Quiet. Hidden. Bring along companions who are scintillating conversationalists because there's little to do but sip and talk.
author: Faye S.

description: A year ago I wouldn't have written a review of this wine bar hidden behind the Zuni Caf.  It was still a quiet little wine bar with a large, varied selection.  And I didn't want too many people to know about it!  Ok ok, before I get all uppity (and decide I don't like it anymore because it got popular), this place is certainly bumpin' most of the time now, so I guess the secret is out ;)   Their wines by the glass are not cheap, but there is a really good selection.  Plus the bartender can always offer you a recommendation if you're stumped.  I love the atmosphere here, and they always have plenty of interesting artwork hanging on the exposed brick walls.  They also offer "build your own" cheese plates with consistently solid cheese offerings.  It's also a great place to impress your date!
author: Leslie R.

description: Great initimate wine bar located in a dark alley.  They have a long extensive wine list that begins at about $9 a glass. The decor reminds me of some of the underground bars in Italy. Great place for dates.
author: Kat F.

description: let's see, i love cheese & i adore wine more than my first born...if & when I decide i can be without wine for 9 months.   The fact that you can create your own little plates of delish cheese, fruit, salami, olives and most importantly membrillo to pair up with their fabulous manchego is such a great idea.    When i don't know what i want suggestions are graciously offered as well as a a taste.  I've never met a wine here that i didn't like.  BONUS ROUND: i come out with knowledge of some new band every single time.
author: Liz V.

description: My friends and i were exploring Hayes Valley one night many months ago and we happened to stumble upon this cool little spot tucked away behind Zuni cafe. Very cozy, very cool atmosphere with exposed brick walls. This place is great, totally perfect for a mellow night out w/ a friend or two.
author: Meredith M.

description: Great wine bar!  Tucked away where you wouldn't see it without knowing, uncrowded (at least when we were there on a holiday evening), great atmosphere.  We had comfy seating, and it wasn't real loud, so we were actually able to hear each other talk.  Had a great bottle of Malbec, and some wines by the glass.  Really enjoyable time.
author: Chris B.

description: Wine and cheese, yes please. I love this place. It's got a great atmosphere, wine and cheese list, and it's often got cool art on the walls.
author: Christina S.

description: After a wonderful evening of ballet the other night, I was in the mood for a good glass of wine, and Hotel Biron seemed to be the perfect place to go. I've hit just about every other wine bar in the city, so why not try the one everyone holds so dear? Well, apparently, the entire city (I even ran into one of my buiding-mates with an ex-building mate) was in the same mood I was in Saturday, and while we pushed and shoved our way to the bar, there was just no way we were going to be able to do wine and cheese while balancing on one leg and leaning against a pillar amid all the other wine drinkers. After some hemming and hawing, we went next door (yet the entrance is on Market) to Cav where we were seated (no shoving here) quickly and drank to our hearts' content. Next time, we'll plan to try Hotel Biron, but earlier in the evening.
author: Bee H.

description: A friend introduced me to this tucked-away spot. As we were walking up, I was skeptical do to the discrete location. Once inside, I was awed with the romantic mood. The dim lighting, cozy couches, and impressive selection of wine surely make a great spot for a date. Unfortunately, the comfortable atmosphere got me into some paparazzi-style trouble... but let's not get into that.
author: Rada I.

description: Very nice place.  A little hard to find (kind of in an alley), but this sort of adds an "exclusive vibe."  The wine selection is very nice and very thorough and the owner, Chris, is a very cool guy to hang out and talk with.  Ask for the Chilean Carmamere (green chilles like crazy...)
author: Joe R.

description: One of my favorite places in the City, period. Wine, chacuterie, cheese, belgian ales, good conversation. Can one ask for more?
author: D. R.

description: Went to Hotel Biron last night on a first date. Great place for such a thing. We started out at the bar, and later got cozy on the couch. Shared a lush bottle of Syrah, then switched to a lighter French white. No table service, but not a prob getting service from the bar. More than anything, this wine bar has really nice ambiance. An intimate place to get to know someone a little bit better...
author: chloe r.

description: Small, unassuming wine bar. The ambiance was superb, the right amount of candles, dim lighting, comfy seating and appropriate music all complemented by a selection of art on the walls. The prices for a glass were on the high end, cheapest was $8, with most around $10 - $12. They also have a diverse selection of beer. Overall a nice experience.
author: Jason B.

description:
oh biron... why aren't you a hotel.  You have all the makings for a hotel?
great service, great cheese and wine, great lighting, great couch,
i guess it's just the hours that don't work huh.  i wonder if I hid behind the couch if you would ever find me?
author: meg d.

description:
perfect place. my favorite of San Francisco.

great selection and the atmosphere always lure me to end up here. I always have the best nights here. everytime. (oh, well, except one :-)

this place rocks. if I opened up a wine bar, it would be an almost exact replica of Hotel Biron. (maybe mine would have a little garden in the back) A super-saver option to jetting to Barcelona or Berlin.
author: Howard C.

description: One of the best selections of other world wines in the city.  They get it!  Most people try new foods but rarely venture out side the "box" with wine, but these folks make it fun. Always fun art work that can start and end a conversation as the last of the Primotivo goes down.
author: t b.

description: Went there for the first time last night.  It was nice but hard to see anything it was so dark.  Also the staff was so busy they never replaced a few silverware pieces we'd asked for.  The compte cheese was so-so and stay away from the pate' - not good.  The bartender was pretty cool and easy going.  Over all it was a so so.
author: Jacque P.

description:
Hotel Biron has a few things going for it the least of which is the wine. Their selection is by and large comprised of close outs which they purchase wholesale for low prices: hence the one star. A wine bar must sell wines that are good and also available for later purchase. 

The decor of Biron can be a positive or negative depending upon how you look at it... It definately has a hole in the wall quality to it but it is this same quality that can also make it attractive to many people. The exposed red brick is nice looking but as others have mentioned the chairs are not the most comfortable. The cheese portions there are very generous and unlike most places where you get 4 tiny pieces of bread to serve up 4-5 ounces of cheese Hotel Biron delivers. There is a strange smell that permeates the place as others have noted but this is new within the last year. I have not been back to Biron for more than a drop in since their neighbor had a fire last year and we were all forced to leave which was ok because as much as i want to like Biron it is too loud and uncomfortable to have a conversation with somebody.
author: Jamie b.

description:
There seems to be a lot of reviews here at Yelp that talk about what crowd is present at a particular place.  Sometimes, the people are too pretentious for others, sometimes to hipster, sometimes too old, sometimes too young.  I gotta tell you, I go to Hotel Biron, have some good wine and cheese with my lady, and I really don't give a goshdarn too much about the people around me. I quit caring about the other cliques after high school.  Actually, I'm lying.  I didn't care then either.

Listen, I don't know anything about crowds and all that.  Here's what I know about: wine. They do a good job.  It's not the best, (think Hayes and Vine from a couple years back), but they do very well.  First Crush has some great flights and small plates, and I like that, but the decor and variety in Biron's wine list is better.  Hotel Biron does a great job of finding eclectic wines from all over the world.  Well, most of the world.  I'm still waiting for a wine list with some Middle Eastern varietals to shake things up.  Some of these places go a little too safe.  Hotel Biron has some good cheese plates, with ample portions for a more than fair price.  Go, drink wine, eat cheese, enjoy the decor, and quit caring about who else is in there with you.  Unless, of course, you're into that sort of thing.
author: James P.

description: Owner/sommelier/bartender Chris is a super-nice guy who brings a little extra something to an already cool, intimate spot where wine and art mix nicely. Down the street from Linc Art gallery and Zuni Cafe, Rose Alley has more hipness in a block than some SF neighborhoods have in a square mile.
author: Andrew S.

description: very chill, unassuming spot.  We thought there was a good range of bottles with a reasonable markup.  nice cheese selection as well to compliment it.  will definitely return!
author: Nat K.

description:
hotel biron is my absolute favorite wine bar in the city.  it's tiny but has never felt overly crowded.  it's extremely centrally located (right off of market and gough, sort of behind zuni), but feels hidden away.  it always has interesting art on the walls.  it's perfectly dimly lit without being too dark.  

and of course, it's a wine bar, so it has a great great selection of interesting choices.  the owner is extremely nice, approachable, and helpful.  while they don't do flights, which would be a fun way to try a lot of new wines with falling off your bar stool by the end of the night, they do pour half glasses.  share with a friend and try four half glasses for not too much money.  

they also have a very limited selection of cheeses and other snacky choices.  everything that i have tried was excellent.  

check hotel biron out.  but don't tell too many people, because we don't want it to get overcrowded, right?
author: Kirsten F.

description: A sexy, low-key 2nd date venue. Almost like it was stolen from a movie. The wines and snacks are good enough to enjoy, and help you enjoy the company even more.
author: Rene D.

description: I think it's the best wine bar in the city. The selection is top-notch, but, yes, pricey. They got good stuff. They should charge more than retail. The snacks are extra yummy, the music downbeat and low volume, the lighting is soothing, what's not to love?
author: patrick g.

description: Small and very stylish wine bar with wonderful selection of wines and cheeses. The bartender is very friendly and helpful, and he always gives great suggestions! Love the interior, the space is small, but there is plenty of places to sit down. Definitely go there if you like good wine!
author: Maryna Y.

description: Exposed brick, gooey stinky cheese, comfy couches!  What more could a girl ask for from a wine bar.  Oh good wine, yes they have that too!
author: Brye L.

description: I came here on a first date and although I liked the place, it is a bit loud. We wound up sitting in the back of the bar which was much quieter but lacking in atmosphere. We picked a couple apps to accompany our wine and they were out of both of them AND the wine I wanted. YIKES. Luckily they made up for it with flying colors by making a delicious cheese plate (who knew blue cheese and honey is such a good combo?) and suggesting an awesome wine. While I enjoyed my visit I'd be more inclined to discover a new wine bar than revisit this one...
author: chelsea b.

description: I've added last night's bartender to my list of cute cheese boys in the Bay Area. And he's high on my list of the The Cheese Knowledgeable, as he told me about a triple cream brie from Tasmania (ohmigawd?!?!) and served me a trio of cheeses, none of which I'd tried before. Let me tell you, that is a rare feat. And I'm a fan of any place that offers quince paste and pears as sides. As far as I'm concerned, rose champagne + art + cheese = a pretty good Thursday night.
author: Autumn W.

description: I was going to say this place is a "hidden gem", but being that two hundred and so people have reviewed it, it's apparently more well known than I thought.  You'd never know by going here, as every time I've been the crowd has been just perfect.  It's not that big of a place to begin with, so I'm sure on the weekends it has the potential to get a bit crowded.  The first time I came here was on a first date and although my date turned out to be a bust, I do thank him for introducing me to this great wine bar.  The wine list is fab, as are the cheese plates.  The servers are very knowledgeable and helpful.  It's a good place to go to for a chill night.
author: Michelle L.

description: GOD DAMN THAT CHEESE IS GOOD! WINES NOT HALF BAD EITHER! like the dark mystious ambiance..good spot to spend your recovery day
author: Kyle B.

description: Sweet spot. So not a hotel, either. I love how there is no sign and simply a  "B." I was first told that this is a secret spot, but I don't think it's a secret anymore! The wine selection is great and the cheese choices are great...they give ya a nice amount of bread as well! I would love to go again.
author: Anita C.

description: Fantastic little wine bar in the alley behind Zuni, with a great wine list and delicious cheeses to make sure you don't get too drunk. I met up with a few girlfriends for some vino and good conversation, and we found everything we needed and wanted for the night. You have to go up to the bar to order, but if you order food, they will bring it to you. It's cozy and dark inside, and it does get loud when it fills up, but really, it's the perfect place for a few friends. I'll be looking for an excuse to come back on my next visit to SF!
author: Jennifer L.

description: I've been here a couple of times and Biron Hotel is definitely becoming one of my favorite drinking spots, so why four stars when they have one of the finest wine selections in SF? The price of the cheese to accompany your perfect glass of wine is a bit pricey. Love the service, love the ever changing art on the walls, and definitely love the crowd.
author: Crf C.

description: A dark swank wine bar perfect for liaisons of the date variety.  The prices aren't cheap but their little cheese, olive and meat plates are delicious as is all the wine.    The charm of the place is its small size, dim lighting (anyone do it in the back room yet?) and fantastic artwork featuring a revolving cycle of local artists.  A perfect place to find out if you and s/he are ever going to make out, or to revitalize that romantic spark in your otherwise dead relationship...I just saying.  Hotel Biron loses one star from me for price through really, it is probably worth it.
author: Ian H.

description: This is a great little wine bar: intimate, cozy... The wine selection is fabulous. Wonderful place to gather with friends and chat the night away. I will be back, oh yes! I will be back!
author: Ange M.

description: Hotel Biron is a cool little spot to relax with good friends and a glass of wine. They also have a nice beer menu and are happy to answer questions about the wine and the beer.
author: J F.

description:
love alleyway entrance.

love exposed brick.

love olives and cheese.

love polite gentlemen buying wine for our table in attempt to hit on my gorgeous friends.

love hotel biron.
author: shaine h.

description: A quaint space with sexy lighting and cool artwork.  This place is romantic but not too romantic - you can still go there with friends and hang out.  Great wine selection and a knowledgeable staff.
author: christine c.

description: My favorite little place. Love it when it's not crowded and you can cozy up with your friends over a nice bottle of wine and cheese plate. i've had 2 birthday parties here. Thinking about having a third.
author: Leslie T.

description: Cool for a date, to just chill. It's an upscale wine bar. The only bummer is the location...
author: Michael S.

description: Thank God they are under new ownership. That guy who formerly owned it was basically a younger version of the crabby bartender of the Owl Tree. This is a cool place to hang out - very laid back. Good cheese platters and wine.
author: Stephanie I.

description: what a great little place. Dark, romantic, simple. Perfect way to start a date over a  glass of wine and a cheese plate, or end it late at night, making out on the couch in the back room, if you can get in. If you are doing Hayes Valley, you have to go here.
author: William A.

description: What a great find! The wine here is so good and the ambiance is so European, what a great little place to take a date before or after dinner. I think it would deserve 5 stars if only they would come to your table to take your wine order, but the staff are really cordial and they know a lot about the wine the serve.
author: Stephen M.

description: I can't believe I have spent so many awesome nights in this place and have yet to write it an appropriate review.  This has got to be the bar where I feel the most comfortable, the most happy, the most transported back to a simpler way of doing things, thinking about things... oh, and feel like I'm at some hidden gem of a bar in an alleyway in Paris.  Yes, they've definitely got the Parisian look and feel hands down here - exposed brick and stone, wrought iron fixtures, very dim lighting, classic looking bar.  The wines by the glass list runs the gamut, touching every major wine producing region across the world giving you plenty of room to explore and experiment.  Oh, and the classic French nibbles like charcuterie, pate, cheeses, etc. pair wonderfully with the wines - and are quite generous portions.  I've honestly made a whole meal out of a couple of plates of the generous nibbles they have here.  This is definitely my favorite wine bar and is in the running for my favorite bar period.  I always have an amazing time here... this place just has a knack for keeping dates and friends on their best behavior ensuring a relaxing, joyful evening.
author: Chris P.

description: I have a soft spot on my palate for delicious wine, and an even softer spot in my heart for great wine bars. Hotel Biron was my second stop on my mid-week out-of-towner in San Fran tour of this very cute block on Market. Located around the corner from Zuni and Cav, Hotel Biron is a dark wood, intimate spot, where the owner Chris is more than happy to serve you exactly what you want, even if you, (as is the situation in my case) use descriptions such as "a wine that doesn't burn my tongue and tastes good but not too much like 1 year old raisins from my pantry."
author: Courtney P.

description: Nice big pours, room to breathe and a decent cheese menu. I'll definitely be back with friends on the weekend or coworkers post-work day. The cheese plate is quite generous - but the salami is a little on the tough side. Nice folks working there and lots of seating room. Try it - you'll feel like you've uncovered a hidden gem. :)
author: Deann M.

description: This is a wine bar, only serving a selection of appetizers appropriate to their current wine list. But what a wine bar! Small, intimate, very romantic, with a mixture of small tables and comfy couches, with helpful, knowledgeable staff. Prices are reasonable, and pours are significant! They also have a rotating gallery of local art, featuring a new artist every month.
author: Don H.

description: Hotel Biron is the perfect spot to have a drink on a Tuesday night.  The bar is perfectly occupied, bustling but not so busy that you can't find a table.  The crowd is casual and low key.  I usually feel tragically uphip at wine bars in this city.  Not at Biron.  I found the environment to be welcoming and low key.  I have no idea what the scene is like on the weekend, but I highly recommend it for a midweek drink.
author: sarah k.

description: Hotel Biron is quite possibly my favorite bar in all of San Francisco. First of all it's right behind my house in my favorite neighborhood--Hayes Valley. Second of all, it is the most relaxing yet lively place to sit down with your buddies talk, eat, and drink. They give you free samples when you are trying to decide which wine to drink. They also have amazing art exhibits by local SF artists that change on a monthly basis. HB--I love you!
author: Shyla B.

description: Great wine bar with friendly staff (although I miss their old bartender Trevor!). Depending on the night, Biron can be loud and crowded or quiet and romantic. The wine selection is good-- including a sparkling shiraz!-- and this is the perfect spot for an after-dinner glass of port or muscat.  The rotating art collection always makes for a good coversation starter.
author: shoba d.

description: Hotel Biron is cute but this is not my wine bar.  It is a novel approach to have patrons go to buy their wine as they would a latte or even any other beverage.  I find their selection not terribly interesting and the appeal is trying to appeal to too many paletes.  I agree Chris is a super nice guy with no attitude.  in the wine world that is rarely the case.  my only request-- more comfy chairs.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Really nice. Had a 30$ bottle of Rhone red with a friend and really enjoyed the atmosphere. The art on the walls was a bit of a downer, but hey, the whole experience was really fun and not stuffy at all. It was perfectly busy for a Thursday night, but I could see it getting too busy over the weekend. Regardless, reasonable wines. Nice staff. Cool atmosphere. Little out of the way space. I'll be back... many times.
author: Matt C.

description: I checked this place out on Monday, and it lived up to all the hype.  The wine selection was impressive, and the staff friendly.  Its tiny, but yet it gives you a cozy romantic feeling when you are on date or out with the girls.  Definitely one of new favorite places to go.
author: Emmy B.

description: Hotel Biron is one of my favorite places in SF. Come after work; it's the quiet and cozy antithesis to happy hour. Love their wine selections and fruit/cheese platters. Good place if you're looking for an intimate setting, or for toasting a birthday with a few close friends...
author: Dora A.

description:
wow, that cheese plate - the picture- yeah, it's GREAT
really good wines although i don't know a lot of them, they are helpful and will pick out exactly what you are looking for.
i love this place, small cute and really cool
author: Scott K.

description: I love the exposed brick and cozy couches--but if you get there too late, you have to sit on the uncomfortable wrought-iron stools which don't encourage me to stay too long. Though it's not quite the kind of place to go for drinks by myself, their bottles are fabulous, and if I manage to get there right at 5pm I can grab a glass of Santa Barbara Pinot and a cheese plate and read until the sun goes down.
author: Molly A.

description: A tiny, quaint, wine-bar that is so small, if you blink while driving up Rose Street, you'll miss it.  Find it and enter and you're sure to enjoy a cozy atmosphere with a large and affordable selection of wines, excellent cheeses, salami, and olives to boot!  I can't complain about much, but I would imagine that this place would be kind of a drag if it was packed.  There is so little room that you're literally sitting back to back with the table behind you.  Outside of that, it's a great stop before or after Zuni's or the Brazilian grill next door.
author: Ross H.

description: A nice, cozy spot to sip on some wine without all the snob attitude.  Nice vibe. Definitely a place to help you get laid.
author: Ezduzit S.

description: Because of the back alley location and it's proximity to Zuni I felt like it was the younger hipper little brother of that cafe. For what it is (an intimate 2-3 person per table-max wine bar) it's great. Even though it is this close to Zuni it's not overrun (nor will it ever be) by the more fleeting and fickle crowd who would head there. I wouldn't hesitate to take a date here for that after-dinner 2nd glass of wine. I might head here with an out of town couple as well, but I think this is best visited on a slow night without pre-planning.
author: Mike M.

description: We were here on an unusually busy night, so seating was hard to come by...but we eventually grabbed a table and I had a great glass of Chilean wine accompanied by bread and cheese.  My wine was $12, so the prices are a bit steep...They have interesting artwork and a nice little lounge in the back.  It's location in an alley behind Zuni Cafe makes you feel as though you've stumbled upon a hidden gem.
author: Allison S.

description: its cozy and lit just right-the folks there always have something  good to reccomend. They have great wine and cheese pairings.
author: Helen J.

description: The wines, well-selected; the light, low; the feel, not quite an oasis, but a well-chosen, well-burrowed niche.
author: Joe G.

description: I went there for a birthday party. It was good for that because there aren't that many other people there. It got crowded but the bartender did a great job.  Wine is mostly $8 - 11 a glass. What the menu doesn't tell you is that they also serve beer.
author: Amy E.

description: On my birthday, I wanted the BEST of everything.  All the best that this city could offer, alcohol...that is.  And I thought, the best wine bar in SF had to be Hotel Biron - our first stop of the nite!   They have the best cheese plate here, a phenomenal wine selection.  Of course, in addition to glasses of champagne we chugged on the party bus, red wine was a dangerous chaser.  This bar is tiny with a warm and intimate vibe.  It's a great spot for a big party on an empty night, and since this was our first stop, we were able to overtake the bar and make it our own private party.  But don't rule this place out if you're thinking of where to take your date.  Hotel Biron is electic and romantic.
author: Wendy H.

description: Wine list is OK, but not much is served by the glass. The place is too small for this I guess. Was unlucky in getting a completely ruined 97 Barolo, which was adequately replaced with a new bottle though. Atmosphere is comfortable, art on the walls is a bonus. Had great company, which always has an influence on the jury of course.
author: Michiel D.

description: Excellent -- a great place for a first date, 15th date, with friends...good wine list, a knowledgeble, helpful and not overbearing bartender,nice cheese & fruit plates, great atmosphere.
author: dannebrog ..

description: hmmm, Catch 22 posting a Yelp review about the Hotel Biron because part of its charm is its discreetness. I love this place for its intimate setting and hidden location. Great, great wine list, fabulous cheeses, and very helpful staff. Last time I was there you were playing Neutral Milk Hotel so bonus points for that. Anyway, great little date spot, esp. if you want cred points for knowing of somewhere off the beaten path.
author: Saleema F.

description: It is about time. This place is unpretentious. Most of the wine bars in this city are filled with wannabes, and hotel biron is so casual. It would be so easy to hang out here every night. The ambiance is cozy, romantic, interesting, and conducive to hanging out with a group of friends. Everything you want in a wine bar, without all the annoying rubber necking posers.
author: SF U.

description: Lovely little wine bar - space can be an issue, so not really great for large groups, although when we were here last time, we did manage to squeeze 12 of us in there, so it can be done.  Very cozy and somehow, feels like you are in Paris.
author: Jenn K.

description: Amazing host! Sexy as fuck atmosphere! Killer wines with the best suggestions to your likes around. Artsy. Tucked away. Top notch wine and cheese.  I love it!
author: Chard M.

description: I love the back alley feel of this place and it is pretty warm and cosy. But try to get there early to get seats. The atmosphere is great for chilling with your pals but it can get really loud after a while. The Pierre Robert cheese platter is really yummy and worthwhile
author: Topazskye L.

description: Love this place.  Really dark and cozy interior, good wine selection (though some of it is a bit overpriced imo) and a great cheese selection.  It doesn't ever seem to be too crowded when I'm there so I'm hoping these reviews won't change that.
author: Victoria G.

description: Good wine. Good space. Good cheese. Good location. Good art. Good soundtrack.  A lively mix of people.  A bench outside to sit on if you enjoy a smoke. Or just a chat.  Tables? Check. Cozy couches? Check.  And just out of the way enough to feel a little special.  If you were a boy, Biron, I would have a big ole crush on you.
author: Tristan C.

description:
There is nothing quite like ending a hard day at work with a glass of wine and a cheese plate with serra de estrella at hotel biron.
This spot has a comfortable and relaxing ambiance. It doubles as an Art Gallery with work from different artist which always adds a unique touch to every visit.
They have many wines by the glass available and you can order a cheese plate until like 12am which is great for us restaurant folk who don't really feel like Jack in the Box downtown.
Hotel Biron is awesome but not as awesome as Chris.
author: Caroline G.

description: A teeny wine bar and peudo-art gallery in an alley. Hard to find, excellent border-town atmosphere -- that "communal, gathering around the kitchen" feel at the end of a party where no one has to get up the next day.
author: John M.

description: Great little hidden spot to have drinks with friends. My only warning to you is don't go when it's pouring down rain because the place smells like wet sock. They have a great selection of international wines and cheeses to go with it.
author: Palak P.

description: Nice and cozy interior. Pretty much perfect for our girls' gathering on Wednesday night. The wine selection was good and I love that they offer tasty cheeses that can be accompanied by bread, water crackers, or fruit. I'll definitely be back..
author: Sylvia C.

description: Hidden out of the way, it was a wonderful find.  I started going on a regular basis for a while but, it's become a bit of a hot spot lately so it's hard to get a seat depending on the time of day.  The staff has been very helpful and very informative when it comes to choosing a new wine.  Each time I let them know what I've liked in the past and what I was looking for in my next choice they were right on the mark.  The layout has little seating areas where you can sit with a small group or just choose a table for two.  The exposed brick walls and lighting are comforting as well.
author: Carl C.

description: Cool, swanky wine bar. Seems like the perfect place to meet up for an assignation.
author: Amanda S.

description: I'll throw 3.75 staaaas on it. Its a great place to wait for your table at Zuni. Small intimate and cozy. Has both beer and wine so everyone in your group will be somewhat happy. Not super impressed with the wine selection - not that i'm a wine snob but sometimes something really blows your mind and nothing here so far did. Will definitely go back.
author: Lauren D.

description: Terrific and well appointed little hole in the wall. Good first date place.
author: Eric G.

description: I've been coming to this place for about three years now, and have loved how knowledgeable the bartenders are, how delicious the charcutrie places are, and how amazing the atmosphere is. When I take my friends out for a glass of wine, we go here. When I had a crappy day and want to leave the house for a good read and some wine, I come here. I really don't know what else to say, but it's really an amazing place.
author: Edwin M.

description: Hotel Biron is really sweet.  Nice ambience and kind of like a secret little hide out...which is always good.  The crowd can be a little pretentious (kind of like the crown at 111 Minna...you feel me?)  So yeah, but overall, wonderful spot.  Staff is friendly.  Yum cheese yum wine!
author: Rikki D.

description:
Ohhhh....I have been waiting to rip into this place, since everyone that has been there thinks this place is heaven.  I cant believe all the good yelp reviews on this place.  It is literally so sad.  From first glance it seems like it is going to be a cute little wine bar, tucked away in an alley off market street. But it is actually an old run down hole in the wall, that put up some really cheap crappy decor and then dimmed the lights.
All the table are super sticky and wobble, its stuffy with poor ventilation, the floor is caked with dirt.  I am not even sure what the floor was actually, I felt like I was walking through a construction site, with all the uneven surfaces they have going on there. Oh and the one bathroom lock doesnt work, and people kept walking in on each other, and when you open the door up on someone, everyone in the back room can see you sitting on the toilet as they sip their wine.

Felt like I was at a marina wine bar....  I would say almost every one around me was drinking rose and white wine.....so like i said......little wine knowledge going on...because if there were...reason I am giving it one star.....half the wine they had sitting back behind the bar,  that they were serving had gone bad, and no one seemed to know any better.
So whatever, I throw up my hands.  I seriously think that you can open up a wine bar in this city and serve grocery store wine from another country, charge 15 dollars a glass, and no one would even know any better.
I dont know, maybe the 4 bad wines I tried was just a fluke....
author: Allie M.

description: i really liked their food plates.  service is so so. atmosphere is always chill and relaxed. i would go here again.
author: b l.

description: Reminded me of a wine bar in an Italian fortress because of the stone walls and narrow space.  The selection is fairly impressive, the staff knowledgeable, and it has a very unpretentious vibe (especially compared to other wine bars in the city) where it's easy to just "chill."  It's a great place to detox on a weeknight, and also offers small plates.  The cheese plate and artichoke dip are the only ones I've had, and they're fine complements to the wines.
author: Suhani K.

description: Cozy little place, I've been coming here for some time.  The wine list is good, the food a bit limited.  The bathroom occasionally needs some major help.  Service is fine and very helpful as long as it's not too packed.  Overall, one of the the better wine bars in the city.
author: marie m.

description: Never too crowded unless there is an art event going on. This small little spark of goodness at an alley off of Market Street is great for late weekday evenings. Have sushi at the Sushi Zone or dinner at Zuni then walk over to Hotel Biron for some great wine.
author: Esso E.

description: Yeah, it gets a little stuffy in there.  And yes, sometimes it takes forever to  order a glass of wine but I love this place.  It's one of my neighborhood haunts so I've been countless times and can't seem to find anything negative to say.  After the closure of Hayes and Vine I was forlorn and filled the void by going to Hotel Biron.  It's turned out to be a favorite wine bar.
author: Anne D.

description: Perfect date spot in an abysmal neighborhood (sorry, Market Street). Loved the selection - short, implying confidence in the offering - and the cheese is always a great compliment. Great space, great lighting, everything is DIY (including fetching of wine - no wait staff, just a bartend). A definite destination wine bar. I've been half a dozen times.
author: Eric S.

description:
oh, comfy couch how i love your embrace.   

earthy european wine in hand, tasty cheese on which to nibble, another nod to the aforementioned seating and... viola!  what more could a girl want?  

the staff will let you try a sip of any vintage you are considering and will help steer you to just the "peppery but not too peppery and with a bit of cherry but not too much so" that you had a hankering for.

whether it's unexpected guests in town on a sunday evening or a friday night out with "schmoopie," hotel biron has been a treat.
author: julia p.

description:
OK...here goes. Went to the wine bar last night for a going away party for a friend. The place was a sardine can to start with. A friend put it in a  not so polite way--"Feels like the Marina threw up here..." 
The service was slow--the cheese plater took about 15min to come out. OK. you cut the cheese and put it on the plate with bread. 
Short staffed--as I heard the disgruntled bartender complain about it being too crowded for a Tuesday. 
Next...
author: Jack F.

description: Pleasant lighting and interesting wall art, lighthearted mood and over all semi-trendy ambiance. It is a long thin room, much quieter at the back. We went on a Thursday night--clearly a good during the week place to go. Order at the bar, take your wine to your table.
author: Alex S.

description: I really like it here.  It's comfy. cozy and a great place to chill after work.  It gets a little crowded since its on the small side, but get there early for a seat on the couch and it is absolutely wonderful.  Good wine, good cheese, good service... what more could one ask for?
author: Allison G.

description: great ambiance. perfect for a cozy evening with a bottle of wine.
author: Sky B.

description:
Tucked away in a not so intimdating crack alley, lays this gem.
I come late night after work, to unwind a have a glass or two of wine. Their portions of cheese and charcuterie are enormous. For $5 per selection you get a nice "healthy" slice. I'm down for the duck/pork fat.
author: t f.

description: What a killer space.  Small intimate and friendly.  A good list and very reasonably priced.  If I ever get another date I am taking her here for sure.
author: brian m.

description: Love this place or a great glass of wine. I went here with my freind Karen before dinner at Zuni - they have a fabulous cheese plate and great atmosphere.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Such a cute, intimate place to have a glass of wine (or three in my case) and nibbles in Hayes Valley. The choices were excellent, though I wish they had a slightly larger food selection. But then again, you don't go to a wine bar to eat, do you? I love the fact that this is on a little sidestreet off Market...keeps it a bit of secret.
author: Madhavi K.

description: Great, "secret" little spot, but the prices are exorbitant!
author: elizabeth b.

description: My favorite wine bar in the city...and I love me a wine bar. This place has the feel of a little place hidden away in a small Parisian alley. Well selected wine list, fabulous cheese plate, and a (usually) low-key group of people here. If you prefer see and be seen kind of places with tons of Marina-ites, head to District. If you like good wines in a funky, low-key atmosphere, Biron is the place.
author: SL N.

description: Great brick cozy, art-on-the-wall place with beer, wine and kind of a swanky feel without a busy scene.  Order the cheese platter..it's delicious with some pate.  The service is non-pretentious and the ambiance is intimate but sometimes stuffy.
author: regina k.

description: A fun little hide out that keeps a cozy atmosphere...
author: David G.

description: A nice but cozy place...lighting could be better and energy level is okay.  Its a nice place to take a friend for a drink and to talk.  Its has its pros and cons...but overall a nice place.
author: Temoor N.

description: Great atmosphere! Wonderful wine list and yummy small plates.  Great place to meet up with a small group; super sexy place!
author: Tameka L.

description: This was a great little wine bar sort of tucked away from the main crowds.  The wine was reasonably priced with a large selection and great cheeses to go along with everything.  We showed up on a friday night and still didn't have any issue finding a table relatively quickly even though the space is somewhat smaller.  Overall, this is definitely a great spot and I plan on coming back quite often.
author: nick g.

description:
The wine list is great.  The pours vary, which is fine.  The inner decor is fantastic, especially the raw brick wall.  

However, every time I have been there, the noise level has been excessive.  It's nearly impossible to hold an conversation without resorting to near-yelling, which is not what I seek in a wine bar.
author: Eric S.

description: 4 Stars on an off-night when it's not raining.  It's just a great, tucked-away little spot to catch up w/ your lovable friends one-on-one.  Stay away when it is raining.  There's no circulation; it gets gnarly up in that shizzle, right quick.
author: Shimmalicious S.

description:
pros: great place, great wine, very good ambiance, in a nice area (hayes valley)
cons: awful acoustics, it can get really loud
author: Lucas G.

description: Been coming here for a while, and it never ceases to give me that feeling of "this is a great wee place"!
author: Heather F.

description: sorry hotel biron, docking some stars because your unisex bathroom lock doesn't reliably work. i've experienced this on several occasions... someone flinging the bathroom door open while people are using it. might wanna get that fixed.
author: C C.

description: I would say for atmosphere it gets a 4 star rating, but for customer service and wine selection, I would give it a 1 or 2 star rating, a resounding C-/D+ grade.  The owner pushes expensive wines on you that never blew my mind, and often were just plain fine, perhaps good, never amazing.  I think their prices are very high for wine that is just fine. But my main gripe is that it is loud, too crowded (good for them, I suppose) and they won't allow you to reserve the back room (or any one table).  I was coming there for a monthly meet-up, and bringing 5-10 people each month with me; but I finally gave up the location, since my monthly attendance apparently did not count for event a table top sign to reserve my spot. Now we buy a bottle of the same "just fine" wine for the same price they charge for a glass.  Sorry but although they are a nice venue, they could use some help building customer loyalty.
author: Susan T.

description: Wine. Art. Alley. Bricks.
author: Jeff B.

description: exposed brick, great photography, quaint space, little flickering lights, and mod furniture. this place is charming without being too romantic. oh, and the wine is good too.
author: miss lisa k.

description: Pricey.  The Teirra Prometidos, for eg, costs 13 per glass. Or 33 per btl. Its 13 per bottle at K&L.  I see that they should charge at least the wholesale price of a bottle for a glass, just in case noone else drinks from that bottle,  but here they're charging way too much per glass  for a cheap Malbec.
author: B M.

description: Hotel Biron is so cute and cozy---a great place to go for a first date---and just like home (or rather, the home I wish I had).  My date and I sat on the comfortable couch in the walkway on our visit, with prime views of the bar area and of the artsy wall-hangings; I could've curled up right there and stayed all night if it were not true that all good things must come to an end.
author: Hannah J.

description: too small, cold, damp and dreary, great if you need to write a sad novel
author: Porfirio R.

description: i love this lil' wine bar. it reminds me of a wine bar you would find off a little alley in barcelona or paris -- very european charm and the wine selection is fabulous as well. i had my first glass of red champers there...mmmm...
author: sandy o.

description: this out of the way wine bar in hayes valley is a great spot to meet someone on a first date or post dinner drink.  grab an argentinian wine, order up some roasted olives and triple cream cheese, and enjoy the low key lighting and contemporary art draped on the walls.  its the kinda place that could easily be in the village in nyc.  worth going to.
author: Kevin J.

description: such a cozy little place with rotating art.  the wine selection of course is nice, but i love the cheese selections.
author: sarah C.

description: i love this place and i'm not sure what took me so long to review it.  i love everything about this place and i don't think there's any place quite like it in san francisco.  great location - it's down an alley off of market.  nice ambiance - it's intimate and it's slightly dark but not too dark.  nice couches.  and great wine and cheese.
author: michelle k.

description: awesome space, great wine and a hop from zuni
author: David F.

description: now this is what a wine bar should be like -- small, unpretentious and laid back.  my only complaint is that when it's packed, the fact that there is no service is a drag.  it's also down the street from my crib and easy to get to.
author: rerun w.

description:
swank little neighborhood niche. love the decor and a great place to sit down and have conversation. comfortable seating and very laid back atmosphere. interesting art and nice alternative for a weekday night that you want to get out of the house for a few hours.

my favorite.
author: J K.

description: Perfect for a week-night glass of wine (on the weekends it can get a little too crowded for the tiny space, but during the week it's usually easy to find a spot). The wine selection is expansive, but not overwhelming, and the cheese is a little pricey ($6 per piece), but the portions are not tiny. The alley-way entrance, exposed brick wall, and the candlelight all make it super cozy.
author: Ilona G.

description: The Hotel Biron is really cute.  It's just a tiny little wine bar located in a small little alley behind Market Street.  The venue could host a maximum of forty people stuffed.  It's dark and intimate.  The bar is all of six feet, but it feels friendly and comfy.  The staff is amenable, the first glass I ordered was corked and they took it back and gave me a different wine sans questions.  The crowd was hip and cute, fun people enjoying the wines and having a good time.  They do art exhibits and I was there when they had a very interesting display of a local group that specialized in kinetic art and regular art. The kinetic art was hypnotizing (something about blood platelets running through the veins, but I couldn't stop watching it).  The menu is sparse, but quality.  Cheeses, salami and olives all served with bread.  Finally, there's the wine list, which for the most part is very Euro-centric, but very good and quite reasonably priced.  They also have beers, and some interesting non-alcoholic drinks like Fizzy Lizzy's Pomegranate and Apple juice.  You'll love this place.  Cheers.
author: Nicolas T.

description: My favorite place. I love it here. The service is great and I love the "Old World" feel inside. I always look forward to going!!! The wine selection is great without being overwhelming!!!
author: ersy s.

description: a chill place to grab a nice glass of wine or beer in a very European setting.  during the week, it's a great place to end up where you and your date can get to know one another.
author: Vic A.

description: cool place in a hidden alley. ideal for a quick stop when you'ew out for the night. would have never found this place if it wasn't for my friend who'd already been here. Artsy dark ambience. They allow a mini wine tasting before you order a glass or bottle. Nice service. Place is small. A couple couches, but mostly chairs. Good wine bar for dates if you want to avoid a loud bar or restaurant. very mellow if you're in the mood for it.
author: Food L.

description: i want to like this place, i really do, and i dig the euro ambience, the owner, and the rotating art, but i don't like any of the wines. oh well. we went on a thursday, right at 5, and the owner poured me a selection of wines from south africa, france, spain, greece, etc, to try, and me no rikey. i like my california wines, bitches. but once i settled back on the couch and began quaffing, my cares melted away. feels like an outdoor cafe inside. dim candlelight. gets crowded and it aint cheap. good for tete a tete dates or planning world domination.
author: Mary V.

description: i love the outside of this hidden little bar - just a dark door, with a little B sign.  very non-descript and mysterious.  i have passed by a few times and always thought, i wonder what that bar is... well now i know that its a cute wine bar.  i stopped in with some friends on friday and we had a few bottles of wine.  at first we had trouble finding seats but even though it was a little crowded, something opened up.  there are lots of little tables and seating areas.  its very dark and cozy there - definitely a great spot to stop in for a drink before dinner at a nearby restaurant on market street or hayes valley.
author: Carolyn B.

description: Cozy, great wine and yummy cheese. Not pretentious... nothing to say other than AWESOME.
author: Patricia M.

description: great ambiance -- luv the weirdo art all over the walls, quick service (although it's more of self serve), great cheese plates, and pretty good wine for a good price.  plus 30% off industry nights on monday?!?!  can't go wrong.  i must say it can be hard to get a table here at times since it's so tiny, but wait 5-10 minutes and usually something will open up.
author: Latef X.

description: one of my very favorite wine bars in the city.  i'm a big fan of their carefully selected wines by the glass, as well as the generously-portioned cheese plate.  i also like the intimacy of the little back room area next to the restrooms :)
author: melita s.

description: Hotel Biron, the name is deceiving but it is one of the best wine bar: The atmosphere reminds me of what wine is about, romance, friends, great conversation, music, and just enjoying the pleasures of life. This place is by no means shallow or pretentious just a really a small, swanky, hidden gem with modern world furniture and local art work on top of it all. The owner Chris is a very cool with a great attitude. A very nice guy who knows his wines. He of course tastes and buys them. Get a cheese plate while you taste some great European whites.
author: Ron B.

description: love this place, faab, fab, fab! the only thing not so fab is the smell of cheese, but hey, it's cheese!! what's not to love about cheese?!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description:
mmm... Biron... how do i love thee... is it the wine?  could be, it's tasty, perfectly chilled (if that's what is called for) and deliciously served by attentive bartenders who give you 'tastes' that would make the sommeliers in Napa blush...
is it the cheese?  could be, there's something about a good cheese plate that sort of makes me weak in the knees...
or is the people? most definitely, everytime I've been into Biron I've met some cool-ass peeps (from a girl who was getting ready to display her work on the walls the next week) to a jewelry designing girlfriend with a studio in the basement.  yum.
author: Anjali K.

description: i went here after dinner at Jardiniere was it.? no it wasnt. It was a restaurant on the corner near Hotel Biron. So, if anyone knows what restaurant that could have been let me know, perhaps. What can I say that has not been said hidden in an alley, and art decor for sale?  The wine guy was nice, he was knowledgeable,  and there was a lesbian group there that evening. i dont think, I could convert them. Oh,I had a gf then.
author: Andrew K.

description: Great little place for a private gathering. The best thing about this place is you can bring in your own personal chef so you're not limited by the menu.
author: Gina S.

description: a definite gem. my favorite wine bar. brick walls, cool art, little nooks and crannies for romance or good chatter with a friend. they let you taste before you buy, which is nice.
author: yasmin k.

description: I sometimes feel as though this is my own little place and I don't want to tell anyone about it.  I have had great luck here recently, always snagging the back room for some lounging and wine.  The cheese selection is always on par and it's a cool little out of the way bar that is never a "scene."  I only go on weeknights, so maybe that's my luck.  Great place to bring a date who think they know every place in the city.
author: Evan A.

description: The strength of this place is really its ambience -- the tucked-away location and dim lighting make me feel like I've discovered a great bar in Vienna or somewhere. The wine selection is huge and the cheese plate is lovely, but they're on the expensive side, so it's mostly worth going when you're in the mood for mood.
author: Page R.

description: we love biron!! good wine selection...cheese and service is awesome..they don't kick you out until you finish ur wine...darkj enough that is so relaxing...we think alot of people in the restaurant  business come in biron to just chill and relax after a long busy night ...
author: denise m.

description: I love this whole in the wall, neighborhood wine bar where the locals hang out. I wish it was mine.
author: Fiona Z.

description: put on your fancy pants!  you'll feel like you walked into another country.
author: pauline e.
